It is hard to imagine a good death in the purgatory of an intensive-care unit.'b'Ann Braude'b'\n Cambridge, Mass., Dec. 23, 2009'b''b''b'The writer is on the faculty of Harvard Divinity School.'b''b'WHAT is an e-book?'b'News that the heirs of William Styron, the author of \xe2\x80\x9cSophie\xe2\x80\x99s Choice,\xe2\x80\x9d are licensing the electronic-publishing rights for some of his Random House books to Open Road Integrated Media got me to pondering: Are e-books a new frontier in publishing, a fresh version of the author\xe2\x80\x99s work? Or are they simply the latest editions of the books produced by publishers like Random House?'b'It was an old-fashioned book publisher who decided that William Styron\xe2\x80\x99s work was worth reading in the first place. Hiram Haydn signed him up and edited his debut novel, \xe2\x80\x9cLie Down in Darkness,\xe2\x80\x9d which Random House published in 1951. As Mr. Styron himself later said, both Mr. Haydn and his subsequent Random House editor, Robert Loomis, had a \xe2\x80\x9cgenius for catching me out in my weakest or most slipshod moments, but never tried to impose their ideas on mine. It\xe2\x80\x99s the moral support that\xe2\x80\x99s been so valuable.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In the course of his career, Mr. Styron published nine other books with Random House, each of which received the scrupulous line-by-line attention of one of the great editors of the time. Each was also copy-edited through several stages of proof that were passed back and forth among the copy editor, Mr. Styron and Mr. Loomis.'b'The appropriate typeface was chosen and submitted to the author for approval by Random House\xe2\x80\x99s designers, and a binding was selected. A dust jacket \xe2\x80\x94 often involving art specially commissioned by Random House to represent and advertise the book \xe2\x80\x94 was designed, and copy intended to induce reviewers and readers to pick the book up and pay attention to it was written.'b'Employees of the Random House publicity department then talked about the books with anyone who would listen and submitted bound proofs to newspapers and magazines for review, while the Random House sales department obtained advance orders from booksellers. The Random House rights department, working in concert with Mr. Styron\xe2\x80\x99s agent, pitched the books to magazine editors, movie agents and foreign publishers.'b'Large-print versions for the reading-impaired and audio versions were produced, marketed and sold by Random House or licensed to others, and, after a suitable period, cheaper paperback versions were also published.'b'For each book, Random House exploited its edition in every then-conceivable format. And through it all, Mr. Loomis and his colleagues kept in touch with Mr. Styron, monitoring the life of the book through its various permutations.'b'Recently, a new, previously unimagined version of the work became a possibility: Mr. Styron\xe2\x80\x99s books can now be reproduced and distributed electronically.'b'The author\xe2\x80\x99s heirs hold the copyright to his work. But should another company be able to issue e-book versions of Random House\xe2\x80\x99s editions without its involvement?  An e-book version of Mr. Styron\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cThe Confessions of Nat Turner\xe2\x80\x9d will contain more than the author\xe2\x80\x99s original words. It will also comprise Mr. Loomis\xe2\x80\x99s editing, as well as all the labor of copy editing, designing and producing, not to mention marketing and sales, that went into making it a desirable candidate for e-book distribution. Mr. Styron\xe2\x80\x99s books took the form they have, are what they are today, not only because of his remarkable genius but also, as he himself acknowledged, because of the dedicated work of those at Random House.'b'In this increasingly virtual age of open access and universal availability, it\xe2\x80\x99s important for readers to keep in mind what it is that a publisher does for an author. A publisher \xe2\x80\x94 and I write as one \xe2\x80\x94 does far more than print and sell a book. It selects, nurtures, positions and promotes the writer\xe2\x80\x99s work.'b'An e-book distributor is not a publisher, but rather a purveyor of work that has already been created. In this way, e-books are no different from large-print or paperback or audio versions. They are simply the latest link in an unbroken editorial chain, the newest format for one of man\xe2\x80\x99s greatest inventions: the constantly evolving, imperishable book \xe2\x80\x94 given its definitive form by a publisher.'b'Even if someday, God forbid, books are no longer printed, they will still need the thought and care and dedication that Mr. Loomis and his colleagues put into producing William Styron\xe2\x80\x99s work for nearly 60 years. Some things never change.'b'Nairobi, Kenya'b'LAST Monday, Somali pirates seized two more prizes in rapid succession: a British-flagged chemical tanker and a Greek bulk carrier, bringing the current number of captive ships to 12 and the number of hostage mariners to at least 278. Despite the presence in the region of three multinational naval task forces comprising about 30 warships, there were 68 successful pirate hijackings in 2009, compared with 49 one year earlier.'b'If the New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Day capture of an Indonesian tanker is any indication, 2010 will not herald an end to the attacks. As one Somali pirate told me last year: \xe2\x80\x9cSometimes, we capture ships when [warships] are right around us. We don\xe2\x80\x99t care about them. They\xe2\x80\x99re not going to stop us.\xe2\x80\x9d Indeed, the pirates\xe2\x80\x99 range has expanded to more than 1,000 miles off the Somali coast \xe2\x80\x94 as far as the Seychelles \xe2\x80\x94 and the futility of an exclusively naval strategy is increasingly apparent.'b'The situation is not without hope. There might be another way to make greater strides against pirates. However, it would involve allying ourselves with a place that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t exist: the autonomous region of Puntland, Somalia.'b'To the ancient Egyptians, the land of Punt was a source of munificent treasures and bountiful wealth. Modern  Puntland, a self-governing region in northeastern Somalia, may or may not be the successor to the Punt of legend. As I discovered when I first visited, last year, it contained none of the gold and ebony that dazzled the Egyptians, save perhaps for the color of the sand and the skin of the nomadic goat and camel herders who have inhabited it for centuries.'b'I arrived in Puntland in the frayed seat of a 1970s Soviet propeller plane. The 737s of Dubai, with their meal service and functioning seatbelts, were a distant memory; the plane I was on was not even allowed to land in Dubai, and the same probably went for the unkempt, ill-tempered Ukrainian pilot.'b'The state of the sole road running through Puntland\xe2\x80\x99s north-south axis is symbolic of the neglect the region experienced under its former dictator, Siad Barre \xe2\x80\x94 who was overthrown in 1991 at the onset of the Somali civil war \xe2\x80\x94 and from the international community since. The three-decade-old Chinese concrete was crumbling and corroded, with craterous potholes turning my 150-mile journey from the airport into a four- or five-hour jolting ordeal. It was the dry season, and parched shrubs dotted the barren landscape; the dust clung to my skin until my shirt felt like fine sandpaper.'b'I spent the next six weeks living in the regional capital, Garowe, amid the boom and bustle created by the recent influx of pirates\xe2\x80\x99 wealth from nearby coastal bases of operation. Conducting research with a local journalist \xe2\x80\x94 who is the son of Puntland\xe2\x80\x99s president, Abdirahman Farole \xe2\x80\x94 I gained an inside view into the workings of this fledgling and largely autonomous state within Somalia.'b'Contrary to the oft-recycled one-liners found in most news reports, Somalia is not a country ruled by anarchy. Indeed, it is a mischaracterization to even speak of Somalia as a uniform entity. It is an amalgamation of quasi-independent regions like Puntland, which was founded in 1998 as a tribal sanctuary for the hundreds of thousands of Darod-clan people fleeing massacres in the south. Puntland comprises one-quarter to one-third of Somalia\xe2\x80\x99s total land mass (depending on whom you talk to) and almost half of its coastline.'b'Straddling the shipping bottleneck of the Gulf of Aden and the Indian Ocean, it was the natural candidate to become the epicenter of the recent outbreak of Somali piracy. But inhabitants of Puntland enjoy a relatively violence-free existence, little troubled by the turmoil to the south. The region has experienced only one low-intensity civil conflict since its founding, a brief dispute in 2001 and 2002 between the presidential incumbent, Abdullahi Yusuf, and his challenger, Jama Ali Jama.'b'In any serious attempt to combat piracy, Puntland must play an integral role. Yet it is not recognized as a legitimate actor in the region  and has been financially abandoned by the international community, which continues to ignore the reality on the ground in favor of the flimsy transitional federal government, a 550-member parliamentary hodgepodge ruling over a few checkpoints in Mogadishu, hundreds of miles from any real pirate activity. A collection of ex-warlords and self-styled moderate Islamists, this is a government that does not govern; its M.P.\xe2\x80\x99s have no constituents, its ministers no portfolios, and it exercises nothing close to control of the violence within its supposed borders.'b'The perpetuation of this farce is inexplicable. At an April 2009 donor conference in Brussels, the international community pledged $250 million to finance, among other things, the training of a police force and the upkeep of the African Union mission in Mogadishu. This, despite the fact that politicians of the transitional government have a talent for making money vanish into thin air. A far better use of aid would be to augment Puntland\xe2\x80\x99s paltry $18 million budget, which is almost exclusively derived from port taxes.'b'Two weeks into my visit, I accompanied President Farole to Bossaso,  Puntland\xe2\x80\x99s sweltering northern metropolis (and largest city), on his first domestic tour since his election. Addressing an assembly of Somali businessmen one evening, he appealed for donations to pay for a list of absurdly modest projects: building a four-mile road from the livestock-inspection station to the port; replacing road signs on the lone highway, long ago stripped bare for the valuable metal; constructing a small hospital. As the members of the transitional government huddle in their Mogadishu barracks, waiting to collect their welfare checks, Mr. Farole is reduced to roaming the countryside, begging for alms.'b'Despite Puntland\xe2\x80\x99s limited capacity, Mr. Farole is committed to taking the fight to the pirates. Indeed, the government of Puntland has been advocating a strict policy of nonnegotiation with pirates since the beginning of the crisis. On those occasions that Puntland\xe2\x80\x99s tiny (and now defunct) coast guard has been given the authority by shipowners to liberate hijacked vessels, the pirates have tended to melt away, content to keep their lives rather than their prize.'b'Successful land operations in Puntland\xe2\x80\x99s coastal towns have accompanied these marine assaults. One afternoon, while in Bossaso, the president personally led a sudden raid on a gang of pirates preparing to shove off into the Gulf of Aden. These would-be hijackers joined the more than 100 convicted pirates, many with life sentences, being held in Puntland\xe2\x80\x99s lone prison.'b'It is unclear if an all-out assault would have worked with the pirates on board a multimillion-dollar lottery ticket like the Saudi oil supertanker Sirius Star, which was released last year after a huge ransom was paid. But the effect of international shipping companies consistently giving in to pirates\xe2\x80\x99 demands is clear: ransoms keep creeping steadily upward, highlighted by a reported $4 million paid to release the Chinese bulk carrier MV De Xin Hai on Dec. 28 \xe2\x80\x94 the highest publicly announced amount to date. Unless a concerted effort is made to prevent shipping companies from paying these ransoms, the hands of both international navies and the local authorities will be tied \xe2\x80\x94 and the pirates know it.'b'Meanwhile, the Puntland security forces, at sea and on land, are woefully undermanned, underfinanced and underequipped. The terrain encompassing the eastern coastal towns, including the infamous pirate haven of Eyl, is rugged and roadless. Any land operation has to originate in Bossaso or Garowe, home to the only military bases in the region, and it would involve transporting troops up to hundreds of miles by four-wheel drive. The logistical difficulties in deploying such a response make successful results extremely rare, and almost entirely dependent on timely local intelligence gathering. Without ample international assistance, Puntland\xe2\x80\x99s law-enforcement capacity is unlikely to improve.'b'Buttressing Puntland will not bring an end to the piracy problem. Because of a combination of increasing government security sweeps, hostility from the local people and the growing preference of the pirates to work in the relatively vacant Indian Ocean (and not the heavily patrolled Gulf of Aden), the locus of attacks has begun to shift from Eyl to ports farther south, particularly Harardhere.'b'But Puntland remains crucial, and success there might prove a model for similar action in Harardhere, which is governed by another regional administration distinct from the turbulent south, albeit an extremely weak one.'b'The way to begin is by siphoning to Puntland some of the money flowing into the bottomless coffers of the transitional government. If the international community is serious about ending Somali piracy, it must engage Puntland as a full-time partner.'b'Acknowledging its existence would be a sound first step.'b'Bush administration officials came up with all kinds of ridiculously offensive rationalizations for torturing prisoners. It\xe2\x80\x99s not torture if you don\xe2\x80\x99t mean it to be. It\xe2\x80\x99s not torture if you don\xe2\x80\x99t nearly kill the victim. It\xe2\x80\x99s not torture if the president says it\xe2\x80\x99s not torture.'b'It was deeply distressing to watch the  United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit sink to that standard in April when it dismissed a civil case brought by four former Guant\xc3\xa1namo detainees never charged with any offense. The court said former Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld and the senior military officers charged in the complaint could not be held responsible for violating the plaintiffs\xe2\x80\x99 rights because at the time of their detention, between 2002 and 2004, it was not \xe2\x80\x9cclearly established\xe2\x80\x9d that torture was illegal.'b'The Supreme Court could have corrected that outlandish reading of the Constitution, legal precedent, and domestic and international statutes and treaties. Instead, last month, the justices abdicated their legal and moral duty and declined to review the case.'b'A denial of certiorari is not a ruling on the merits. But the justices surely understood that their failure to accept the case would further undermine the rule of law.'b'In effect, the Supreme Court has granted the government immunity for subjecting people in its custody to terrible mistreatment. It has deprived victims of a remedy and Americans of government accountability, while further damaging the country\xe2\x80\x99s standing in the world.'b'Contrary to the view of the lower appellate court, it was crystal clear that torture inflicted anywhere is illegal long before the Supreme Court\xe2\x80\x99s 2008 ruling that prisoners at Guant\xc3\xa1namo, de facto United States territory, have a constitutional right to habeas corpus. Moreover, the shield of qualified immunity was not raised in good faith. Officials decided to hold detainees offshore at Guant\xc3\xa1namo precisely to try to avoid claims from victims for conduct the officials knew was illegal.'b'Reversing the Circuit Court would not have ended the matter. The plaintiffs would still have had to prove their case at trial. They deserved that chance. There are those who oppose trying to punish Bush-era lawlessness \xe2\x80\x94 some who argue that America should not look backward and some who excuse that lawlessness. But the rule of law rests on scrutinizing evidence of past behavior to establish accountability, confer justice and deter bad behavior in the future.'b'President Obama, much to his credit, has forsworn the use of torture, but politics and policy makers change and democracy cannot rely merely on the good will of one president and his aides. Such good will did not exist in the last administration. And the inhumane and illegal treatment of detainees could make a return in a future administration unless the Supreme Court sends a firm message that ordering torture is a grievous violation of fundamental rights.'b'Anyone who doubts the degree of executive branch pliability in this realm needs to consider this: The party that urged the Supreme Court not to grant the victims\xe2\x80\x99 appeal because the illegality of torture was not \xe2\x80\x9cclearly established\xe2\x80\x9d was the Obama Justice Department.'b'Even as many members of Congress resist as too hard or too costly the steps necessary to address global warming, American cities and states \xe2\x80\x94 the largest of which have carbon footprints bigger than those of most nations \xe2\x80\x94 have quietly been making serious commitments to curb emissions. Instead of finding reasons to do nothing, Congress should build on these actions to fashion a national response to climate change.'b'According to a recent 'b'study'b' by Environment America, an advocacy group, about half of the states have broad plans and specific regulations aimed at reducing carbon dioxide emissions. When fully realized, these actions would cut emissions by over 7 percent between now and 2020 \xe2\x80\x94 a sizable distance toward the 17 percent reductions President Obama promised at Copenhagen.'b'About half the reductions would come from proposed emission limits in six big states, plus a regional cap on power plant emissions adopted by New York and nine other Northeastern states. The other half would result from legally required increases in the use of alternative energy sources like wind \xe2\x80\x94 29 states have approved such mandates \xe2\x80\x94 as well as stronger state and city efficiency standards for appliances, lighting and buildings.'b'California\xe2\x80\x99s goal of cutting greenhouse gases by one-quarter by 2020 is plausible partly because the state has been so successful in improving the efficiency of its power plants and buildings, promoting renewable energy and insisting on fuel-efficient vehicles. The state recently approved strict new energy-efficiency requirements for television sets, which now account for 10 percent of the average household\xe2\x80\x99s energy use but are largely unregulated. The rules will save consumers $1 billion in energy bills and reduce carbon dioxide emissions by three million tons each year. Though that is just under 1 percent of current emissions, it is small steps like these that will take California to its overall goal.'b'In another positive move, New York City has adopted a new law requiring periodic \xe2\x80\x9cenergy audits\xe2\x80\x9d on 22,000 large commercial and residential buildings that account for half of the city\xe2\x80\x99s carbon dioxide emissions.'b'Owners will not be required to make renovations under the law,  although this idea should be revisited if the economy improves.  The expectation is that the prospect of saving energy costs over the long term will lead to major investments in more efficient heating and cooling systems. The law is a critical component of Mayor Michael Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s goal of reducing New York City\xe2\x80\x99s carbon emissions by 30 percent by 2030.'b'A national policy endorsed by Congress that puts a price on greenhouse gas emissions  is urgently needed. These states and cities shed a hopeful light on what this nation and others can and must achieve.'b'The United States, which has less than 5 percent of the world\xe2\x80\x99s population, has about one-quarter of its prisoners. But the relentless rise in the nation\xe2\x80\x99s prison population has suddenly slowed as many states discover that it is simply too expensive to overincarcerate.'b'Between 1987 and 2007 the prison population nearly tripled, from 585,000 to almost 1.6 million. Much of that increase occurred in states \xe2\x80\x94 many with falling crime rates \xe2\x80\x94 that had adopted overly harsh punishment policies, such as the \xe2\x80\x9cthree strikes and you\xe2\x80\x99re out\xe2\x80\x9d rule and drug laws requiring that nonviolent drug offenders be locked away.'b'These policies have been hugely costly. According to the Pew Center on the States, state spending from general funds on corrections increased from $10.6 billion in 1987 to more than $44 billion in 2007, a 127 percent increase in inflation-adjusted dollars. In the same period, adjusted spending on higher education increased only 21 percent.'b'In 2008, the explosion of the prison population ground to a near halt, according to 'b'data'b' released last  month by the Bureau of Justice Statistics. About 739,000 inmates were admitted to federal and state facilities, only about 3,500 more than were released.'b'One factor seems to be tight budgets as states decide to release nonviolent offenders early. This can not only save money. If done correctly, it can also be very sound social policy. Many nonviolent offenders can be dealt with more effectively and more cheaply through treatment and jobs programs.'b'Michigan, which has been hard hit by the recession, has done a particularly good job of releasing people who do not need to be in prison. As the American Civil Liberties Union\xe2\x80\x99s National Prison Project details in a 'b'new report'b', Michigan reduced its prison population by about 8 percent between March 2007 and November 2009 by taking smart steps, notably doing more to get nonviolent drug offenders out, while helping in their transition to a productive, and crime-free, life.'b'Not every state has gotten the message. Florida, for example,  has a state law mandating that all prisoners serve a high percentage of their sentence, which is both dubious corrections policy and terrible fiscal policy.'b'For many years, driving up prison populations has been an easy thing for elected officials to do, popular with voters and powerful corrections officer unions. The new incarceration figures suggest, however, that in the current hard economic times, strapped states are beginning to realize that they do not have the money to keep people in prison who do not need to be there.'b'The nation\xe2\x80\x99s hard times are proving to be boom times for the lobbying industry in Washington. Lobbyists are expected to easily break their  record of $3.3 billion in annual business, raising an inevitable question: How much more in special-interest donations will be bagged by lawmakers as they are furiously lobbied on everything from health care reform to economic regulation?'b'No one confesses to explicit quid pro quo crudity. But the power of lobbyists as they channel money and urge favor for rich clients is a gripping, and so far immutable, fact of political life. It needs to change.'b'To his credit, President Obama has delivered some promised reforms in the executive branch, particularly by banning administration officials from doubling back as lobbyists across his time in office. But the moneyed clout of K Street makes it urgent that Mr. Obama deliver on an even bigger promise. He must repair the damage done by his unfortunate rejection last year of publicly subsidized election financing as an alternative to the temptations of the special-interest trough.'b'Mr. Obama chose unlimited private financing to buoy his campaign to a huge electioneering advantage. He pronounced the leaner public subsidy option used by major candidates since Watergate to be a \xe2\x80\x9cbroken system\xe2\x80\x9d outdated by modern campaign costs.'b'Mr. Obama made much of a promise to fix it, once elected. So, the time has come to fix it.'b'He needs to set a strong example for Congress and the status quo laziness of Washington and move convincingly for revival of the public option, which served the nation well. This would create pressure for a similar system of restraint by Congressional candidates now basted with special-interest money. As the lucre builds to critical mass, a public option for Congressional and presidential candidates becomes ever more vital.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Hard Choice for a Comfortable Death: Drug-Induced Sleep'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cMonths to Live\xe2\x80\x9d series, front page, Dec. 27):'b'Bravo to The New York Times for its in-depth reporting on palliative sedation. When death is imminent, sedating a patient if nothing else can be done to ameliorate severe suffering is a legitimate medical intervention. Those who confuse palliative sedation with euthanasia \xe2\x80\x94 either out of ignorance or with intent to blur crucial distinctions for political reasons \xe2\x80\x94 do suffering patients a profound disservice.'b'Since any medical intervention can have unintended lethal side effects, we should no more consider palliative sedation euthanasia than when a patient dies during heart bypass surgery.'b'Indeed, it would be a terrible thing if patients in need refused or were denied this humane medical treatment because they or their physicians mistakenly confused it with mercy killing.'b'Wesley J. Smith'b'\n   Castro Valley, Calif., Dec.'b''b'27, 2009'b''b'The writer is the  author of \xe2\x80\x9cForced Exit: Euthanasia, Assisted Suicide and the New Duty to Die.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'From the perspective of a longtime hospice and palliative medicine practitioner, your article may raise unnecessary fears. First, most practitioners, patients and families arrive at palliative sedation without crossing a clear threshold or boundary. In almost all cases multiple other drug and nondrug treatments have already been brought to bear on the patient\xe2\x80\x99s suffering without relief.'b'Many of the drug treatments result in some degree of sedation, the acceptable level of which is determined jointly by patient and physician. At the point of so-called palliative sedation there is no alternative other than uncontrolled pain and distress.'b'Second, the article perpetuates the myth that death is hastened by pain relievers and sedatives in these circumstances. Sufficient research exists to contradict these concerns and suggests that far from hastening death, such interventions appear to have a neutral effect on survival and may actually prolong life while relieving suffering. How so? A patient with uncontrolled pain is under severe cardiovascular stress from the pain itself. A rapid heart rate, shallow breathing and agitation will themselves shorten life as death nears. Relief of the pain calms the heart and helps the patient breathe more effectively.'b'Politicians have done much to raise fear around care at the end of life; we mustn\xe2\x80\x99t add to it.'b'Steven Radwany'b'\n   Akron, Ohio, Dec.'b''b'29, 2009'b''b'The writer is medical director of palliative care and hospice services for Summa Health System.'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'I am concerned about your article\xe2\x80\x99s portrayal of palliative sedation. The purpose of palliative sedation is to alleviate symptoms that cannot otherwise be managed. Over the last 20 years, the knowledge about how to manage symptoms \xe2\x80\x94 including agitation like that of the patient profiled in your article, Leo Oltzik \xe2\x80\x94 has grown exponentially.'b'Too often, palliative sedation is used as a first-line therapy rather than a therapy of last resort. In some units, palliative sedation is used on one-third to one-half of patients. That is far too often. Most expert providers will use palliative sedation extremely rarely in a 20- to 25-year career.  Further, expert providers do not use palliative sedation lightly. They consult with colleagues to make sure that all other means of symptom management have been tried.'b'Finally, terminal sedation implies, as a colleague of mine says, \xe2\x80\x9ca one-way ticket.\xe2\x80\x9d Palliative sedation is usually done with the intent of allowing someone to be awakened after a day or so to see if the symptoms are alleviated.'b'Margaret M. Mahon'b'\n   Fairfax, Va., Dec.'b''b'28, 2009'b''b'The writer is a nurse and an associate professor at the School of Nursing of George Mason University. 'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'Your article about \xe2\x80\x9cdrug-induced sleep\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cterminal sedation\xe2\x80\x9d was especially timely for me.'b'My mother passed away peacefully on Dec. 10 in Nathan Adelson Hospice here in Las Vegas. She had fallen at home the week before and broken three ribs, lacerating her liver in the process. She was 94.'b'It became increasingly clear that she would not recover from the resulting complications. Our goal was to make her comfortable and free of pain, which thanks to her and the hospice we did.'b'The process you referred to as \xe2\x80\x9cterminal sedation,\xe2\x80\x9d though we had not heard that term before, was gently presented to us. And, in our case, kind doctors and nurses helped us every step of the way to our everlasting gratitude.'b'During this time, my sister and I faced tough decisions, but these were made at every turn with my mother\xe2\x80\x99s wishes having been clearly stated in writing. Both of our parents (our father died in 1994) had put in place written advance directives. So I was saddened to read in your article that many families facing these situations still do so without knowledge of the family member\xe2\x80\x99s desires.'b'At the end, my sister and I, while suffering profound grief, believed that we made the right choices and that our mother died  as she would have wanted.'b'Ginny Nagy'b'\n   Las Vegas, Dec.'b''b'27, 2009'b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'Your fine article on \xe2\x80\x9ca comfortable death\xe2\x80\x9d could leave the impression that there is some legal dispute about the practice of terminal sedation. There is not.'b'The article quotes a concurring opinion of Justice Sandra Day O\xe2\x80\x99Connor in the case of Washington v. Glucksberg (1997). But it would have been more useful to quote the majority opinion in the companion case, Vacco v. Quill, written by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, which dealt directly with the legality of terminal sedation in New York.'b'In the chief justice\xe2\x80\x99s words, \xe2\x80\x9cJust as a State may prohibit assisting suicide while permitting patients to refuse unwanted lifesaving treatment, it may permit palliative care related to that refusal, which may have the foreseen but unintended \xe2\x80\x98double effect\xe2\x80\x99 of hastening the patient\xe2\x80\x99s death.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'George J. Annas'b'\n   Boston, Dec.'b''b'29, 2009'b''b'The writer is chairman of the department of health law, bioethics and human rights at the Boston University School of Public Health.'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'Candid and thorough, your report on terminal sedation demonstrates the problem when the legal status of a medical procedure rests on whether a doctor\xe2\x80\x99s primary thought and intention is to treat suffering (legal) or ease dying (illegal).'b'The arcane theological doctrine of double effect creates a thought crime and ignores the patient\xe2\x80\x99s wishes altogether. Terminal sedation treats suffering and eases dying. We should learn to acknowledge and honor both effects.'b'Objective, discernible criteria, not an unknowable \xe2\x80\x9cintention,\xe2\x80\x9d should determine whether terminal sedation is ethical and legal in a given situation. Is death inevitable and imminent? Have all other treatments for end-of-life suffering been tried and failed?'b'And most important, has the patient requested or consented to terminal sedation, in the knowledge that death will ensue?'b'If the patient is delirious or otherwise incapable, the requesting or consenting process falls to surrogates, usually close family.'b'Any decision to forgo a few hours of life to escape suffering belongs to the patient. Doctors who usurp that decision flirt with a God complex, whether they explain their actions with double-effect theology or not.'b'Barbara Coombs Lee'b'\n   President'b'\n    Compassion and Choices'b'\n   Denver, Dec.'b''b''b''b'28, 2009'b'To the Editor:'b'\xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Decade We Had'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Op-Ed, Dec. 27) includes thoughtful retrospective articles by writers offering insightful observations about each of the last 10 years \xe2\x80\x94 except for Jonathan Safran Foer\xe2\x80\x99s cute, faux postmodern take on 2005, \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Nothing Ever Happens'b',\xe2\x80\x9d which relegates Hurricane Katrina and its aftermath to \xe2\x80\x9cand a mandatory evacuation was ordered in New Orleans.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I get Mr. Foer\xe2\x80\x99s shtick, his clever relativism, which gives equal or greater weight to such inanities as the cancellation of \xe2\x80\x9cStar Trek: Enterprise\xe2\x80\x9d as it does to events in the Middle East or the tragedies of New Orleans and the Gulf Coast. Yes, we live information-saturated lives; yes, determining what is significant poses epistemological quandaries. So?'b'Katrina was the most important domestic story of 2005, and the story of its aftermath is far from over. Not to acknowledge this, and to make a long joke instead, strikes me as poor judgment on Mr. Foer\xe2\x80\x99s part.'b'Brad Richard'b'\n New Orleans, Dec.\n27, 2009'b''b'To the Editor:'b'According to David Leonhardt (\xe2\x80\x9c'b'Last Call on Reforming Health Reform Bill'b',\xe2\x80\x9d Economic Scene, Dec. 23), \xe2\x80\x9cCadillac\xe2\x80\x9d plans are dispensable because people with such plans end up no healthier than those with \xe2\x80\x9cmerely good insurance.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'His analysis misses the point of the more generous benefits in the most comprehensive plans, which is not to provide better preventive care, but rather to cover the full range of medical necessities for people who face serious illness.'b'Coverage for benefits like private-duty nursing and medical supplies may seem like frills for a healthy population; they tend to get stripped out as plans degenerate from \xe2\x80\x9cCadillac\xe2\x80\x9d status. But they can be indispensable for the seriously ill, who may face medical bankruptcy trying to cover these costs on their own, despite their \xe2\x80\x9cgood\xe2\x80\x9d insurance. Isn\xe2\x80\x99t financial security in the face of catastrophic medical expenses one of the primary purposes of health insurance?'b'Mark Scherzer'b'\n Legislative Counsel, New Yorkers'b'\n  for Accessible Health Coverage'b'\n New York, Dec.\n 23, 2009'b''b''b''b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s what\xe2\x80\x99s coming in economic news: The next employment report could show the economy adding jobs for the first time in two years. The next G.D.P. report is likely to show solid growth in late 2009. There will be lots of bullish commentary \xe2\x80\x94 and the calls we\xe2\x80\x99re already hearing for an end to stimulus, for reversing the steps the government and the Federal Reserve took to prop up the economy, will grow even louder.'b'But if those calls are heeded, we\xe2\x80\x99ll be repeating the great mistake of 1937, when the Fed and the Roosevelt administration decided that the Great Depression was over, that it was time for the economy to throw away its crutches. Spending was cut back, monetary policy was tightened \xe2\x80\x94 and the economy promptly plunged back into the depths.'b'This shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be happening. Both Ben Bernanke, the Fed chairman, and Christina Romer, who heads President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s Council of Economic Advisers, are scholars of the Great Depression. Ms. Romer has warned explicitly against re-enacting the events of 1937. But those who remember the past sometimes repeat it anyway.'b'As you read the economic news, it will be important to remember, first of all, that blips \xe2\x80\x94 occasional good numbers, signifying nothing \xe2\x80\x94 are common even when the economy is, in fact, mired in a prolonged slump. In early 2002, for example, initial reports showed the economy growing at a 5.8 percent annual rate. But the unemployment rate kept rising for another year.'b'And in early 1996 preliminary reports showed the Japanese economy growing at an annual rate of more than 12 percent, leading to triumphant proclamations that \xe2\x80\x9cthe economy has finally entered a phase of self-propelled recovery.\xe2\x80\x9d In fact, Japan was only halfway through its lost decade.'b'Such blips are often, in part, statistical illusions. But even more important, they\xe2\x80\x99re usually caused by an \xe2\x80\x9cinventory bounce.\xe2\x80\x9d When the economy slumps, companies typically find themselves with large stocks of unsold goods. To work off their excess inventories, they slash production; once the excess has been disposed of, they raise production again, which shows up as a burst of growth in G.D.P. Unfortunately, growth caused by an inventory bounce is a one-shot affair unless underlying sources of demand, such as consumer spending and long-term investment, pick up.'b'Which brings us to the still grim fundamentals of the economic situation.'b'During the good years of the last decade, such as they were, growth was driven by a housing boom and a consumer spending surge. Neither is coming back. There can\xe2\x80\x99t be a new housing boom while the nation is still strewn with vacant houses and apartments left behind by the previous boom, and consumers \xe2\x80\x94 who are $11 trillion poorer than they were before the housing bust \xe2\x80\x94 are in no position to return to the buy-now-save-never habits of yore.'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s left? A boom in business investment would be really helpful right now. But it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to see where such a boom would come from: industry is awash in excess capacity, and commercial rents are plunging in the face of a huge oversupply of office space.'b'Can exports come to the rescue? For a while, a falling U.S. trade deficit helped cushion the economic slump. But the deficit is widening again, in part because China and other surplus countries are refusing to let their currencies adjust.'b'So the odds are that any good economic news you hear in the near future will be a blip, not an indication that we\xe2\x80\x99re on our way to sustained recovery. But will policy makers misinterpret the news and repeat the mistakes of 1937? Actually, they already are.'b'The Obama fiscal stimulus plan is expected to have its peak effect on G.D.P. and jobs around the middle of this year, then start fading out. That\xe2\x80\x99s far too early: why withdraw support in the face of continuing mass unemployment? Congress should have enacted a second round of stimulus months ago, when it became clear that the slump was going to be deeper and longer than originally expected. But nothing was done \xe2\x80\x94 and the illusory good numbers we\xe2\x80\x99re about to see will probably head off any further possibility of action.'b'Meanwhile, all the talk at the Fed is about the need for an \xe2\x80\x9cexit strategy\xe2\x80\x9d from its efforts to support the economy. One of those efforts, purchases of long-term U.S. government debt, has already come to an end. It\xe2\x80\x99s widely expected that another, purchases of mortgage-backed securities, will end in a few months. This amounts to a monetary tightening, even if the Fed doesn\xe2\x80\x99t raise interest rates directly \xe2\x80\x94 and there\xe2\x80\x99s a lot of pressure on Mr. Bernanke to do that too.'b'Will the Fed realize, before it\xe2\x80\x99s too late, that the job of fighting the slump isn\xe2\x80\x99t finished? Will Congress do the same? If they don\xe2\x80\x99t, 2010 will be a year that began in false economic hope and ended in grief.'b'Here in the United States, we spent New Year\xe2\x80\x99s weekend bidding good riddance to the awful, awful aughties \xe2\x80\x94 a miserable decade of bubbles and busts, rising health care bills and soaring deficits, domestic terror attacks and overseas quagmires.'b'Elsewhere, though, the decade\xe2\x80\x99s turn was probably flavored by nostalgia. For much of the world, the last 10 years was a period to savor \xe2\x80\x94 an era of impressive economic growth, ever-higher life expectancy, relative peace and steady progress against poverty.'b'A billion-odd Chinese had a pretty good decade, and so did a billion Indians: their economies just about doubled in size, minting new millionaires and lifting countless peasants into a growing middle class. Brazil boomed, Indonesia prospered, and even Africa enjoyed a season of substantial growth. Nobody would mistake Vladimir Putin\xe2\x80\x99s Russia for a liberal democratic paradise, but most Russians seem to prefer its stability to the basket-case republic Putin inherited from Boris Yeltsin.'b'Seen in this light, America\xe2\x80\x99s lost decade looks less like a big zero and more like an inevitable corrective to the high-flying 1990s. The enormous Clinton-era gulf between the United States and its competitors was bound to narrow eventually. For now, at least, our decline is only relative \xe2\x80\x94 from hyperpower back to superpower, from the only nation that mattered to the one that matters most.'b'But as the 2010s begin, there\xe2\x80\x99s reason to worry that America has further to fall. Our politics are polarized, our finances are still overleveraged, and our society is increasingly segregated  \xe2\x80\x94  by income, education and family structure \xe2\x80\x94 between a thriving elite and a struggling working class. Worse, neither political party seems capable of forging a new policy synthesis to reckon with our domestic challenges.'b'In the unhappy aughts, we witnessed the exhaustion of Reaganomics. A quarter-century after Ronald Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s mix of tax cuts and deregulation revived American competitiveness, George W. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s attempt to imitate the Gipper produced only wage stagnation and skyrocketing debt.'b'This failure helped cost Republicans their majority. But instead of seeking a new post-Reagan consensus, the Obama Democrats are returning to their party\xe2\x80\x99s long-running pursuit of European-style social democracy  \xe2\x80\x94  by micromanaging industry, pouring money into entitlement and welfare programs, and binding the economy in a web of new taxes and regulations.'b'These policies may help smooth over the inequalities that have opened in our national life since the 1970s. But they threaten to cost America its position in the world along the way.'b'Social democracy has its benefits, but global competitiveness isn\xe2\x80\x99t one of them. As Jim Manzi points out, in an essay on \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Keeping America\xe2\x80\x99s Edge'b'\xe2\x80\x9d  in the latest issue of National Affairs, \xe2\x80\x9cfrom 1980 through today, America\xe2\x80\x99s share of global output has been constant at about 21 percent. Europe\xe2\x80\x99s share, meanwhile, has been collapsing in the face of global competition \xe2\x80\x94 going from a little less than 40 percent of global production in the 1970s to about 25 percent today.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'If we hope to avoid a similar plunge, the Obama-era tilt toward government intervention needs to be balanced, and soon, by a new growth-oriented agenda. This will require more than the rote invocations of Reaganism that too many Republican politicians have fallen back on, however. The age of sweeping tax cuts financed by deficit spending is over. The policies of the 1980s will not keep America competitive in the 2010s. Our challenges are new, and we must think and act anew.'b'Manzi\xe2\x80\x99s National Affairs essay, a tour d\xe2\x80\x99horizon of our socioeconomic situation, provides a solid place to start. He proposes a fourfold agenda: Unwind the partnerships forged between Big Business and Big Government in the wake of the 2008 crash; seek financial regulations that \xe2\x80\x9ccontain busts,\xe2\x80\x9d by segregating high-risk transactions from lower-risk enterprises; deregulate the public school system, to let a thousand charter schools and start-ups bloom; and shift our immigration policy away from low-skilled immigration, and toward the recruitment of high-skilled  \xc3\xa9migr\xc3\xa9s from around the globe.'b'To this list, I would add tax reform and entitlement reform. The former should broaden the tax base while cutting taxes on work, childrearing and investment. The latter should means-test both Social Security and Medicare, reducing both programs\xe2\x80\x99 spending on well-off retirees rather than questing fruitlessly for their privatization.'b'This is a right-of-center agenda, broadly speaking, but it\xe2\x80\x99s also one that you could imagine attracting bipartisan support, even in the current polarized environment.'b'Which is as it should be \xe2\x80\x94 since in the quest to make the 2010s a far, far better era than the grueling decade America has just escaped, we\xe2\x80\x99re all in this together.'b'An earlier version of this column incorrectly identified the elected official from South Carolina who assaulted a senator with a cane in 1856. He was a member of the House of Representatives, not a fellow senator.'b'The United States opens this decade in a sour mood. First, Americans are anxious about the future. Sixty-one percent of Americans believe the country is in decline, according to the latest NBC News/Wall Street Journal survey. Only 27 percent feel confident that their children\xe2\x80\x99s generation will be better off than they are.'b'Second, Americans have lost faith in their institutions. During the great moments of social reform, at least 60 percent of Americans trusted government to do the right thing most of the time. Now, only a quarter have that kind of trust.'b'The country is evenly divided about President Obama, but state governments are in disrepute and confidence in Congress is at withering lows. As Frank Newport of the Gallup organization noted in his year-end wrap-up, \xe2\x80\x9cAmericans have less faith in their elected representatives than ever before.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Third, the new administration has not galvanized a popular majority. In almost every sphere of public opinion, Americans are moving away from the administration, not toward it. The Ipsos/McClatchy organizations have been asking voters which party can do the best job of handling a range of 13 different issues. During the first year of the Obama administration, the Republicans gained ground on all 13.'b'The public is not only shifting from left to right. Every single idea associated with the educated class has grown more unpopular over the past year.'b'The educated class believes in global warming, so public skepticism about global warming is on the rise. The educated class supports abortion rights, so public opinion is shifting against them. The educated class supports gun control, so opposition to gun control is mounting.'b'The story is the same in foreign affairs. The educated class is internationalist, so isolationist sentiment is now at an all-time high, according to a Pew Research Center survey. The educated class believes in multilateral action, so the number of Americans who believe we should \xe2\x80\x9cgo our own way\xe2\x80\x9d has risen sharply.'b'A year ago, the Obama supporters were the passionate ones. Now the tea party brigades have all the intensity.'b'The tea party movement is a large, fractious confederation of Americans who are defined by what they are against. They are against the concentrated power of the educated class. They believe big government, big business, big media and the affluent professionals are merging to form self-serving oligarchy \xe2\x80\x94 with bloated government, unsustainable deficits, high taxes and intrusive regulation.'b'The tea party movement is mostly famous for its flamboyant fringe. But it is now more popular than either major party. According to the NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll, 41 percent of Americans have a positive view of the tea party movement. Only 35 percent of Americans have a positive view of the Democrats and only 28 percent have a positive view of the Republican Party.'b'The movement is especially popular among independents. The Rasmussen organization asked independent voters whom they would support in a generic election between a Democrat, a Republican and a tea party candidate. The tea party candidate won, with 33 percent of independents. Undecided came in second with 30 percent. The Democrats came in third with 25 percent and the Republicans fourth with 12 percent.'b'Over the course of this year, the tea party movement will probably be transformed. Right now, it is an amateurish movement with mediocre leadership. But several bright and polished politicians, like Marco Rubio of Florida and Gary Johnson of New Mexico, are unofficially competing to become its de facto leader. If they succeed, their movement is likely to outgrow its crude beginnings and become a major force in American politics. After all, it represents arguments that are deeply rooted in American history.'b'The Obama administration is premised on the conviction that pragmatic federal leaders with professional expertise should have the power to implement programs to solve the country\xe2\x80\x99s problems. Many Americans do not have faith in that sort of centralized expertise or in the political class generally.'b'Moreover, the tea party movement has passion. Think back on the recent decades of American history \xe2\x80\x94 the way the hippies defined the 1960s; the feminists, the 1970s; the Christian conservatives, the 1980s. American history is often driven by passionate outsiders who force themselves into the center of American life.'b'In the near term, the tea party tendency will dominate the Republican Party. It could be the ruin of the party, pulling it in an angry direction that suburban voters will not tolerate. But don\xe2\x80\x99t underestimate the deep reservoirs of public disgust. If there is a double-dip recession, a long period of stagnation, a fiscal crisis, a terrorist attack or some other major scandal or event, the country could demand total change, creating a vacuum that only the tea party movement and its inheritors would be in a position to fill.'b'Personally, I\xe2\x80\x99m not a fan of this movement. But I can certainly see its potential to shape the coming decade.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m starting the new year with the sinking feeling that important opportunities are slipping from the nation\xe2\x80\x99s grasp. Our collective consciousness tends to obsess indiscriminately over one or two issues  \xe2\x80\x94  the would-be bomber on the flight into Detroit, the Tiger Woods saga  \xe2\x80\x94  while enormous problems that should be engaged get short shrift.'b'Staggering numbers of Americans are still unemployed and nearly a quarter of all homeowners owe more on their mortgages than their homes are worth. Forget the false hope of modestly improving monthly job numbers. The real story right now is the entrenched suffering (with no end in sight) that has been inflicted on scores of millions of working Americans by the Great Recession and the misguided economic policies that preceded it.'b'As The Washington Post reported over the weekend, the entire past decade \xe2\x80\x9cwas the worst for the U.S. economy in modern times.\xe2\x80\x9d There was no net job creation  \xe2\x80\x94  none  \xe2\x80\x94  between December 1999 and now. None!'b''b'The Post article'b' read like a lament, a longing for the U.S. as we\xe2\x80\x99d once known it: \xe2\x80\x9cNo previous decade going back to the 1940s had job growth of less than 20 percent.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Middle-class families in 2008 actually earned less, adjusted for inflation, than they did in 1999. The data for 2009 are not yet in, but you can just imagine what happened to those families in that nightmarish downturn. Small children over the holidays were asking Santa Claus to bring mommy or daddy a job.'b'One in eight Americans, and one in four children, are on food stamps. Some six million Americans, 'b'according to an article in The Times'b' on Sunday, have said that food stamps were their only income.'b'This is a society in deep, deep trouble and the fixes currently in the works are in no way adequate to the enormous challenges we\xe2\x80\x99re facing. For example, an end to the mantra of monthly job losses would undoubtedly be welcomed. But even if the economy manages to create a few hundred thousand new jobs a month, it would do little to haul us from the unemployment pit dug for us by the Great Recession. We need to create more than 10 million new jobs just to get us back to where we were when the recession began in December 2007.'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s needed are big new innovative efforts to fashion an economy that creates jobs for all who want and need to work. Just getting us back in fits and starts over the next few years to where we were when the recession began should not be acceptable to anyone. We should be moving now to invest aggressively in a new, greener economy, leading the world in the development of alternative fuels, advanced transportation networks and the effort to restrain the poisoning of the planet. We should be developing an industrial policy that emphasizes the need for America to regain its manufacturing mojo, as tough as that might seem, and we need to rebuild our infrastructure.'b'We\xe2\x80\x99re not smart as a nation. We don\xe2\x80\x99t learn from the past, and we don\xe2\x80\x99t plan for the future. We\xe2\x80\x99ve spent a year turning ourselves inside out with arguments of every sort over health care reform only to come up with a bloated, Rube Goldberg legislative mess that protects the insurance and drug industries and does not rein in runaway health care costs.'b'The politicians will be back soon, trust me, screaming about the need to rein in health costs.'b'We keep talking about how essential it is to radically improve public education while, at the same time, we\xe2\x80\x99re closing libraries and firing teachers by the tens of thousands for economic reasons.'b'The fault lies everywhere. The president, the Congress, the news media and the public are all to blame. Shared sacrifice is not part of anyone\xe2\x80\x99s program. Politicians can\xe2\x80\x99t seem to tell the difference between wasteful spending and investments in a more sustainable future. Any talk of raising taxes is considered blasphemous, but there is a constant din of empty yapping about controlling budget deficits.'b'Oh, yes, and we\xe2\x80\x99re fighting two wars.'b'If America can\xe2\x80\x99t change, then the current state of decline is bound to continue. You can\xe2\x80\x99t have a healthy economy with so many millions of people out of work, and there is no plan now that would result in the creation of millions of new jobs any time soon.'b'Voters were primed at the beginning of the Obama administration for fundamental changes that would have altered the trajectory of American life for the better. Politicians of all stripes, many of them catering to the nation\xe2\x80\x99s moneyed interests, fouled that up to a fare-thee-well.'b'Now we\xe2\x80\x99re escalating in Afghanistan, falling back into panic mode over an attempted act of terror and squandering a golden opportunity to build a better society.'b'The financial crisis and Great Recession have their roots in the housing bust. When it comes, a lasting recovery will be evident in a housing rebound. Unfortunately, housing appears to be weakening anew.'b'Figures released last week show that after four months of gains, home prices flattened in October. At that time, low mortgage rates (courtesy of the Federal Reserve) and a home buyer\xe2\x80\x99s tax credit (courtesy of Congress) were fueling sales. That should have propped up prices. But it was not enough to overcome the drag created by a glut of 3.2 million new and existing unsold single-family homes \xe2\x80\x94 about a seven-month supply.'b'The situation, we fear, will only get worse in months to come. Rates already are starting to rise as lenders brace for the Fed to curtail support for mortgage lending as early as the end of March. The home buyer\xe2\x80\x99s tax credit is scheduled to expire at the end of April. And a new flood of foreclosed homes is ready to hit the market.'b'It is increasingly clear that the Obama administration\xe2\x80\x99s anti-foreclosure effort \xe2\x80\x94 which pressed lenders to reduce interest rates \xe2\x80\x94 isn\xe2\x80\x99t doing nearly enough. High unemployment rates also mean that many borrowers who did qualify for aid have been unable to keep up with even reduced monthly payments.'b'As a result, an estimated 2.4 million foreclosed homes will be added to the existing glut in 2010, driving prices down by another 10 percent or so. That would bring the average decline nationwide to about 40 percent since the peak of the market in 2006.'b'A renewed price drop could usher in a new grim chapter in the foreclosure crisis. Already an estimated one-third of homeowners with a mortgage \xe2\x80\x94 nearly 16 million people \xe2\x80\x94 owe more than their homes are worth; in industry parlance, they are \xe2\x80\x9cunderwater.\xe2\x80\x9d If prices drop further, ever more borrowers will sink ever deeper. Research suggests that the greater the loss of home equity, the greater the likelihood that borrowers will decide to turn in the keys and find a cheaper place to rent.'b'Things didn\xe2\x80\x99t have to get this bad.'b'The best way to modify an underwater loan is to reduce the principal balance, lowering the monthly payment and restoring equity. But for the most part, lenders have refused to reduce principal because it would force them to take an immediate loss on the loan. Lenders also have vehemently \xe2\x80\x94 and successfully \xe2\x80\x94 resisted Congressional efforts to change the law so that bankruptcy courts could reduce the mortgage balances for bankrupt borrowers.'b'The administration decided not to press lenders to grant principal reductions in the flawed belief that simply making payments more affordable would be enough to forestall foreclosures. It hasn\xe2\x80\x99t. The administration also didn\xe2\x80\x99t fight for the bankruptcy fix when it was before Congress last year despite President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s campaign promise to do so.'b'The economy is hard pressed to function, let alone thrive, when house prices are falling. As home equity erodes, consumer spending falls and foreclosures increase. Lenders lose the ability and willingness to extend credit and employers are disinclined to hire. True economic recovery is all but impossible.'b'To avert the worst, the White House should alter its loan-modification effort to emphasize principal reduction. It ruled last week that a police officer can be held liable for delivering a high-level electric shock to an unarmed person who poses no immediate threat.'b'Carl Bryan, 21, was driving to his parents\xe2\x80\x99 home in Southern California when he was stopped for speeding. On the same trip, he was pulled over for not wearing a seat belt. Angry at facing a second traffic citation, he hit the steering wheel and yelled expletives to himself. He then stepped out of the car. There is some disagreement over what happened next \xe2\x80\x94 the officer said Mr. Bryan took \xe2\x80\x9cone step\xe2\x80\x9d toward him, while Mr. Bryan said he did not take any. It is undisputed that Mr. Bryan, who was not armed, did not verbally threaten the officer and was not attempting to flee.'b'Without warning, the officer shot Mr. Bryan with a Taser, which uses compressed nitrogen to propel \xe2\x80\x9cprobes\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 aluminum darts connected to wires that deliver a very painful, 1,200-volt electric charge into the target\xe2\x80\x99s muscles. As the current immobilized him, Mr. Bryan fell to the ground, fracturing four teeth. A doctor had to remove one of the probes with a scalpel.'b'Mr. Bryan sued for assault and battery and intentional infliction of emotional distress. The officer tried to get the suit dismissed on summary judgment, but the trial court ruled that it could go forward. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, based in San Francisco, affirmed that decision by a 3-to-0 vote.'b'The appeals court ruled that the officer was not justified in using the Taser. The evidence showed, the court said, that Mr. Bryan did not pose an immediate threat. It was also relevant that the \xe2\x80\x9ccrime\xe2\x80\x9d he was accused of was a mere traffic violation. Given these facts, the amount of force used was unreasonable.'b'Although the Ninth Circuit\xe2\x80\x99s decision is only binding on a group of Western states and territories, all of the more than 17,000 law enforcement agencies across the country that use Tasers should follow its guidance. Second, recognize that the national border is a \xe2\x80\x9cbright line,\xe2\x80\x9d and if people captured within the United States are going to be treated as if they were somewhere else \xe2\x80\x94 provided that they are certified terrorists \xe2\x80\x94 things are going to  get complicated quickly.'b'What about Maj. First, the commission was told, the no-fly list had not 61,000 names but only 12, and included none of the 9/11 hijackers, even though  the F.B.I. was searching actively for two of them before the attack.'b'Then came the bombshell: the F.A.A. security officials were unaware  \xe2\x80\x94 until the commission asked its question at a hearing \xe2\x80\x94 that the State Department  maintained a terrorist watch list at all.'b'In the hearing, Tim Roemer, a commission member, was stunned, 'b'telling the F.A.A. officials'b': \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a difference of 60,988 names between what\xe2\x80\x99s been accumulated at the State Department as dangerous people, shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be flying, and what you have with your 12 people. Now, I can\xe2\x80\x99t understand why there are not more efforts in liaison activities to reach out to State Department and start to bring some of those names over and prevent those people from flying.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Today, the no-fly list has grown to 4,000 people, but the name of the man accused of the Christmas bombing attempt, Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab,  was not on it. Critical information concerning Mr.  Abdulmutallab\xe2\x80\x99s growing estrangement from his family and his Islamic radicalization in Yemen, 'b'according to an understandably exasperated President Obama'b', \xe2\x80\x9cwas passed to a component of our intelligence community but was not effectively distributed so as to get the suspect\xe2\x80\x99s name on a no-fly list.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Others in the intelligence community, according to Mr. Brennan, were aware that Al Qaeda in Yemen was training a Nigerian, perhaps named Umar Farouk, to carry out an attack. \xe2\x80\x9cBut there was nothing,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'according to Mr. Brennan,'b' \xe2\x80\x9cthat brought it all together.\xe2\x80\x9d When Mr. Abdulmutallab\xe2\x80\x99s father reported his dangerous behavior to the United States Embassy in Nigeria, moreover, no one checked whether the younger Abdulmutallab  held a multiple-entry visa (he did), or whether he had been denied a visa anywhere else (he had).'b'As President Obama said yesterday, after meeting with his national security team at the White House, \xe2\x80\x9cThis was not a failure to collect intelligence; it was a failure to integrate and understand the intelligence we already had.\xe2\x80\x9d What, more than eight years after 9/11, and more than four years after the issuance of the 9/11 commission\xe2\x80\x99s findings, are we to make of this systemic failure? And what should be done about it?'b'First, we should dismiss the partisan bickering over the issue. Both parties have presided over security failures and successes; systemic failures cannot be ascribed to the stewardship of a political party. Any effort to take partisan advantage of this unfortunate event, moreover, can only mask the more serious underlying issues, which President Obama raised squarely in yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s remarks: are lapses in information gathering and sharing like those that occurred here endemic, or fixable?'b'The task of isolating the data points that identify one dangerous individual among thousands is hard; there will be, under the best of conditions, an element of judgment involved, an ineradicable quantum of human frailty. Tragic mistakes will always be possible. And there will be little or no defense against a lunatic, unconnected with any group, who ignites kindling in his underpants.'b'The question that Congress should investigate, and the administration should ask itself, is whether the system we have in place has reduced the likelihood of human error to an acceptable, if not irreducible, margin.'b'Our national security system should aspire to the zero-tolerance effectiveness with which our military has prevented an accidental launching of nuclear weapons. The attempted Christmas bombing, thwarted by brave passengers and not by our intelligence community, illustrates how far we still have to go.'b'There are procedural fixes worth undertaking, of course, like mandating enhanced screening, or installing body scanning technology, or coordinating the software used by intelligence agencies, or instructing State Department personnel to query the visa status of any person reported to be suspicious. Reforming the no-fly list procedures, as President Obama has proposed, is certainly overdue. But in our view the problem runs deeper, and requires a searching look at the structure of government itself.'b'Despite the best efforts of the 9/11 commission and other intelligence reformers, budgetary authority over intelligence remains unaligned with substantive responsibility. Turf battles persist among intelligence agencies. Power is sought while responsibility is deflected. The drift toward inertia continues.'b'Government agencies are most likely to succeed when structure matches mission. With its many jurisdictional boundaries and its persistent bureaucratic fault lines, our current system, although greatly improved since 9/11, affords too many opportunities to let information slip, too many occasions for human frailty to assert itself.'b'The attempted Christmas bombing carries an eerie echo of the failures that led to 9/11 because those fundamental flaws persist. The challenge for President Obama and Congress is to resist superficial sound-bite solutions and undertake the harder task of reinventing our national security system. As the president stated, \xe2\x80\x9cThe margin for error is slim, and the consequences of failure can be catastrophic.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'THE Islamic Republic of Iran is not about to implode. Nevertheless, the misguided idea that it may do so is becoming enshrined as conventional wisdom in Washington.'b'For President Obama, this misconception provides a bit of cover; it helps obscure his failure to follow up on his campaign promises about engaging Iran with any serious, strategically grounded proposals. Meanwhile, those who have never supported diplomatic engagement with Iran are now pushing the idea that the Tehran government might collapse to support their arguments for military strikes against Iranian nuclear targets and adopting \xe2\x80\x9cregime change\xe2\x80\x9d as the ultimate goal of America\xe2\x80\x99s Iran policy.'b'Let\xe2\x80\x99s start with the most recent events. On Dec. 27, large crowds poured into the streets of cities across Iran to commemorate the Shiite holy day of Ashura; this coincided with mourning observances for a revered cleric, Grand Ayatollah Hossein Ali Montazeri, who had died a week earlier. Protesters used the occasion to gather in Tehran and elsewhere, setting off clashes with security forces.'b'Important events, no doubt. But assertions that the Islamic Republic is now imploding in the fashion of the shah\xe2\x80\x99s regime in 1979 do not hold up to even the most minimal scrutiny. Antigovernment Iranian Web sites claim there were \xe2\x80\x9ctens of thousands\xe2\x80\x9d of Ashura protesters; others in Iran say there were 2,000 to 4,000. Whichever estimate is more accurate, one thing we do know is that much of Iranian society was upset by the protesters using a sacred day to make a political statement.'b'Vastly more Iranians took to the streets on Dec. 30, in demonstrations organized by the government to show support for the Islamic Republic (one Web site that opposed President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad\xe2\x80\x99s re-election in June estimated the crowds at one million people). Photographs and video clips lend considerable plausibility to this estimate \xe2\x80\x94 meaning this was possibly the largest crowd in the streets of Tehran since Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini\xe2\x80\x99s funeral in 1989. In its wake, even President Ahmadinejad\xe2\x80\x99s principal challenger in last June\xe2\x80\x99s presidential election, Mir Hossein Mousavi, felt compelled to acknowledge the \xe2\x80\x9cunacceptable radicalism\xe2\x80\x9d of some Ashura protesters.'b'The focus in the West on the antigovernment demonstrations has blinded many to an inconvenient but inescapable truth: the Iranians who used Ashura to make a political protest do not represent anything close to a majority. Those who talk so confidently about an \xe2\x80\x9copposition\xe2\x80\x9d in Iran as the vanguard for a new revolution should be made to answer three tough questions: First, what does this opposition want? Second, who leads it? Third, through what process will this opposition displace the government in Tehran?'b'In the case of the 1979 revolutionaries, the answers to these questions were clear. They wanted to oust the American-backed regime of Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi and to replace it with an Islamic republic. Everyone knew who led the revolution: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who despite living in exile in Paris could mobilize huge crowds in Iran simply by sending cassette tapes into the country. While supporters disagreed about the revolution\xe2\x80\x99s long-term agenda, Khomeini\xe2\x80\x99s ideas were well known from his writings and public statements. After the shah\xe2\x80\x99s departure, Khomeini returned to Iran with a draft constitution for the new political order in hand. As a result, the basic structure of the Islamic Republic was set up remarkably quickly.'b'Beyond expressing inchoate discontent, what does the current \xe2\x80\x9copposition\xe2\x80\x9d want? It is no longer championing Mr. Mousavi\xe2\x80\x99s presidential candidacy; Mr. Mousavi himself has now redefined his agenda as \xe2\x80\x9cnational reconciliation.\xe2\x80\x9d Some protesters seem to want expanded personal freedoms and interaction with the rest of the world, but have no comprehensive agenda. Others \xe2\x80\x94 who have received considerable Western press coverage \xe2\x80\x94 have taken to calling for the Islamic Republic\xe2\x80\x99s replacement with an (ostensibly secular) \xe2\x80\x9cIranian Republic.\xe2\x80\x9d But University of Maryland polling   after the election and popular reaction to the Ashura protests suggest that most Iranians are unmoved, if not repelled, by calls for the Islamic Republic\xe2\x80\x99s abolition.'b'With Mr. Mousavi increasingly marginalized, who else might lead this supposed revolution? Surely not Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, the former president who became a leading figure in the protests after last summer\xe2\x80\x99s election. Yes, he is an accomplished political actor, is considered a \xe2\x80\x9cfounding father\xe2\x80\x9d of the state and heads the Assembly of Experts, a body that can replace the Islamic Republic\xe2\x80\x99s supreme leader. But Mr. Rafsanjani lost his 2005 bid to regain the presidency in a landslide to Mr. Ahmadinejad, and has shown no inclination to spur the masses to bring down the system he helped create.'b'Nor will Mohammad Khatami, the reformist elected president in 1997, lead the charge; in 1999, at the height of his popularity, he publicly disowned widespread student demonstrations protesting the closing of a newspaper that had supported his administration.'b'Many of the Westerners who see the opposition displacing the Islamic Republic emphasize the potential for unrest during Shiite mourning rituals, which take place at three-, seven- and 40-day intervals after a person\xe2\x80\x99s death. During the final months of the shah\xe2\x80\x99s rule, his opponents used mourning rituals held for demonstrators killed by security forces to catalyze further protests. But does this mean that a steady stream of mourning rituals for fallen protesters today will set off a similarly escalating spiral of protests, eventually sweeping away Iran\xe2\x80\x99s political order?'b'That is highly unlikely. First, Ayatollah Montazeri had unique standing in the Islamic Republic\xe2\x80\x99s history; it is not surprising that the coincidence of his seven-day observance with the Ashura observation would have drawn crowds. His 40-day observance \xe2\x80\x94 which will fall on Jan. 29 \xe2\x80\x94 and the early February commemoration of the 1979 revolution might also encourage public activism. But there is nothing in the Islamic Republic\xe2\x80\x99s history to support projections that future mourning rituals for those killed in the Ashura protests will elicit similar attention.'b'For example, in late 1998 four prominent intellectuals were assassinated, allegedly by state intelligence officers, prompting considerable public outrage. Yet the mourning rituals for the victims did not prompt large-scale protests. In 1999, nationwide student protests were violently suppressed, with at least five people killed and 1,200 detained. Once again, though, the mourning dates for those who died did not generate significant new demonstrations. Likewise, after the presidential election in June, none of the deaths associated with security force action \xe2\x80\x94 even that of Neda Agha-Soltan, the young woman whose murder became a cause c\xc3\xa9l\xc3\xa8bre of the YouTube age \xe2\x80\x94 resulted in further unrest.'b'In keeping with this pattern, the seven-day mourning observances for those killed in the Ashura protests generated no significant demonstrations in Iran. Clearly, comparisons of the Ashura protests to the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989, projecting a cascade of monumental consequences to follow, are fanciful. The Islamic Republic will continue to be Iran\xe2\x80\x99s government. And, even if there were changes in some top leadership positions \xe2\x80\x94 such as the replacement of Mr. Ahmadinejad as president by Ali Larijani, the speaker of the Parliament, as some Westerners speculate \xe2\x80\x94 this would not fundamentally change Iran\xe2\x80\x99s approach on regional politics, its nuclear program and other matters of concern.'b'The Obama administration\xe2\x80\x99s half-hearted efforts at diplomacy with Tehran have given engagement a bad name. As a result, support for more coercive options is building across the American political spectrum. The president will do a real disservice to American interests if he waits in vain for Iranian political dynamics to \xe2\x80\x9csolve\xe2\x80\x9d the problems with his Iran policy.'b'As a model, the president would do well to look to China. Since President Richard Nixon\xe2\x80\x99s opening there (which took place amid the Cultural Revolution), successive American administrations have been wise enough not to let political conflict \xe2\x80\x94 whether among the ruling elite or between the state and the public, as in the Tiananmen Square protests and ethnic separatism in Xinjiang \xe2\x80\x94 divert Washington from sustained, strategic engagement with Beijing. President Obama needs to begin displaying similar statesmanship in his approach to Iran.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Why Twitter Will Endure'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Week in Review, Jan. 3):'b'As a 71-year-old grandmother of 10, I have eschewed Facebook, declined a BlackBerry (who wants to be contacted \xe2\x80\x9cinstantly\xe2\x80\x9d?) and barely given Twitter a thought ... until today. That would mean limiting contributions to $1,000 instead of $55,900 for state races. Lobbyists would be allowed to pitch in only $250. He would end the scandalous practice of writing checks for party \xe2\x80\x9chousekeeping\xe2\x80\x9d that have no limits at all.'b'\xc2\xb6He wants to ban all contributions from corporations, including limited liability corporations, one of the latest tricks for adding big bucks to campaigns.
