But that\xe2\x80\x99s a complaint for another day.'b'SAN JOS\xc3\x89, Costa Rica'b'Hmmm. You think it\xe2\x80\x99s a coincidence? Costa Rica is one of the very few countries to have abolished its army, and it\xe2\x80\x99s also arguably the happiest nation on earth.'b'There are several ways of measuring happiness in countries, all inexact, but this pearl of Central America does stunningly well by whatever system is used. For example, the 'b'World Database of Happiness'b', compiled by a Dutch sociologist on the basis of answers to surveys by Gallup and others, lists Costa Rica in the top spot out of 148 nations.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s because Costa Ricans, asked to rate their own happiness on a 10-point scale, average 8.5. Denmark is next at 8.3, the United States ranks 20th at 7.4 and Togo and Tanzania bring up the caboose at 2.6.'b'Scholars also calculate happiness by determining \xe2\x80\x9chappy life years.\xe2\x80\x9d This figure results from merging average self-reported happiness, as above, with life expectancy. Using this system, Costa Rica again easily tops the list. The United States is 19th, and Zimbabwe comes in last.'b'A third approach is the \xe2\x80\x9c'b'happy planet index'b',\xe2\x80\x9d devised by the New Economics Foundation, a liberal think tank. This combines happiness and longevity but adjusts for environmental impact  \xe2\x80\x94  such as the carbon that countries spew.'b'Here again, Costa Rica wins the day, for achieving contentment and longevity in an environmentally sustainable way. The Dominican Republic ranks second, the United States 114th (because of its huge ecological footprint) and Zimbabwe is last.'b'Maybe Costa Rican contentment has something to do with the chance to explore dazzling beaches on both sides of the country, when one isn\xe2\x80\x99t admiring the sloths in the jungle (sloths truly are slothful, I discovered; they are the tortoises of the trees). Costa Rica has done an unusually good job preserving nature, and it\xe2\x80\x99s surely easier to be happy while basking in sunshine and greenery than while shivering up north and suffering \xe2\x80\x9cnature deficit disorder.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'After dragging my 12-year-old daughter through Honduran slums and Nicaraguan villages on this trip, she was delighted to see a Costa Rican beach and stroll through a national park. Among her favorite animals now: iguanas and sloths.'b'(Note to boss: Maybe we should have a columnist based in Costa Rica?)'b'What sets Costa Rica apart is its remarkable decision in 1949 to dissolve its armed forces and invest instead in education. Increased schooling created a more stable society, less prone to the conflicts that have raged elsewhere in Central America. Education also boosted the economy, enabling the country to become a major exporter of computer chips and improving English-language skills so as to attract American eco-tourists.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99m not antimilitary. But the evidence is strong that education is often a far better investment than artillery.'b'In Costa Rica, rising education levels also fostered impressive gender equality so that it ranks higher than the United States in the World Economic Forum 'b'gender gap index'b'. This allows Costa Rica to use its female population more productively than is true in most of the region. Likewise, education nurtured improvements in health care, with life expectancy now about the same as in the United States  \xe2\x80\x94  a bit longer in some data sets, a bit shorter in others.'b'Rising education levels also led the country to preserve its lush environment as an economic asset. Costa Rica is an ecological pioneer, introducing a carbon tax in 1997. The 'b'Environmental Performance Index'b', a collaboration of Yale and Columbia Universities, ranks Costa Rica at No. 5 in the world, the best outside Europe.'b'This emphasis on the environment hasn\xe2\x80\x99t sabotaged Costa Rica\xe2\x80\x99s economy but has bolstered it. Indeed, Costa Rica is one of the few countries that is seeing migration from the United States: Yankees are moving here to enjoy a low-cost retirement. My hunch is that in 25 years, we\xe2\x80\x99ll see large numbers of English-speaking retirement communities along the Costa Rican coast.'b'Latin countries generally do well in happiness surveys. Mexico and Colombia rank higher than the United States in self-reported contentment. Perhaps one reason is a cultural emphasis on family and friends, on social capital over financial capital  \xe2\x80\x94  but then again, Mexicans sometimes slip into the United States, presumably in pursuit of both happiness and assets.'b'Cross-country comparisons of happiness are controversial and uncertain. But what does seem quite clear is that Costa Rica\xe2\x80\x99s national decision to invest in education rather than arms has paid rich dividends. Maybe the lesson for the United States is that we should devote fewer resources to shoring up foreign armies and more to bolstering schools both at home and abroad.'b'In the meantime, I encourage you to conduct your own research in Costa Rica, exploring those magnificent beaches or admiring those slothful sloths. It\xe2\x80\x99ll surely make you happy.'b'Cambridge, Mass.'b'SEEN from Tokyo, America\xe2\x80\x99s relationship with Japan faces a crisis. The immediate problem is deadlock over a plan to move  an American military base on the island of Okinawa. It sounds simple, but this is an issue with a long back story that could create a serious rift with one of our most crucial allies.'b'When I was in the Pentagon more than a decade ago, we began planning to reduce the burden that  our presence places on Okinawa, which houses more than half of the 47,000  American troops in Japan. The Marine Corps Air Station Futenma was a particular problem because of its proximity to a crowded city, Ginowan. After years of negotiation, the Japanese and American governments agreed in 2006 to move the base to a less populated part of Okinawa and to move 8,000 Marines from Okinawa to Guam by 2014.'b'The plan was thrown into jeopardy last summer when the Japanese  voted out the Liberal Democratic Party that had governed the country  for nearly half a century in favor of the Democratic Party of Japan. The new prime minister, Yukio Hatoyama, leads a government that is inexperienced, divided and still in the thrall of campaign promises to move the base off the island or out of Japan completely.'b'The Pentagon is properly annoyed that Mr. Hatoyama is trying to go back on an agreement that took more than a decade to work out and that has major implications for the Marine Corps\xe2\x80\x99 budget and force realignment. Secretary of Defense Robert Gates expressed displeasure during a trip to Japan in October, calling any reassessment of the plan \xe2\x80\x9ccounterproductive.\xe2\x80\x9d When he visited Tokyo in November, President Obama agreed to a high-level working group to consider the Futenma question. But since then, Mr. Hatoyama has said he will delay a final decision on relocation until at least May.'b'Not surprisingly, some in Washington want to play hardball with the new Japanese government. But that would be unwise, for Mr. Hatoyama is caught in a vise, with the Americans squeezing from one side and a small left-wing party (upon which his majority in the upper house of the legislature depends) threatening to quit the coalition if he makes any significant concessions to the Americans. Further complicating matters, the future of Futenma is deeply contentious for Okinawans.'b'Even if Mr. Hatoyama eventually gives in on the base plan, we need a more patient and strategic approach to Japan. We are allowing a second-order issue to threaten our long-term strategy for East Asia. Futenma, it is worth noting, is not the only matter that the new government has raised. It also speaks of wanting a more equal alliance and better relations with China, and of creating an East Asian community \xe2\x80\x94 though it is far from clear what any of this means.'b'When I helped to develop the Pentagon\xe2\x80\x99s East Asian Strategy Report in 1995,  we started with the reality that there were three major powers in the region \xe2\x80\x94 the United States, Japan and China \xe2\x80\x94 and that maintaining our alliance with Japan would shape the  environment into which China was emerging. We wanted to integrate China into the international system by, say, inviting it to join the World Trade Organization, but we needed to hedge against the danger that a future and stronger China might turn aggressive.'b'After a year and a half of extensive negotiations, the United States and Japan agreed that our alliance, rather than representing a cold war relic, was the basis for stability and prosperity in the region. President Bill Clinton and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto affirmed that in their 'b'1996 Tokyo declaration'b'.  This strategy of \xe2\x80\x9cintegrate, but hedge\xe2\x80\x9d continued to guide American foreign policy through the years of the Bush administration.'b'This year is the 50th anniversary of the 'b'United States-Japan security treaty.'b'  The two countries will miss a major opportunity if they let the base controversy lead to bitter feelings or the further reduction of American forces in Japan. The best guarantee of security in a region where China remains a long-term challenge and a nuclear North Korea poses a clear threat  remains the presence of American troops, which Japan helps to maintain with generous host nation support.'b'Sometimes Japanese officials quietly welcome \xe2\x80\x9cgaiatsu,\xe2\x80\x9d or foreign pressure, to help resolve their own bureaucratic deadlocks. But that is not the case here: if the United States undercuts the new Japanese government  and creates resentment among the Japanese public, then a victory on Futenma could prove Pyrrhic.'b'Washington'b'ON Wednesday, Senator Chris Dodd announced his retirement after 30 years in the Senate. As a Senate Democratic staffer in 1980, I remember Mr. Dodd\xe2\x80\x99s election well \xe2\x80\x94 it was the only bright spot on the night that changed the Senate drastically, and in ways we still feel today.'b'In the 1960s and \xe2\x80\x9970s, a great Senate had occupied a unique place in our country. It was the Senate that broke the Southern filibuster to enact the Civil Rights Act of 1964; became the arena for challenging, and ultimately ending, the Vietnam War; called Richard Nixon to account; spearheaded new environmental and consumer protections; and advanced equal treatment for women. In an era marked by war, assassinations and political scandal, the Senate provided continuity, gravitas and leadership.'b'The Senate\xe2\x80\x99s fall was as swift as it was surprising. In 1977, the Senate greeted a new president, Jimmy Carter, with a new leadership team of its own, Robert Byrd as majority leader and Howard Baker as minority leader.  Several iconic members \xe2\x80\x94 Sam Ervin, J. William Fulbright, Mike Mansfield, Philip Hart \xe2\x80\x94 were gone. But the core of the great Senate, the liberal Democrats elected in 1958 and 1962, and the moderate-to-progressive Republicans who had forged so many bipartisan alliances, was still intact.'b'The Russell and Dirksen Senate Office Buildings were filled with young, talented, ambitious staff members like Madeleine Albright, Tim Russert, Susan Collins and Tom Daschle. And after battling the imperial presidencies of Lyndon Johnson and Richard Nixon, the Senate was armed with new legislative tools, including the War Powers Act, the Budget Control Act and the Freedom of Information Act.'b'There was every reason to think that the Senate would continue with a solid Democratic majority, operate in a bipartisan fashion, and have a powerful, positive influence in the country. But the assertive Senate Democrats and the new, outsider president clashed from the start. Republicans formed strong alliances with an energized business community and surging social conservatives. Jesse Helms, finishing his first term, and Orrin Hatch, newly elected, mastered and exploited the Senate rules; liberal senators retaliated in kind. The filibuster, previously a weapon of last resort, became increasingly commonplace.'b'Still, thanks to statesmanship and bipartisan traditions, the 95th Congress compiled a respectable record, including passage of a far-ranging energy program, the Civil Service Reform Act and financial relief for New York City.'b'America\xe2\x80\x99s politics, however, had already started moving to the right, spurred by anger over the Panama Canal treaty and a tax revolt that started in California and swept across the country. In the 1978 election, conservatives helped oust several Democratic senators and purged Republican liberals: defeating Clifford Case in a primary; standing by while Ed Brooke, the only African-American senator, lost; and causing Charles Percy, who won re-election only after pledging that he had \xe2\x80\x9cgotten the message,\xe2\x80\x9d to turn hard to the right.'b'Nixon\xe2\x80\x99s 49-state sweep in 1972 had not diminished the Democratic majority. But by 1980, with America facing an economy in tailspin and the hostage crisis in Iran, the conservative tide was running too strong, and the veteran liberal senators had plainly lost a step.'b'Frank Church, who had overseen the Senate investigation into intelligence abuses, turned hawkish in a desperate effort to revive his sagging political fortunes. George McGovern, who had provided singular leadership in opposing the Vietnam War and fighting hunger, slumped badly in his re-election bid. Jacob Javits, the most liberal Republican and perhaps the greatest legislator of his era, unwisely sought one more term despite failing health.'b'Before joining Thomas Eagleton\xe2\x80\x99s staff, I had worked for Gaylord Nelson, the great Wisconsin environmentalist who was now campaigning unconvincingly as a champion of small business. One afternoon, I found Eagleton scribbling furiously on a pad, talking on the phone, smoking constantly.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve got to help Gaylord,\xe2\x80\x9d Eagleton boomed. \xe2\x80\x9cHe just did a three-day California fund-raising trip.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Nelson hated fund-raising. \xe2\x80\x9cThat sounds like a good thing,\xe2\x80\x9d I ventured.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHe actually came out behind,\xe2\x80\x9d Eagleton told me. \xe2\x80\x9cThe trip cost more than he raised.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'On election night, my wife, Nancy, and I got into the car to go to the first of several parties. It was just after 8 p.m.; the radio told us that Birch Bayh had been defeated by Dan Quayle.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re all going down,\xe2\x80\x9d I said. Nancy knew I meant the veteran Senate liberals.'b'That night, they were all defeated as Ronald Reagan won a crushing victory over Jimmy Carter. Additionally,  Abraham Ribicoff, one of the liberal stalwarts, had retired, as had Adlai Stevenson, while  Ed Muskie had left the Senate in May to become secretary of state. It was the greatest exodus of talent and experience in Senate history. The incoming Republican class had a few promising politicians, but it also included many who came with no visible accomplishments, and left, one term later, with that record intact.'b'In the weeks that followed, we Democrats were virtual zombies, numb with grief and shock. It didn\xe2\x80\x99t help that the Republicans celebrated boisterously and endlessly. At the end of one long day, the elevator opened in front of me, and a group of happy Republicans, dressed in formal wear, poured out. I noticed a heavily made-up but still strikingly attractive woman: Senator John Warner\xe2\x80\x99s wife, better known as Elizabeth Taylor.'b'The 1980 election was more than just a change of party control from Democratic to Republican. Gone was the Senate that had been experienced, progressive and bipartisan; 30 years have passed, and the decline has only accelerated. The Senate today is bitterly divided, frequently paralyzed and borderline bizarre. Olympia Snowe offered this sad observation: \xe2\x80\x9cWe have been miniaturized.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Can the Senate renew itself? In late 1963, the Senate was also in crisis, to the point that Mike Mansfield, the majority leader, prepared to offer his resignation as majority leader. But one towering achievement, the Civil Rights Act of 1964, transformed the legislative body and began the period of great accomplishment that lasted until 1980. Against the odds, let us hope that the Senate\xe2\x80\x99s recent passage of landmark health care legislation can have the same effect.'b'President Obama was right to take responsibility for the near-catastrophic Christmas Day terrorist plot. The buck, as always, must stop with the president. And it was a relief to hear him candidly acknowledge widespread failures in the vast and vastly expensive intelligence and homeland security system and insist that his administration do better. It must.'b'Of course, we have heard about these problems before in the months and years after 9/11. And while Mr. Obama did not create the current system, he has now gotten a bitter lesson in its weaknesses and its stubborn resistance to change, despite the mea culpas and pledges of reform.'b'Many of the most glaring failings \xe2\x80\x94 specifically the failure to correlate and act on available intelligence about a brewing terrorist plot \xe2\x80\x94 were supposed to have been corrected long ago. They clearly were not.'b'The review the White House released on Thursday acknowledges that the government was awash in clues \xe2\x80\x94 about a plot by an Al Qaeda affiliate in Yemen to attack the United States and about Umar Farouk Abdulmutallab, the Nigerian man trained in Yemen who is accused of trying to blow a hole in the side of Detroit-bound Northwest Flight 253. The report is filled with shocking details on how the government failed to act.'b'To recap what happened, quickly:'b'In May, Britain refused to renew Mr. Abdulmutallab\xe2\x80\x99s visa, and it put him on a watch list. In August, the National Security Agency overheard leaders of the Al Qaeda branch in Yemen discussing a plot involving a Nigerian man. In November, Mr. Abdulmutallab\xe2\x80\x99s father, a respected banker in Nigeria, warned the American Embassy in Abuja that his son was being radicalized and had disappeared in Yemen. The father even met with an official of the Central Intelligence Agency.'b'The son was put on the least-restrictive American watch list \xe2\x80\x94 one that still allowed him to board a plane to Detroit without luggage and with a ticket that was paid for with cash.'b'The report implicitly acknowledges all of this, saying that the system failed \xe2\x80\x9cto identify, correlate, and fuse into a coherent story all of the discrete pieces of intelligence held by the U.S. government\xe2\x80\x9d about both the Al Qaeda group and Mr. Abdulmutallab. It also makes clear that this was not a single failure by one agency but was a cascade of failures across agencies and departments and the bureaucracies that are supposed to coordinate them.'b'It says that once the government learned of a possible plot in Yemen, the intelligence community failed to devote more analytic resources, and it failed to put one agency or official in charge. John Brennan, the senior official responsible for figuring out what went wrong, said on Thursday that only after the failed plot did the intelligence community recognize that the group, Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula, actually posed a direct threat to the United States.'b'The report also describes serious problems with the system of watch lists, which, even with fair and frightening warning, put Mr. Abdulmutallab on one that only flagged him for future investigation rather than on the no-fly list. Janet Napolitano, the secretary of homeland security, said that while Mr. Abdulmutallab was in the air, customs officials had decided to question him after he landed.'b'The government\xe2\x80\x99s report chillingly acknowledges that, eight years after 9/11, it still does not have a single database that contains all terrorism-related information. And, incredibly, the report suggests that the intelligence community does not know the current \xe2\x80\x9cvisa status of all \xe2\x80\x98known and suspected terrorists,\xe2\x80\x99 beginning with the No Fly list.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'President Obama has now ordered a raft of immediate improvements in the handling of intelligence and in border security.'b'We would feel more reassured if these steps weren\xe2\x80\x99t so basic and self-evident: improve intelligence analysis; clarify the responsibilities of different agencies; upgrade computer technology; ensure faster distribution of intelligence reports; train National Security Agency personnel in watch list procedures; add more people to watch lists; enhance airport screening.'b'More than eight years after 9/11, the United States has another chance to learn from its mistakes. So does Al Qaeda. President Obama has his work cut out for him.'b'Between them, the Obama administration and the federal courts have reversed most of the Bush administration\xe2\x80\x99s wrongheaded environmental regulations. But a few bad rules linger on the books, among them an inadequate health standard governing harmful ozone, which most people call smog.'b'Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s Environmental Protection Agency is now proposing to get rid of this rule and replace it with a stronger standard. This would result in cleaner air and better health for millions of Americans.'b'Ozone is a photochemical reaction that occurs when sunlight mixes with nitrogen oxides and other pollutants from power plants, vehicles, refineries and industrial facilities. It poses a serious health threat, especially in children and people suffering from asthma and lung disease, and is responsible for respiratory-related emergency room visits, hospitalizations and premature deaths.'b'Apart from their health advantages, the new rules proposed reflect the administration\xe2\x80\x99s effort to restore science, as opposed to politics, to its rightful place in environmental rule-making. In 2008, the E.P.A.\xe2\x80\x99s independent board of scientific advisers unanimously recommended that the ozone standards be set at somewhere between 0.060 and 0.070 parts per million.'b'Responding, in part, to industry pressure, the Bush administration imposed a less exacting and less protective standard of 0.075 parts per million. The new proposal, to be issued after a 60-day comment period, is expected to be somewhere in the range originally proposed by the scientific panel.'b'Some big polluters, including the oil companies, are likely to resist since the new standards would require investments in stronger pollution controls on power plants, refineries and chemical plants. The standards could also provide the impetus for cleaner vehicles.'b'Lisa Jackson, the E.P.A.\xe2\x80\x99s administrator, should stick to her guns. When Carol Browner, then the administrator, first tightened health standards for smog and other pollutants like soot in 1997, industry groups rose up as one, predicting bankruptcy. But technology almost always catches up. In the end, costs are a fraction of the original claims, and the air is a lot cleaner.'b'Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California was on the mark when he said this week that the state needed to change policies that spend more money on prisons than on the state\xe2\x80\x99s once-vaunted higher education systems, which are being bled to death in budget cuts. But Mr. Schwarzenegger was way off the mark when he suggested that the answer was to privatize prison services or to pass yet another constitutional amendment, this time to limit prison spending.'b'States that privatize prisons sometimes save money, but they can also buy trouble by ceding control to companies that put profit first and inmate welfare a distant second. That would be disastrous for the California prison system. It is already under pressure from scores of court orders that require it to reduce its growing prison count and provide adequate mental, medical and dental services, as well as better care for the disabled.'b'It would generally be impossible for the state to unilaterally lower prison spending without first cutting the prison population dramatically. And because so much prison spending is nondiscretionary, a constitutional amendment that reduced spending \xe2\x80\x94 without cutting the prison population \xe2\x80\x94 would be doomed to failure. It would also draw the ire of judges who have rightly run out of patience with the state\xe2\x80\x99s long list of failures in this area.'b'The only real way for California to cut prison costs is to reverse sentencing policies that have filled its prisons to bursting and have driven up costs by about 50 percent over the last decade alone. Among other things, too many minor offenders are sent to jail for too long.'b'The Legislature tinkered at the margins of this problem last year. But real sentencing reform has proved impossible in the State Assembly, where lawmakers live in fear of the politically powerful corrections officers\xe2\x80\x99 union lobby, which enforces the status quo by labeling reformers as soft on crime.'b'Sleight of hand will not cut prison costs in California. To do that, lawmakers will need to find their spines.'b'Somewhere in the afterlife\xe2\x80\x99s screening room, Will Hays, architect of Hollywood\xe2\x80\x99s old Production Code, and the stern Catholic bishops of the Legion of Decency are probably sharing a chuckle, maybe over Scotch and cigarettes. Why? The recent fuss over \xe2\x80\x9cAvatar,\xe2\x80\x9d the James Cameron film in which the latest in cinematic technology meets the oldest argument in the movies: whether vice on screen encourages vice in real life.'b'In \xe2\x80\x9cAvatar,\xe2\x80\x9d a character played by Sigourney Weaver smokes. They have criticized the movie as a threat to public health.'b'Your initial response \xe2\x80\x94 for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake \xe2\x80\x94 might be tempered by knowing that the advocates have persuasive scientific studies to support their warnings. Stanton A. Glantz, the director of the Center for Tobacco Control Research and Education at the University of California, San Francisco, points to several, in publications like the medical journal The Lancet, showing strong evidence that on-screen smoking increases teenage cigarette use.'b'The World Health Organization wants governments to \xe2\x80\x9cseverely restrict smoking imagery in all film media.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Glantz doesn\xe2\x80\x99t go that far. Us, too. But it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to condemn the strategy of using information, not censorship, to confront a perceived public-health threat, especially when, as Mr. Glantz argues, big spending on movie product placement by tobacco companies tilts the field heavily in smoking\xe2\x80\x99s favor.'b'Probably the only rational response is to let the artists and scolds flourish together, along with information. Protect our children as we must, but we should leave the moviemakers to do their thing.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Art of the Deal'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by Judith H. Dobrzynski (Op-Ed, Jan. 2):'b'All who care about our art museums should be grateful to Ms. Dobrzynski for raising an issue about which few choose to speak. But I disagree with her conclusion \xe2\x80\x94 that selling works of art to deal with a museum\xe2\x80\x99s financial crisis is justified \xe2\x80\x94 for two reasons. First, it would not work, and second, it would probably have unintended consequences.'b'To raise substantial amounts of income, you must sell good, and thereby potentially important, works of art. The smaller the amount raised by sales of works of art, the more this solution becomes stopgap. If a long-term solution is to be achieved, not only must substantial amounts be raised, but also the money must be put into an endowment with an annual spendable rate that preserves the principal.'b'The unintended consequences could well include a change in the board\xe2\x80\x99s perception of its fiduciary responsibility to one more focused on asset management than philanthropy. Human nature has shown us that if there is an accepted alternative to giving one\xe2\x80\x99s own money, many, if not all, will seize it. And potential and past donors of works of art will be uncertain as to the future use of their gifts.'b'The decisions that would need to be made by the \xe2\x80\x9cimpartial arbitrator\xe2\x80\x9d suggested by Ms. Dobrzynski \xe2\x80\x94 What art is too important to sell? Have all the possible reductions in operating costs been achieved? Has the board contributed to the maximum of its capacity? \xe2\x80\x94 are too central to the integrity of a museum to be given to others, even if that were to provide temporary political and ethical cover.'b'James N. Wood'b'\nLos Angeles, Jan. 4, 2010'b''b''b'The writer is president and chief executive of the J. Paul Getty Trust, which operates the J. Paul Getty Museum.'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'The argument that museums should come before an arbitrator or regulatory agency to seek permission to deaccession objects from their collections fails to recognize the realities of deaccessioning today.'b'While it is true that the economic downturn has caused more museums to capitalize their collections and to consider the unethical action of deaccessioning to finance general operating costs, in most cases deaccession through sale, transfer and exchange is a routine part of responsible and sustainable collections management, especially in the absence of adequate public funding to maintain museums\xe2\x80\x99 ever-growing inventory of objects.'b'An appropriate response is to educate museum trustees that collections are not just another asset but central to an institution\xe2\x80\x99s identity, to draft sound acquisition policies shaped by a museum\xe2\x80\x99s mission and to make the deaccession process transparent to the communities they serve.'b'If museum directors routinely made public their deaccession activity, as the Indianapolis Museum of Art does on its 'b'Web site'b', then we could move beyond the polarizing nature of deaccession discussions.'b'Janet Marstine'b'\nSouth Orange, N.J., Jan. 3, 2010'b''b''b'The writer is an assistant professor and director of the Institute of Museum Ethics at Seton Hall University.'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s unreasonably paternalistic to subject institutions to some supposedly objective case-by-case system, like the one proposed by Judith H. Dobrzynski, for the purpose of determining how an institution like an art museum should be permitted to use its assets.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s a simpler, sounder system to guide deaccession: The bought can be sold.'b'This system reserves the sanctity of donor intent, as well as that of artwork acquired under special circumstances. And it ignores the largely unjustified slippery-slope paranoia that if allowed to sell one piece of artwork in a time of need, then institutions would more easily part with others in the future.'b'If the struggling institution purchased a piece of artwork free of restrictions preventing resale, then that institution should be permitted to sell it at will. Extraordinary times need not call for extraordinary measures \xe2\x80\x94 just reasonable ones.'b'Hillel Buechler'b'\nDix Hills, N.Y., Jan. 2, 2010'b''b''b'The writer is a student at Brandeis University, which has been considering a plan to close its art museum and sell the works to raise money. 'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'Typically when museums run into the kinds of financial difficulties that prompt thoughts of selling off parts of their \xe2\x80\x9cpermanent\xe2\x80\x9d collections, those difficulties arose from years of fiscal mismanagement by the very same directors and trustees now looking for quick monetary fixes.'b'This is why museum professionals argue that when museums sell holdings, the income should be reserved for future acquisitions rather than smoothing over bad fiscal decisions. Doing otherwise only removes the museum world\xe2\x80\x99s equivalent of moral hazard.'b'All too often a root cause of a museum\xe2\x80\x99s financial crisis is a building expansion compelled by the growth of its collection. A more effective, long-term solution to the perennial problem of museums spending beyond their means is to rework the professional practices regarding acquisitions.'b'When a trustee or someone else donates a work to a museum, the conditions of the gift should include a cash payment to the museum\xe2\x80\x99s operating endowment equal to a set percentage of the tax-deductible value of the work. Similarly, when a museum uses money from an acquisition fund to purchase a work, a set percentage of the price should be paid into the operating endowment.'b'To allow museum directors and trustees to keep growing their institutions\xe2\x80\x99 collections without taking responsibility for the long-term costs of accommodating and caring for them is irresponsible. To permit them to start selling off collections, no matter how carefully the sales are vetted, will only perpetuate a problem that prompted the sales in the first place.'b'Jeffrey Abt'b'\nHuntington Woods, Mich., Jan.\n2, 2010'b''b''b'The writer is an associate professor of art at Wayne State University and the author of \xe2\x80\x9cA Museum on the Verge: A Socioeconomic History of the Detroit Institute of Arts, 1882-2000.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Democrats Wary as Two Senators Decide to Retire'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (front page, Jan. 7): At this point it does not look good for the Democratic Party because wars continue and expand; the economy is shaky for millions, yet the bankers got big bonuses; and the public option is dead. 'b''b'Health care reform is almost (knock on wood) a done deal. Next up: fixing the financial system. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be writing a lot about financial reform in the weeks ahead. Let me begin by asking a basic question: What should reformers try to accomplish?'b'A lot of the public debate has been about protecting borrowers. Indeed, a new Consumer Financial Protection Agency to help stop deceptive lending practices is a very good idea. And better consumer protection might have limited the overall size of the housing bubble.'b'But consumer protection, while it might have blocked many subprime loans, wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have prevented the sharply rising rate of delinquency on conventional, plain-vanilla mortgages. And it certainly wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have prevented the monstrous boom and bust in commercial real estate.'b'Reform, in other words, probably can\xe2\x80\x99t prevent either bad loans or bubbles. But it can do a great deal to ensure that bubbles don\xe2\x80\x99t collapse the financial system when they burst.'b'Bear in mind that the implosion of the 1990s stock bubble, while nasty  \xe2\x80\x94  households took a $5 trillion hit  \xe2\x80\x94  didn\xe2\x80\x99t provoke a financial crisis. So what was different about the housing bubble that followed?'b'The short answer is that while the stock bubble created a lot of risk, that risk was fairly widely diffused across the economy. By contrast, the risks created by the housing bubble were strongly concentrated in the financial sector. As a result, the collapse of the housing bubble threatened to bring down the nation\xe2\x80\x99s banks. And banks play a special role in the economy. If they can\xe2\x80\x99t function, the wheels of commerce as a whole grind to a halt.'b'Why did the bankers take on so much risk? Because it was in their self-interest to do so. By increasing leverage  \xe2\x80\x94  that is, by making risky investments with borrowed money  \xe2\x80\x94  banks could increase their short-term profits. And these short-term profits, in turn, were reflected in immense personal bonuses. If the concentration of risk in the banking sector increased the danger of a systemwide financial crisis, well, that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t the bankers\xe2\x80\x99 problem.'b'Of course, that conflict of interest is the reason we have bank regulation. But in the years before the crisis, the rules were relaxed  \xe2\x80\x94  and, even more important, regulators failed to expand the rules to cover the growing \xe2\x80\x9cshadow\xe2\x80\x9d banking system, consisting of institutions like Lehman Brothers that performed banklike functions even though they didn\xe2\x80\x99t offer conventional bank deposits.'b'The result was a financial industry that was hugely profitable as long as housing prices were going up  \xe2\x80\x94  finance accounted for more than a third of total U.S. profits as the bubble was inflating  \xe2\x80\x94  but was brought to the edge of collapse once the bubble burst. It took government aid on an immense scale, and the promise of even more aid if needed, to pull the industry back from the brink.'b'And here\xe2\x80\x99s the thing: Since that aid came with few strings  \xe2\x80\x94  in particular, no major banks were nationalized even though some clearly wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have survived without government help  \xe2\x80\x94  there\xe2\x80\x99s every incentive for bankers to engage in a repeat performance. After all, it\xe2\x80\x99s now clear that they\xe2\x80\x99re living in a heads-they-win, tails-taxpayers-lose world.'b'The test for reform, then, is whether it reduces bankers\xe2\x80\x99 incentives and ability to concentrate risk going forward.'b'Transparency is part of the answer. Before the crisis, hardly anyone realized just how much risk the banks were taking on. More disclosure, especially with regard to complex financial derivatives, would clearly help.'b'Beyond that, an important aspect of reform should be new rules limiting bank leverage. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be delving into proposed legislation in future columns, but here\xe2\x80\x99s what I can say about the financial reform bill the House passed  \xe2\x80\x94  with zero Republican votes  \xe2\x80\x94  last month: Its limits on leverage look O.K. Not great, but O.K. It would, however, be all too easy for those rules to get weakened to the point where they wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t do the job. A few tweaks in the fine print and banks would be free to play the same game all over again.'b'And reform really should take on the financial industry\xe2\x80\x99s compensation practices. If Congress can\xe2\x80\x99t legislate away the financial rewards for excessive risk-taking, it can at least try to tax them.'b'Let me conclude with a political note. The main reason for reform is to serve the nation. If we don\xe2\x80\x99t get major financial reform now, we\xe2\x80\x99re laying the foundations for the next crisis. But there are also political reasons to act.'b'For there\xe2\x80\x99s a populist rage building in this country, and President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s kid-gloves treatment of the bankers has put Democrats on the wrong side of this rage. If Congressional Democrats don\xe2\x80\x99t take a tough line with the banks in the months ahead, they will pay a big price in November.'b''b'Readers intending to watch the movie \xe2\x80\x9cAvatar\xe2\x80\x9d should know that major events in the plot are revealed.'b''b'Every age produces its own sort of fables, and our age seems to have produced The White Messiah fable.'b'This is the oft-repeated story about a manly young adventurer who goes into the wilderness in search of thrills and profit. But, once there, he meets the native people and finds that they are noble and spiritual and pure. And so he emerges as their Messiah, leading them on a righteous crusade against his own rotten civilization.'b'Avid moviegoers will remember \xe2\x80\x9cA Man Called Horse,\xe2\x80\x9d which began to establish the pattern, and \xe2\x80\x9cAt Play in the Fields of the Lord.\xe2\x80\x9d More people will have seen \xe2\x80\x9cDances With Wolves\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cThe Last Samurai.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Kids have been given their own pure versions of the fable, like \xe2\x80\x9cPocahontas\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cFernGully.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s a pretty serviceable formula. Once a director selects the White Messiah fable, he or she doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have to waste time explaining the plot because everybody knows roughly what\xe2\x80\x99s going to happen.'b'The formula also gives movies a little socially conscious allure. Audiences like it because it is so environmentally sensitive. Academy Award voters like it because it is so multiculturally aware. Critics like it because the formula inevitably involves the loincloth-clad good guys sticking it to the military-industrial complex.'b'Yet of all the directors who have used versions of the White Messiah formula over the years, no one has done so with as much exuberance as James Cameron in \xe2\x80\x9cAvatar.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cAvatar\xe2\x80\x9d is a racial fantasy par excellence. The hero is a white former Marine who is adrift in his civilization. He ends up working with a giant corporation and flies through space to help plunder the environment of a pristine planet and displace its peace-loving natives.'b'The peace-loving natives \xe2\x80\x94 compiled from a m\xc3\xa9lange of Native American, African, Vietnamese, Iraqi and other cultural fragments \xe2\x80\x94 are like the peace-loving natives you\xe2\x80\x99ve seen in a hundred other movies. They\xe2\x80\x99re tall, muscular and admirably slender. They walk around nearly naked. They are phenomenal athletes and pretty good singers and dancers.'b'The white guy notices that the peace-loving natives are much cooler than the greedy corporate tools and the bloodthirsty U.S. military types he came over with. He goes to live with the natives, and, in short order, he\xe2\x80\x99s the most awesome member of their tribe. He has sex with their hottest babe. He learns to jump through the jungle and ride horses. It turns out that he\xe2\x80\x99s even got more guts and athletic prowess than they do. He flies the big red bird that no one in generations has been able to master.'b'Along the way, he has his consciousness raised. The peace-loving natives are at one with nature, and even have a fiber-optic cable sticking out of their bodies that they can plug into horses and trees, which is like Horse Whispering without the wireless technology. Because they are not corrupted by things like literacy, cellphones and blockbuster movies, they have deep and tranquil souls.'b'The natives help the white guy discover that he, too, has a deep and tranquil soul.'b'The natives have hot bodies and perfect ecological sensibilities, but they are natural creatures, not history-making ones. When the military-industrial complex comes in to strip mine their homes, they need a White Messiah to lead and inspire the defense.'b'Our hero leaps in, with the help of a pack of dinosaurs summoned by Mother Earth. As he and his fellow freedom fighters kill wave after wave of Marines or former Marines or whatever they are, he achieves the ultimate prize: He is accepted by the natives and can spend the rest of his life in their excellent culture.'b'Cameron\xe2\x80\x99s handling of the White Messiah fable is not the reason \xe2\x80\x9cAvatar\xe2\x80\x9d is such a huge global hit. As John Podhoretz 'b'wrote in The Weekly Standard'b', \xe2\x80\x9cCameron has simply used these familiar bromides as shorthand to give his special-effects spectacular some resonance.\xe2\x80\x9d The plotline gives global audiences a chance to see American troops get killed. It offers useful hooks on which McDonald\xe2\x80\x99s and other corporations can hang their tie-in campaigns.'b'Still, would it be totally annoying to point out that the whole White Messiah fable, especially as Cameron applies it, is kind of offensive?'b'It rests on the stereotype that white people are rationalist and technocratic while colonial victims are spiritual and athletic. It rests on the assumption that nonwhites need the White Messiah to lead their crusades. It rests on the assumption that illiteracy is the path to grace. It also creates a sort of two-edged cultural imperialism. Natives can either have their history shaped by cruel imperialists or benevolent ones, but either way, they are going to be supporting actors in our journey to self-admiration.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s just escapism, obviously, but benevolent romanticism can be just as condescending as the malevolent kind \xe2\x80\x94 even when you surround it with pop-up ferns and floating mountains.'b'Pittsburgh'b'IN the final days of a year dominated by repeated \xe2\x80\x94 and mostly unheeded \xe2\x80\x94 calls for full disclosure on the part of Wall Street banks, pharmaceutical companies, the N.F.L. and any number of other organizations, transparency arrived out of the blue from an unlikely quarter if ever there was one: the Freemasons.'b'Thanks go not to Dan Brown, whose latest novel, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Lost Symbol,\xe2\x80\x9d focuses on the notoriously mysterious fraternal order, but to Tom Sturgeon, a career law-enforcement officer, who was installed as Right Worshipful Grand Master for Pennsylvania on Dec. 28. His ceremony, in a break with centuries-old Masonic tradition, was held at a convention center here and open to the public. \xe2\x80\x9cWe need to make Freemasonry more contemporary,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Sturgeon told me, \xe2\x80\x9cto make it reflect 2010, not 1910 \xe2\x80\x94 or 1810.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Nonetheless, the audience of about 1,200 people seemed to consist primarily of members and their families with a sizeable contingent of Masonic dignitaries from 13 other states and Canada. Many had come in full regalia, sporting tailcoats, purple moire  or black velvet \xe2\x80\x9ccollars,\xe2\x80\x9d satin aprons embroidered with esoteric symbols, white gloves, swords \xe2\x80\x94 all telegraphing distinctions of rank legible only to insiders.'b'Freemasonry in America is organized by state \xe2\x80\x94 there is no higher governing body \xe2\x80\x94 and Pennsylvania is the largest Masonic jurisdiction in the world, with a spectacular temple in Philadelphia, completed in 1873, as its headquarters. Mr. Sturgeon was sworn in reciting the same oath, or \xe2\x80\x9cobligation,\xe2\x80\x9d Benjamin Franklin recited 275 years ago when he took the same office.'b'If the ceremony at the convention center was any indication, it appears that not much has changed in the interim, although the torches around the altar are now electric and the musical repertoire has been updated to include \xe2\x80\x9cBeer Barrel Polka\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cNo Man Is an Island.\xe2\x80\x9d Membership has been declining (currently 120,000 in Pennsylvania, down from 260,000 when Mr. Sturgeon joined in 1965) and the median age has been steadily climbing (now 68).'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBrethren, ladies and friends,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Sturgeon greeted the audience for his installation. \xe2\x80\x9cThe 21st-century Masonic Renaissance starts today!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The \xe2\x80\x9crenaissance\xe2\x80\x9d is Mr. Sturgeon\xe2\x80\x99s agenda for reform, jump-starting a membership drive with a new strategy that permits \xe2\x80\x9cselective invitation,\xe2\x80\x9d replacing the old \xe2\x80\x9cTo be one, ask one\xe2\x80\x9d policy that forbade Masons to proselytize. He also decreed a lifetime dues exemption for any Mason over 60 who brings in two new members under 30. Like other Pennsylvania grand masters before him, Mr. Sturgeon designed a necktie, to be distributed as a token of appreciation. Typically, the ties are a vehicle for the Masonic insignia; his is more in the style of Jerry Garcia, something he thinks younger guys might be more inclined to wear.'b'In his most radical move, Mr. Sturgeon has mandated that the ritual be published in book form. In Pennsylvania, since the order\xe2\x80\x99s beginnings, each Mason has learned his obligation from another Mason, one on one. The ritual had never been written down. For the two lowest ranks of Freemasonry it lasts 30 minutes or so; for the third and highest degree it takes roughly an hour and runs to some 8,000 words. \xe2\x80\x9cIt might take a man away from home maybe 50 nights to sit and learn it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'Though candidates will still be required to perform the ritual from memory, the printed text allows them to learn it on their own. Mr. Sturgeon assured his fellow masons that photocopying will be prohibited, that all copies will be signed out and strictly audited. Even so, this announcement met with silence, a response he had foreseen. \xe2\x80\x9cMany Masons will tell you that one of the great bonds of this fraternity happens when I meet with you 40 times to go over this work, and I become your mentor,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cNow, that\xe2\x80\x99s true. But for the greater good, we have to make a decision.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Not a secret society but \xe2\x80\x9ca society with secrets\xe2\x80\x9d is how the protagonist of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Lost Symbol\xe2\x80\x9d describes the Masons. Has that secrecy served a purpose? Is the famous Masonic bond based, at least to some extent, on shared information that nobody else knows? If that was once the case, it seems safe to say that it isn\xe2\x80\x99t any longer, now that detailed accounts of the Masons\xe2\x80\x99 procedures have been posted online, including YouTube videos of the secret handshake.'b'The drama seems to be in short supply. Any Dan Brown fans who came to the convention center in Pittsburgh expecting daggers pressed to bare chests or red wine drunk out of a skull surely left disappointed. The conspiracy theorists, it seems, needed the Masons\xe2\x80\x99 secrecy even more than the Masons needed it themselves.'b'EVERY year, more than 100,000 Americans discover that they have  often life-threatening blood and bone-marrow diseases like leukemia.  For many, the only hope is a transplant of blood-producing marrow cells.'b'Finding someone to donate the marrow is challenging, though, because the cells must be a near-perfect genetic match with the patient\xe2\x80\x99s own cells, and those are hard to find. Even siblings have compatible marrow cells only 30 percent of the time. Most patients must search nationally and internationally for potential donors.'b'Only 7 in 10 Caucasian patients who need a donor find one. For African-Americans, the odds are longer still; only one in four do.  Tens of thousands of Americans have died for lack of a donor.'b'It would make sense to encourage donation by offering potential donors an incentive \xe2\x80\x94 a gift to a favorite charity, for example, or a scholarship. But federal law forbids doctors, nurses or dying patients to offer any incentives. The intent of the 1984 law, 'b'the National Organ Transplant Act'b', was to prevent the sale of human kidneys for transplant, out of concern that a market in organs could tempt people to risk their health for money by making an irreversible decision to be a donor.'b'But with marrow donation this is not an issue. Unlike organs, marrow cells \xe2\x80\x94 basically, immature blood cells \xe2\x80\x94 are renewable. The body grows fresh ones quickly enough to replace those extracted for transplant in about a month. And donating marrow cells is now very safe \xe2\x80\x94 in most cases, it\xe2\x80\x99s simply a matter of drawing blood from the donor\xe2\x80\x99s arm and running it through a machine that skims off the marrow cells. Well under  half of donations are conducted the old way, by harvesting marrow cells from the donor\xe2\x80\x99s hip.'b'Interestingly, Congress didn\xe2\x80\x99t bar compensation for all human donors. In writing the 1984 law, it excluded renewable cells like blood or sperm from the payment prohibition, even as it inexplicably included bone marrow.'b'We have filed in federal district court a constitutional challenge to the marrow prohibition, because we want to set up a pilot program to ascertain the extent to which certain strategic incentives \xe2\x80\x94 a $3,000 scholarship, a housing allowance, a charitable gift \xe2\x80\x94 could increase marrow-cell donations.'b'If our suit is successful and incentives are allowed, it would not create a freewheeling market in bone marrow donation. Marrow donation would, and should, remain anonymous \xe2\x80\x94 and there should be no negotiation with donors. There would be no buyers or sellers, no possibility of market-like transactions.'b'But people who provide life-giving marrow cells could, in good conscience, get something in return for helping save a life.'b'On July 12, the Op-Ed page published an article by Jonathan Gruber, a professor of economics at M.I.T., on health insurance and taxation. Unless Congress and the White House push a robust job-creation agenda \xe2\x80\x94  starting now \xe2\x80\x94  worsening joblessness is a distinct possibility, even if the economy in general recovers in the coming months. That may be the best hope for concerted federal action to put Americans back to work.'b'At 10 percent, the unemployment rate was unchanged from November to December. But the only reason it held steady is that 661,000 jobless Americans were not counted as unemployed last month because they had not looked for a job in the four weeks preceding the December survey. Over all, an estimated 3.6 million out-of-work people have been uncounted since the recession began in December 2007. They include people who had not recently looked for work and those who would have entered the work force in normal times, like recent high school and college graduates, but remained on the sidelines as jobs disappeared.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s the rub: As soon as the economy shows more signs of life, those missing workers are likely to start looking for work. That would add to the ranks of the officially unemployed, causing the jobless rate to rise, perhaps dramatically \xe2\x80\x94 unless jobs are being created to absorb the labor glut.'b'The private sector alone is unlikely to create enough new jobs, even as the economy recovers. Employers are more likely to add hours to the truncated workweeks of existing employees than to hire new workers. They may also prefer to make temporary workers permanent rather than add new staff.'b'And even if hiring were unexpectedly strong, it could not repair the severely damaged job market anytime soon. But with the population growing \xe2\x80\x94 and with revisions to earlier data expected to show larger losses than previously reported \xe2\x80\x94 the economy is probably coming up short by 10 million to 11 million jobs. To allow these huge, previously untaxed gains to be passed on to heirs (who have themselves done nothing to create the assets) at their present, appreciated value so they are never taxed would be truly unfair to all taxpayers.'b'Robert Ginsburg'b'\n Pikesville, Md., Jan. 1, 2010'b''b'To the Editor:'b'As an owner, trainer and lover of horses for over 50 years, I salute your Dec. 27 editorial \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Out of the Gate'b',\xe2\x80\x9d against maltreatment of horses.'b'But I wish to point out that making all slaughter illegal is itself cruel in cases where the horses are old, crippled, malformed or \xe2\x80\x9coutlaws\xe2\x80\x9d that have proven to be beyond reform. And we cry.'b'Dee Lambert'b'\n   Christmas Valley, Ore., Dec. 28, 2009'b''b'Washington'b'\xe2\x80\x9cSTARTLING results,\xe2\x80\x9d promised the CNN teasers, building anticipation for a segment on this week\xe2\x80\x99s big mental health news: 'b'a study'b' led by researchers at the University of Pennsylvania indicating that the antidepressants Paxil and imipramine work no better than placebos (\xe2\x80\x9cthan sugar pills,\xe2\x80\x9d said CNN) for people with mild to moderate depression.'b'Happy pills don\xe2\x80\x99t work, the story quickly became, even though, boiled down to that headline, it was neither startling nor particularly true.'b'It sounded true. After all, any number of experts have argued that antidepressants \xe2\x80\x94 and selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors like Paxil in particular \xe2\x80\x94 are overhyped and oversold. And after years of hearing about shady practices within the pharmaceutical industry, and of psychiatrists who enrich themselves in the shadows by helping the industry market its drugs, we are primed to believe stories of psychiatric trickery.'b'Yet in all the excitement about \xe2\x80\x9cstartling\xe2\x80\x9d news and \xe2\x80\x9csugar pills,\xe2\x80\x9d a more nuanced and truer story about mental health care in America was all but lost.'b'That story begins to take shape when you consider what the new study actually said: Antidepressants do work for very severely depressed people, as well as for those whose mild depression is chronic. However, the researchers found, the pills don\xe2\x80\x99t work for people who aren\xe2\x80\x99t really depressed \xe2\x80\x94 people with short-term, minor depression whose problems tend to get better on their own. For many of them, it\xe2\x80\x99s often been observed, merely participating in a drug trial (with its accompanying conversation, education and emphasis on self-care) can be anti-depressant enough.'b'None of this comes as news to people who have been prescribing or studying antidepressants over the past 20 years. Neither is it all that likely to change the practice of treating depression \xe2\x80\x94 at least as it\xe2\x80\x99s carried out by responsible doctors.'b'After all, people who are depressed for the first time, or have been depressed for only a short time, or are upset after a personal setback, aren\xe2\x80\x99t considered ideal candidates for immediate drug therapy. And, contrary to popular belief, there\xe2\x80\x99s no evidence that most psychiatrists regularly prescribe pills straight off to people who can get better by reading about depression, exercising or doing nothing. What numbers do exist, said Peter Kramer, who has written extensively on antidepressant use in books like \xe2\x80\x9cListening to Prozac,\xe2\x80\x9d indicate that relatively few people with minimal depression leave psychiatrists\xe2\x80\x99 offices with a prescription.'b'That people have come to believe otherwise may be in part because most patients with depression are treated by general practitioners, not psychiatrists. Studies have shown that these primary care doctors don\xe2\x80\x99t strenuously enough screen their patients for depression before prescribing drugs, or closely monitor their care afterward.'b'And here the truer story about mental health care in America begins to unfold. The trouble is not that the drugs don\xe2\x80\x99t work; it\xe2\x80\x99s that the care is not very good.'b'Inadequate treatment by nonspecialists is only a piece of the problem. In fact, most Americans with depression, rather than being overmedicated, are undertreated or not treated at all. This might have been big news this week, too, had anyone noticed another academic study, 'b'a survey'b' of nearly 16,000 people published this month in The Archives of General Psychiatry, which looked more broadly at the picture of depression in America. The survey found that those who did get care were given psychotherapy more often than drugs. That finding might give heart to those who would prefer to see more alternatives to psychiatric drugs \xe2\x80\x94 if it weren\xe2\x80\x99t for the fact that so much psychotherapy is so bad.'b'In 2008, a team of psychologists brought this point home in blunt terms in the journal Psychological Science in the Public Interest. \xe2\x80\x9cDespite the availability of highly effective interventions,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'they wrote'b', \xe2\x80\x9crelatively few psychologists learn or practice these interventions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This is the big picture of mental health care in America: not perfectly healthy people popping pills for no reason, but people with real illnesses lacking access to care; facing barriers like ignorance, stigma and high prices; or finding care that is ineffective.'b'It is a societywide concern that a  co-author of the new antidepressants study readily acknowledges. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat we reported on was a very small piece of a very large problem,\xe2\x80\x9d Robert J. DeRubeis, a professor of psychology at the University of Pennsylvania, told me. \xe2\x80\x9cThose kinds of things are not being sorted out in this country because there\xe2\x80\x99s no system. Nobody\xe2\x80\x99s asking these questions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'With health care reform almost certainly on the horizon, perhaps now we can hope they will start asking.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s no secret that Afghanistan has replaced Iraq as the central front in America\xe2\x80\x99s struggle against Islamic extremism. Indeed, as illustrated by the chart below (based on data from the Pentagon and 'b'icasualties.org'b', an independent research group), in 2009 there were 498 American and allied deaths in Afghanistan as compared with  141 in Iraq.'b'While the loss of any American life is tragic, it\xe2\x80\x99s important to point out that the Iraq figure is down from 306 fatalities in 2008, and that most of these deaths took place in Baghdad and surrounding towns, a sign that the United States is making progress in turning the counterinsurgency efforts over to Iraqi military and police forces.'b'The news from Afghanistan is far less heartening. The death toll is up by 40 percent from last year, and that\xe2\x80\x99s without including fatalities among Afghan Army and security personnel. Most of the deaths are occurring on the battlefield (unlike in Iraq, where half the fatalities weren\xe2\x80\x99t related to combat), an indication of the intensity of the fighting. And while many see the war in Afghanistan as an American effort, the colors  on the chart show the extent to which the Western allies are sharing the deadly burden.'b'The country needs health care reform, and Congress should move quickly to pass legislation. But as House and Senate leaders work to forge a consensus bill for final approval, they should look for ways to lessen the Medicaid burden on hard-pressed state budgets \xe2\x80\x94 and ensure that relief is fairly apportioned.'b'One of the important goals is to extend coverage to more low-income Americans. The bills quite sensibly require the states to expand Medicaid and offer them generous federal support to do so. Even then, the states \xe2\x80\x94 whose Medicaid budgets are already badly stretched \xe2\x80\x94 will have to put up substantial money of their own.'b'Ideally, Congress should find some way to get more  money to state Medicaid programs. But if that proves politically impossible, as seems likely, the states will have to bear part of the additional burden in what is, after all, a shared national enterprise. Their poorer citizens will benefit greatly.'b''b'HOW DOES MEDICAID WORK?'b'The program currently pays for health care and nursing home care for 50 million poor Americans. In fiscal year 2008, the federal government paid about 57 percent of the total $354 billion cost, with the states picking up the rest. Both bills would broaden eligibility, and their requirement that everyone obtain insurance should also push more currently eligible people to sign up. That is a good thing.'b'It is important to remember that under the reform bills, all of these people would gain access to health insurance \xe2\x80\x94 either through Medicaid or through federally subsidized private insurance plans. Medicaid is a better deal for poor people because it typically charges much less in co-payments and premiums for a better package of benefits than private insurers are apt to provide. From an overall budgetary standpoint, Medicaid is also the cheapest way to insure people since it reimburses hospitals, doctors and other providers at a lower rate than private insurers do.'b'The issue here is how much the states can and should pay for expanding Medicaid rolls.'b''b''b'HOW WOULD IT CHANGE? 'b''b' Right now the states differ considerably on who is eligible for Medicaid. (Only a few   states extend much coverage to poor, childless adults.) Both the House and the Senate versions would require the states to cover all poor people under age 65. The House version would set an income ceiling of 150 percent of the federal poverty level, or $33,000 for a family of four. The Senate bill would expand coverage only up to 133 percent of the federal poverty level, or $29,300 for a family of four. Our own preference would be to choose the higher ceiling for the benefit of more people.'b''b'WHO PAYS? AND HOW MUCH? 'b'To ease the additional burden on the states, under both bills the federal government would pick up the entire tab for newly eligible enrollees for the first two or three years. After that the states would have to pick up part of the cost.'b'The amount of federal support would differ for two categories of people. For those new enrollees who could have been covered under the state\xe2\x80\x99s existing rules \xe2\x80\x94 but never enrolled \xe2\x80\x94 the federal government would pay its usual share, which varies depending on a state\xe2\x80\x99s per capita income. In fiscal year 2008, the federal government paid three-quarters of the program\xe2\x80\x99s costs in Mississippi but only half the cost in New York and California.'b'But for all \xe2\x80\x9cnewly eligible\xe2\x80\x9d enrollees \xe2\x80\x94 those who were not covered by a state\xe2\x80\x99s previous rules \xe2\x80\x94 the states would get a greatly enhanced match. That is appropriate since the goal is to enroll a lot more people. The House would have the federal government pay 91 percent of the costs of these newly eligible in every state. The Senate would pay 82 to 95 percent of the cost, depending on a state\xe2\x80\x99s per capita income. We believe that per capita income is a poor measure of how much help a state needs, especially in states like New York and California, where a veneer of very-high-income people can skew the average income upward. The House approach seems fairer.'b''b'A BIGGER DISPARITY. 'b'While both bills would provide enhanced matches for \xe2\x80\x9cnewly eligible\xe2\x80\x9d Medicaid recipients, they have very different definitions of \xe2\x80\x9cnew.\xe2\x80\x9d The House would count people who are already covered by Medicaid under so-called waiver programs, which are considered demonstration projects. The Senate bill would not.'b'That may sound arcane, but it could make a huge difference. New York, which has large numbers of people in waiver programs, estimates that the Senate bill would cost it an additional $1 billion a year, while the House bill could actually save the state close to $4 billion a year. While good news for New York, that seems unfair.'b'California, a state in comparable if not worse budgetary distress, would get no such relief for its previous expansions of Medicaid because they were mostly achieved through amendments to its state Medicaid plan, not the waiver process. State officials calculate that the reform bills would require it to put up $3 billion to $4 billion a year to cover additional enrollees.'b'Instead of paying more for people already on the rolls, Congress should try to provide an enhanced share to all states for all new Medicaid enrollees, whether or not they were previously eligible.'b''b'WHAT ABOUT THE LAGGARDS? 'b'Texas, a state that currently has far less generous Medicaid coverage, illustrates the problems that can confront even a laggard state. While it will get substantial federal help to pay for its \xe2\x80\x9cnewly eligible\xe2\x80\x9d citizens, it estimates that it would still have to spend $20 billion to $24 billion over a decade to expand its Medicaid rolls.'b'There is no perfect answer to these problems other than providing a lot more federal money for Medicaid expansion. So far the Senate has provided extra money to win the votes of key senators, most notoriously by granting Nebraska full federal funding in perpetuity for all newly eligible people it enrolls. Ideally, that should be done for all states, as Senator Ben Nelson, under fire for his special deal, has recently suggested.'b'That is not apt to happen. But surely Congress could find at least a little more money to ease the problems of California and other states that have already expanded their Medicaid rolls and now face crushing deficits.'b''b'This editorial is a part of a 'b'continuing series'b' by The New York Times that is providing a comprehensive examination of the policy changes and politics behind the debate over health care reform.'b''b'About eight years ago, a company called Beef Products Inc. had the novel idea of injecting its ground beef with ammonia to kill deadly E. coli and salmonella. The Agriculture Department pronounced the idea effective and exempted Beef Products Inc. from routine tests. The company\xe2\x80\x99s beef began appearing regularly in grocery stores, fast food restaurants and school lunch programs. It turned out the beef was not safe.'b'The slaughterhouse trimmings the company used to grind its beef \xe2\x80\x94 known as processed beef \xe2\x80\x94 have a much higher microbial presence than other cuts, including E. coli and salmonella, and the ability of the ammonia to kill the germs appears to have been greatly oversold.'b'Investigators working for a division of the Agriculture Department that oversees school lunch programs found higher rates of salmonella in meat from Beef Products than from other vendors.'b'The Agriculture Department has now belatedly withdrawn its exemption. Top officials admitted that they had been unaware of the problem until The New York Times alerted them to the school lunch test results.'b'This whole scary mess suggests several problems that need fixing, starting with better coordination. School lunch officials and managers at the Agriculture Department\xe2\x80\x99s meat safety division are obviously not sharing information effectively. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack has since directed them to do so. And mindsets must change. School lunch programs were  initially attracted to processed beef (despite its alkaline taste and offensive smell) because it was so much cheaper. Safety and quality must be higher priorities than price.'b'With its exemption has been withdrawn, Beef Products Inc. deserves the closest possible scrutiny: its beef is widely used, not just in schools. And the Agriculture Department\xe2\x80\x99s meat safety division clearly must  be more vigilant. Consumers should not have to wait until somebody in the school lunch program blows the whistle.'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s with the apologies? Goldman Sachs\xe2\x80\x99s Lloyd Blankfein caught his fellow titans by surprise in November, admitting that \xe2\x80\x9cwe participated in things that were clearly wrong and have reason to regret.\xe2\x80\x9d That came less than two weeks after he infuriated pretty much everyone else by declaring that Goldman was \xe2\x80\x9cdoing God\xe2\x80\x99s work.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'He was not the only banker indulging in the contrition thing. (In March, Bank of America\xe2\x80\x99s   Ken Lewis, who presided over the bungled acquisition of Merrill Lynch, issued his own apology and was still pushed out.) Now the former Time Warner chief executive Gerald Levin, who is not even a banker, has plunged into the zeitgeist.'b'Mr. Levin issued a belated \xe2\x80\x94 by a decade \xe2\x80\x94 mea culpa for buying AOL and urged others to follow his lead. \xe2\x80\x9cI presided over the worst deal of the century, apparently,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Levin said. \xe2\x80\x9cI guess it\xe2\x80\x99s time for those who are involved in companies to stand up and say: You know what, I\xe2\x80\x99m solely responsible for it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Wall Street has a lot to apologize for, but contrition would be more convincing if it came with accountability: a resignation or a decision to forswear bonuses and certainly a pledge to stop trying to block desperately needed financial reforms.'b'Americans come as well equipped to apologize as anybody. Five minutes on the neighborhood playground will confirm that parents still try their best to instill in their children the merits of saying \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sorry.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'True contrition is a rare thing in the American corner office, probably because when children become corporate executives they have lawyers who patiently explain how such good manners could get them in trouble in the land of legal liability. In bankers, this is compounded by a sense that they are truly doing God\xe2\x80\x99s work \xe2\x80\x94 not merely gambling with taxpayers\xe2\x80\x99 money.'b'At play here, we suspect,  are both tactics and a sense of history. Legend has it that during the reign of King Louis XVI, Marie Antoinette responded to her hungry subjects\xe2\x80\x99 demand for bread by declaring, \xe2\x80\x9cLet them eat cake.\xe2\x80\x9d In hindsight, an apology might have been a better idea. Mr. Blankfein still has his job.'b'To the Public Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9cTimes Standards, Staffers or Not\xe2\x80\x9d (Jan. 3):'b'I am struck by the hypocrisy of The Times. HIRSCHFELD'b''b'Mountain Lakes, N.J., Jan. 3, 2010'b''b'\xc2\x95'b''b'Clark Hoyt:'b' Newspapers are sustained by advertising revenue, but there is a big difference between that and a writer\xe2\x80\x99s accepting or soliciting free travel. The Times has many advertisers, none with the economic leverage to affect coverage, and the paper has strong safeguards. I\xe2\x80\x99ve asked Bill Keller, the executive editor, to comment on this and the following letter.'b'\xc2\x95'b'Your column buried the essential point made by the former Times columnist Virginia Postrel. She called the paper\xe2\x80\x99s rules about the financial involvement that freelance writers can have with other clients \xe2\x80\x9cborderline unethical\xe2\x80\x9d because The Times wants freelancers to function like staffers without the pay or benefits.'b'Publishers and other corporate media types want to profit from \xe2\x80\x9coutsourced\xe2\x80\x9d production and avoid financial responsibility for the many benefits like health care, vacations and retirement that the corporation\xe2\x80\x99s regularly employed workers have won. Then they react with horror when the \xe2\x80\x9cfreelance\xe2\x80\x9d (read \xe2\x80\x9cunderemployed\xe2\x80\x9d) worker uses whatever means available to compensate for the economic benefits they\xe2\x80\x99ve been denied by that same system of outsourcing that has proved so profitable to corporate America, and so destructive to the American worker, over the past decades.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s the real story. Don\xe2\x80\x99t bury it.'b''b'BOB SCHWARZ'b''b'Queens, Jan. 4, 2010'b''b'\xc2\x95'b''b'Bill Keller: 'b'The Times has established some of the strictest guidelines in the business to protect the independence and integrity of our news report. We want readers to know that our journalists are not beholden to, or intimidated by, anyone \xe2\x80\x94 advertisers, subjects, sources or advocates for causes.'b'Thus we keep a deliberate distance between the people who make journalism and the people who sell ads. We in the newsroom do not tell the advertising department what we are planning to publish. They, in turn, make clear to advertisers that their money buys space to sell their products and services, nothing more. We don\xe2\x80\x99t hesitate to publish unwelcome news or tough-minded analysis about companies or industries that advertise in The Times. Occasionally advertisers have withdrawn their ad dollars in response to something we have published. But we accept that as the price of doing honest journalism.'b'Writers on assignment for The Times, whether staffers or freelancers, are bound by the same ethics code. It\xe2\x80\x99s true that freelance writing is a hard way to make a living, and there\xe2\x80\x99s no question we make it harder by imposing these stringent conflict-of-interest rules. But what are the alternatives? We can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to put everyone who writes a book review or a travel article on full-time staff. If we stopped using freelancers to supplement our staff reporting we would deprive our readers of much interesting material (and deprive freelancers of both income and a prestigious outlet). And if we let freelancers take freebies from people they write about, we would compromise the integrity that people demand of The Times.'b'\xc2\x95'b'The \xe2\x80\x9chonest mistake\xe2\x80\x9d and the \xe2\x80\x9cborderline unethical\xe2\x80\x9d rules mentioned by two former Times freelance writers made me nostalgic for the old days, when there was a brighter line between right and wrong.'b'My late father, Cowl Rider, wrote many of the \xe2\x80\x9cTopics of the Times\xe2\x80\x9d for these pages from the 1940s to the early 1960s, one of which mentioned the Encyclopaedia Britannica. The E.B. offered to send, at no charge, its latest edition, in appreciation for its inclusion in \xe2\x80\x9cTopics.\xe2\x80\x9d I was thrilled at the prospect of getting free stuff by merely putting a company\xe2\x80\x99s name in an article. But it\xe2\x80\x99s not O.K. to be cool about national security when Americans are scared.'b'Our professorial president is no feckless W., biking through Katrina. But his inner certainty creates an outer disconnect.'b'He\xe2\x80\x99s so sure of himself and his actions that he fails to see that he misses the moment to be president \xe2\x80\x94 to be the strong father who protects the home from invaders, who reassures and instructs the public at traumatic moments.'b'He\xe2\x80\x99s more like the aloof father who\xe2\x80\x99s turned the Situation Room into a Seminar Room.'b'THERE may not be a person in America without a strong opinion about what coulda, shoulda been done to prevent the underwear bomber from boarding that Christmas flight to Detroit. In the years since 9/11, we\xe2\x80\x99ve all become counterterrorists.
