Fluent as we are in Al Qaeda and body scanners, when it comes to synthetic C.D.O.\xe2\x80\x99s and credit-default swaps, not so much.'b'What we don\xe2\x80\x99t know will hurt us, and quite possibly on a more devastating scale than any Qaeda attack. Americans must be told the full story of how Wall Street gamed and inflated the housing bubble, made out like bandits, and then left millions of households in ruin. Without that reckoning, there will be no public clamor for serious reform of a financial system that was as cunningly breached as airline security at the Amsterdam airport. And without reform, another massive attack on our economic security is guaranteed. Now that it can count on government bailouts, Wall Street has more incentive than ever to pump up its risks \xe2\x80\x94  secure that it can keep the bonanzas while we get stuck with the losses.'b'The window for change is rapidly closing. Health care, Afghanistan and the terrorism panic may have exhausted Washington\xe2\x80\x99s already limited capacity for heavy lifting, especially in an election year. The White House\xe2\x80\x99s chief economic hand, Lawrence Summers, has 'b'repeatedly'b' 'b'announced'b' that \xe2\x80\x9ceverybody agrees that the recession is over\xe2\x80\x9d  \xe2\x80\x94  which is technically true from an economist\xe2\x80\x99s perspective and certainly true on Wall Street, where bailed-out banks are reporting record profits and bonuses. The contrary voices of Americans who have lost pay, jobs, homes and savings are either patronized or drowned out entirely by a political system where the banking lobby rules in both parties and the revolving door between finance and government never stops spinning.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s against this backdrop that this week\xe2\x80\x99s long-awaited initial public hearings of the 'b'Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission'b' are so critical. This is the bipartisan panel that Congress 'b'mandated last spring'b' to investigate the still murky story of what happened in the meltdown. Phil Angelides, the former California treasurer who is the inquiry\xe2\x80\x99s chairman, told me in interviews late last year that he has been busy deploying a tough investigative staff and will not allow the proceedings to devolve into a typical blue-ribbon Beltway exercise in toothless bloviation.'b'He wants to examine the financial sector\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cgreed, stupidity, hubris and outright corruption\xe2\x80\x9d  \xe2\x80\x94  from traders on the ground to the board room. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s important that we deliver new information,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe can\xe2\x80\x99t just rehash what we\xe2\x80\x99ve known to date.\xe2\x80\x9d He understands that if he fails to make news or to tell the story in a way that is comprehensible and compelling enough to arouse Americans to demand action, Wall Street and Washington will both keep moving on, unchallenged and unchastened.'b'Angelides gets it. But he has a tough act to follow: Ferdinand Pecora, 'b'the legendary prosecutor'b' who served as chief counsel to the Senate committee that investigated the 1929 crash as F.D.R. took office. Pecora was a master of detail and drama. He riveted America even without the aid of television. His investigation led to indictments, jail sentences and, ultimately, key New Deal reforms  \xe2\x80\x94  the creation of the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Glass-Steagall Act, designed to prevent the formation of banks too big to fail.'b'As it happened, a major Pecora target was the chief executive of National City Bank, the institution that would grow up to be Citigroup. Among other transgressions, National City had 'b'repackaged bad Latin American debt as new securities'b' that it then sold to easily suckered investors during the frenzied 1920s boom. Once disaster struck, the bank\xe2\x80\x99s executives  helped  themselves to millions of dollars in interest-free loans. Yet their own employees had to keep ponying up salary deductions for decimated National City stock purchased at a heady precrash price.'b'Trade bad Latin American debt for bad mortgage debt, and you have a partial portrait of Citigroup at the height of the housing bubble. The reckless Citi executives of our day may not have given themselves interest-free loans, but they often walked away with the short-term, illusionary profits while their employees were left with shredded jobs and 401(k)\xe2\x80\x99s. Among those Citi executives was Robert Rubin, who, as the Clinton Treasury secretary, 'b'helped repeal the last vestiges of Glass-Steagall'b' after years of Wall Street assault. Somewhere Pecora is turning in his grave'b'Rubin has never apologized, let alone been held accountable. But he\xe2\x80\x99s hardly alone. Even after all the country has gone through, the titans who fueled the bubble are heedless. 'b'In last Sunday\xe2\x80\x99s Times'b', Sandy Weill, the former chief executive who built Citigroup (and recruited Rubin to its ranks), gave a remarkable interview to Katrina Brooker blaming his own hand-picked successor, Charles Prince, for his bank\xe2\x80\x99s implosion. Weill said he preferred to be remembered for his philanthropy. Good luck with that.'b'Among his causes is Carnegie Hall, where he is chairman of the board. To see how far American capitalism has fallen, contrast Weill with the giant who built Carnegie Hall. 'b'Not only is Andrew Carnegie remembered'b' for far more epic and generous philanthropy than Weill\xe2\x80\x99s  \xe2\x80\x94  'b'some 1,600 public libraries'b', just for starters  \xe2\x80\x94  but also for creating a steel empire that actually helped build America\xe2\x80\x99s industrial infrastructure in the late 19th century. At Citi, Weill built little more than a bloated gambling casino. As Paul Volcker, the regrettably 'b'powerless chairman of Obama\xe2\x80\x99s Economic Recovery Advisory Board'b', 'b'said recently'b', there is not \xe2\x80\x9cone shred of neutral evidence\xe2\x80\x9d that any financial innovation of the past 20 years has led to economic growth. Citi, that \xe2\x80\x9cinnovative\xe2\x80\x9d banking supermarket, destroyed far more wealth than Weill can or will ever give away.'b'Even now  \xe2\x80\x94  despite its near-death experience, despite the departures of Weill, Prince and Rubin  \xe2\x80\x94  Citi remains as imperious as it was before 9/15. Its current chairman, Richard Parsons, was one of three executives (along with Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs and John Mack of Morgan Stanley) who 'b'failed to show up at the mid-December White House meeting'b' where President Obama implored bankers to increase lending. (The trio blamed fog for forcing them to participate by speakerphone, but the weather hadn\xe2\x80\x99t grounded their peers or Amtrak.) Last week, ABC World News was also stiffed by Citi, which refused to answer questions about its latest round of outrageous credit card rate increases and instead e-mailed 'b'a statement blaming its customers'b' for \xe2\x80\x9cnot paying back their loans.\xe2\x80\x9d This from a bank that still 'b'owes taxpayers $25 billion'b' of its 'b'$45 billion  handout'b'!'b'If Citi, among the most egregious of Wall Street reprobates, feels it can get away with business as usual, it\xe2\x80\x99s because it fears no retribution. And it got more good news last week. Now that Chris Dodd is vacating the Senate, his chairmanship of the Banking Committee 'b'may fall next year to Tim Johnson of South Dakota'b', home to Citi\xe2\x80\x99s credit card operation. Johnson was the only Senate Democrat to vote against Congress\xe2\x80\x99s recent bill policing credit card abuses.'b'Though bad history shows every sign of repeating itself on Wall Street, it will take a near-miracle for Angelides to repeat Pecora\xe2\x80\x99s triumph. Our zoo of financial skullduggery is far more complex, with many more moving pieces, than that of the 1920s. The new inquiry does have subpoena power, but its entire budget, a mere $8 million, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t even match the 'b'lobbying'b' 'b'expenditures'b' for just three banks (Citi, Morgan Stanley, Bank of America) in the first nine months of 2009. The firms under scrutiny can pay for as many lawyers as they need to stall between now and Dec. 15, deadline day for the commission\xe2\x80\x99s report.'b'More daunting still is the inquiry\xe2\x80\x99s duty to reach into high places in the public sector as well as the private. The mystery of exactly what happened as TARP fell into place in the fateful fall of 2008 thickens by the day  \xe2\x80\x94  especially the behind-closed-door machinations surrounding the government rescue of A.I.G. and its counterparties. Last week, a Republican congressman, Darrell Issa of California, 'b'released e-mail'b' showing that officials at the New York Fed, then led by Timothy Geithner, pressured A.I.G. to delay disclosing to the S.E.C. and the public the details on the billions of bailout dollars it was funneling to its trading partners. In this backdoor rescue, taxpayers unknowingly awarded banks like Goldman 100 cents on the dollar for their bets on mortgage-backed securities.'b'Why was our money used to make these high-flying gamblers whole while ordinary Americans received no such beneficence? Nothing less than complete transparency will connect the dots. Among 'b'the big-name witnesses that the Angelides commission'b' has called for next week is Goldman\xe2\x80\x99s Blankfein. Geithner, Henry Paulson and Ben Bernanke should be next.'b'If they all skate away yet again by deflecting blame or mouthing pro forma mea culpas, it will be a sign that this inquiry, like so many other promises of reform since 9/15, is likely to leave Wall Street\xe2\x80\x99s status quo largely intact. That\xe2\x80\x99s the ticking-bomb scenario that truly imperils us all.'b'Hong Kong'b'C. H. Tung, the first Chinese-appointed chief executive of Hong Kong after the handover in 1997, offered me a three-sentence summary the other day of China\xe2\x80\x99s modern economic history: \xe2\x80\x9cChina was asleep during the Industrial Revolution. She was just waking during the Information Technology Revolution. She intends to participate fully in the Green Revolution.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ll say. Being in China right now I am more convinced than ever that when historians look back at the end of the first decade of the 21st century, they will say that the most important thing to happen was not the Great Recession, but China\xe2\x80\x99s Green Leap Forward. The Beijing leadership clearly understands that the E.T.  \xe2\x80\x94  Energy Technology  \xe2\x80\x94  revolution is both a necessity and an opportunity, and they do not intend to miss it.'b'We, by contrast, intend to fix Afghanistan. Have a nice day.'b'O.K., that was a cheap shot. But here\xe2\x80\x99s one that isn\xe2\x80\x99t: Andy Grove, co-founder of Intel, liked to say that companies come to \xe2\x80\x9cstrategic inflection points,\xe2\x80\x9d where the fundamentals of a business change and they either make the hard decision to invest in a down cycle and take a more promising trajectory or do nothing and wither. The same is true for countries.'b'The U.S. is at just such a strategic inflection point. We are either going to put in place a price on carbon and the right regulatory incentives to ensure that America is China\xe2\x80\x99s main competitor/partner in the E.T. revolution, or we are going to gradually cede this industry to Beijing and the good jobs and energy security that would go with it.'b'Is President Obama going to finish health care and then put aside the pending energy legislation  \xe2\x80\x94  and carbon pricing  \xe2\x80\x94  that Congress has already passed in order to get through the midterms without Republicans screaming \xe2\x80\x9cnew taxes?\xe2\x80\x9d Or is he going to seize this moment before the midterms  \xe2\x80\x94  possibly his last window to put together a majority in the Senate, including some Republicans, for a price on carbon  \xe2\x80\x94  and put in place a real U.S. engine for clean energy innovation and energy security?'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve been stunned to learn about the sheer volume of wind, solar, mass transit, nuclear and more efficient coal-burning projects that have sprouted in China in just the last year.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s e-mail from Bill Gross, who runs eSolar, a promising California solar-thermal start-up: On Saturday, in Beijing, said Gross, he announced \xe2\x80\x9cthe biggest solar-thermal deal ever. It\xe2\x80\x99s a 2 gigawatt, $5 billion deal to build plants in China using our California-based technology. China is being even more aggressive than the U.S. We applied for a [U.S. Department of Energy] loan for a 92 megawatt project in New Mexico, and in less time than it took them to do stage 1 of the application review, China signs, approves, and is ready to begin construction this year on a 20 times bigger project!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Yes, climate change is a concern for Beijing, but more immediately China\xe2\x80\x99s leaders know that their country is in the midst of the biggest migration of people from the countryside to urban centers in the history of mankind. This is creating a surge in energy demand, which China is determined to meet with cleaner, homegrown sources so that its future economy will be less vulnerable to supply shocks and so it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t pollute itself to death.'b'In the last year alone, so many new solar panel makers emerged in China that the price of solar power has fallen from roughly 59 cents a kilowatt hour to 16 cents, according to The Times\xe2\x80\x99s bureau chief here, Keith Bradsher. Meanwhile, China last week tested the fastest bullet train in the world  \xe2\x80\x94  217 miles per hour  \xe2\x80\x94  from Wuhan to Guangzhou. As Bradsher noted, China \xe2\x80\x9chas nearly finished the construction of a high-speed rail route from Beijing to Shanghai at a cost of $23.5 billion. Trains will cover the 700-mile route in just five hours, compared with 12 hours today. By comparison, Amtrak trains require at least 18 hours to travel a similar distance from New York to Chicago.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'China is also engaged in the world\xe2\x80\x99s most rapid expansion of nuclear power. It is expected to build some 50 new nuclear reactors by 2020; the rest of the world combined might build 15.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cBy the end of this decade, China will be dominating global production of the whole range of power equipment,\xe2\x80\x9d said Andrew Brandler, the C.E.O. of the CLP Group, Hong Kong\xe2\x80\x99s largest power utility.'b'In the process, China is going to make clean power technologies cheaper for itself and everyone else. But even Chinese experts will tell you that it will all happen faster and more effectively if China and America work together  \xe2\x80\x94  with the U.S. specializing in energy research and innovation, at which China is still weak, as well as in venture investing and servicing of new clean technologies, and with China specializing in mass production.'b'This is a strategic inflection point. It is clear that if we, America, care about our energy security, economic strength and environmental quality we need to put in place a long-term carbon price that stimulates and rewards clean power innovation. We can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to be asleep with an invigorated China wide awake.'b'Religions derive their power and popularity in part from the ethical compass they offer. So why do so many faiths help perpetuate something that most of us regard as profoundly unethical: the oppression of women?'b'It is not that warlords in Congo cite Scripture to justify their mass rapes (although the last warlord I met there called himself a pastor and wore a button reading \xe2\x80\x9crebels for Christ\xe2\x80\x9d). It\xe2\x80\x99s not that brides are burned in India as part of a Hindu ritual. And there\xe2\x80\x99s no verse in the Koran that instructs Afghan thugs to throw acid in the faces of girls who dare to go to school.'b'Yet these kinds of abuses  \xe2\x80\x94 along with more banal injustices, like slapping a girlfriend or paying women less for their work  \xe2\x80\x94 arise out of a social context in which women are, often, second-class citizens. That\xe2\x80\x99s a context that religions have helped shape, and not pushed hard to change.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWomen are prevented from playing a full and equal role in many faiths, creating an environment in which violations against women are justified,\xe2\x80\x9d former President Jimmy Carter noted 'b'in a speech last month'b' to the Parliament of the World\xe2\x80\x99s Religions in Australia.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe belief that women are inferior human beings in the eyes of God,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Carter continued, \xe2\x80\x9cgives excuses to the brutal husband who beats his wife, the soldier who rapes a woman, the employer who has a lower pay scale for women employees, or parents who decide to abort a female embryo.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Mr. Carter, who sees religion as one of the \xe2\x80\x9cbasic causes of the violation of women\xe2\x80\x99s rights,\xe2\x80\x9d is a member of The Elders, a small council of retired leaders brought together by Nelson Mandela. 'b'The Elders'b' are focusing on the role of religion in oppressing women, and they have issued a joint statement calling on religious leaders to \xe2\x80\x9cchange all discriminatory practices within their own religions and traditions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Elders are neither irreligious nor rabble-rousers. They include Archbishop Desmond Tutu, and they begin their meetings with a moment for silent prayer.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Elders are not attacking religion as such,\xe2\x80\x9d noted Mary Robinson, the former president of Ireland and United Nations high commissioner for human rights. But she added, \xe2\x80\x9cWe all recognized that if there\xe2\x80\x99s one overarching issue for women it\xe2\x80\x99s the way that religion can be manipulated to subjugate women.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There is of course plenty of fodder, in both the Koran and the Bible, for those who seek a theology of discrimination.'b'The New Testament quotes St. Paul (I Timothy 2) as saying that women \xe2\x80\x9cmust be silent.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'Deuteronomy'b' declares that if a woman does not bleed on her wedding night, \xe2\x80\x9cthe men of her town shall stone her to death.\xe2\x80\x9d An Orthodox Jewish prayer thanks God, \xe2\x80\x9cwho hast not made me a woman.\xe2\x80\x9d The Koran stipulates that a woman shall inherit less than a man, and that a woman\xe2\x80\x99s testimony counts for half a man\xe2\x80\x99s.'b'In fairness, many scholars believe that Paul did not in fact write the passages calling on women to be silent. And Islam started out as socially progressive for women  \xe2\x80\x94 banning female infanticide and limiting polygamy  \xe2\x80\x94 but did not continue to advance.'b'But religious leaders sanctified existing social structures, instead of pushing for justice. In Africa, it would help enormously if religious figures spoke up for widows disenfranchised by unjust inheritance traditions  \xe2\x80\x94 or for rape victims, or for schoolgirls facing sexual demands from their teachers. Instead, in Uganda, the influence of conservative Christians is found in a grotesque push to execute gays.'b'Yet paradoxically, the churches in Africa that have done the most to empower women have been conservative ones led by evangelicals and especially Pentecostals. In particular, Pentecostals encourage women to take leadership roles, and for many women this is the first time they have been trusted with authority and found their opinions respected. In rural Africa, Pentecostal churches are becoming a significant force to emancipate women.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s a glimmer of hope that reminds us that while religion is part of the problem, it can also be part of the solution. The Dalai Lama has taken that step and calls himself a feminist.'b'Another excellent precedent is slavery. Each of the Abrahamic faiths accepted slavery. Muhammad owned slaves, and St. Paul seems to have condoned slavery. Yet the pioneers of the abolitionist movement were Quakers and evangelicals like William Wilberforce. People of faith ultimately worked ferociously to overthrow an oppressive institution that churches had previously condoned.'b'Today, when religious institutions exclude women from their hierarchies and rituals, the inevitable implication is that females are inferior. The Elders are right that religious groups should stand up for a simple ethical principle: any person\xe2\x80\x99s human rights should be sacred, and not depend on something as earthly as their genitals.'b'Arlington, Va.'b'AS I reflect on disturbing events of recent weeks \xe2\x80\x94 'b'the massacre of seven C.I.A. officers'b' in Khost, Afghanistan, and the near bombing of Northwest Flight 253 on its way to Detroit \xe2\x80\x94 I can see in my mind\xe2\x80\x99s eye a young man. He is Middle Eastern, with a thin, mustachioed face and pallid skin, and he stands nervously in the middle of a very public square, unnoticed amid a swirling crowd. Glancing furtively at his watch, he begins to walk, as he was instructed, along a prescribed route.'b'Another young man, an American who is a C.I.A. case officer, has already circled the square, shielded by the passers-by. He is alert to anything out of place, to someone loitering near a motorcycle, to a group of men sitting aimlessly in a car, to anyone who may be paying attention to his source. He is dressed to look like any other dark-haired male of no particular account in this dusty and obscure third-world city in the 1980s. Under the officer\xe2\x80\x99s sweater is a crude bulletproof vest, giving him the barrel-chested look of a wrestler. The vest is of limited protection, but a partial insurance against faults of judgment.'b'The case officer begins to follow his source at a discreet distance. He knows the young man well, or believes he does. His assessment, upon which his life may depend, is that the source, though a member of a terrorist organization and willing to put his life at risk to meet an American spy, is a physical coward. Personal loyalty is important to him, as is his relationship with the American, from which he hopes to benefit.'b'Circumstances can change, however, and with them, motivations. In a world of fear and desperation, today\xe2\x80\x99s friend can become tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s deadly enemy. The case officer is confident that while the source could perhaps find the opportunity to shoot him, he lacks the courage ever to do it himself. While this lack of fortitude may be a blessing, it could easily lead him, if discovered and placed under pressure, to guide others to their American target, to do what he himself could not.'b'Satisfied at length that no one is watching the source, the case officer suddenly approaches him from behind, grabs him by the elbow and pulls him abruptly down a cobblestone alley, in a direction the source could not have anticipated.'b'In this case, the officer\xe2\x80\x99s faith is rewarded. The Middle Easterner becomes a valuable asset. But the case officer is not always so fortunate. A year later, in a different city, he has just inherited a new source. Working against the government of a state sponsor of terrorism, the source is what is referred to in the business as a \xe2\x80\x9cprincipal agent,\xe2\x80\x9d running his own network of subordinate spies. With the case officer\xe2\x80\x99s encouragement, the principal agent has managed to lure a potential subagent \xe2\x80\x94 a childhood friend he considers closer than a brother \xe2\x80\x94 out from the police state where he lives. They hold a series of meetings during which the principal agent vets his friend, assesses him and formally recruits him into the network, all under the watchful guidance of the case officer.'b'As I look back at that young case officer poised at that moment in time, I wish I could speak with him now. I wish I could remind him that his own confidence, his ambition and his desire for success are in fact his worst enemies.'b'Some of the story concerning that principal agent we will never know. We will never know precisely why one day, in setting up another meeting with his old friend, he ignored his training. He had been told \xe2\x80\x94 hadn\xe2\x80\x99t he? \xe2\x80\x94 that he must never allow himself to fall into a pattern, that he must never be predictable. And his case officer, in spite of endless soul-searching, would never know whether any of the myriad things he might have done differently would have saved a brave man whom he had sworn to protect.'b'What we do know is that one evening, the principal agent and his boyhood pal, now his betrayer, had dinner at a shabby seaside restaurant; that they sat at the same table they had occupied the night before; that a group of four men in a car drove slowly around the block twice; that two of the men entered the restaurant and strolled over in front of the principal agent\xe2\x80\x99s table; that each then emptied his pistol into the agent\xe2\x80\x99s chest.'b'In the wake of President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s 'b' speech on intelligence last week'b', there is much soul-searching going on, at C.I.A. headquarters in Langley and elsewhere, about what happened in Khost on Dec. 30. We are told that a Jordanian-born informant betrayed his spymasters and ignited a suicide bomb at a military base, killing those seven C.I.A. employees and wounding at least six more in the greatest blow to American intelligence in two decades. It comes as a cold slap in the face, but one that implicates us all. For these men and women, like the uniformed troops they serve alongside, have assumed great risks, and they have assumed them to keep the rest of us safe at home.'b'As the wildly divergent news accounts attest, none of us on the outside knows what really happened. But this hasn\xe2\x80\x99t stopped the armchair geniuses who dispense grave platitudes on the enormity of the mistakes made, or the \xe2\x80\x9cformer officials\xe2\x80\x9d who preen for reporters, spouting revelations regarding international intelligence relationships that, if true, are best not spoken of at all.'b'There may well have been some element of human error or incaution. Young operatives might have allowed their desire to strike a blow against America\xe2\x80\x99s enemies to override their professional caution. (As perhaps I did myself so many years ago.) Or, perhaps, having weighed the risks and gains of the alternatives, the officers simply came up short. In the wilderness of mirrors that defines human intelligence in counterterrorism, the threat of disaster is an inescapable presence.'b'But for the grace of God, my colleagues and I could have come up similarly short on any number of occasions  in Pakistan and Afghanistan during the run-up to 9/11 and the resulting American-led invasion. Brave young men and women met in wild and obscure places with dubious characters; had they not done so, we would not have had the human information network that was vital in routing Al Qaeda and the Taliban so quickly in 2001.   Some flew on helicopters deep into Taliban-controlled areas to meet with tribal leaders whom we felt we could trust, but whose followers might have had the means and motivation to murder my colleagues. We fully expected to lose many of our people in those days. That our losses were light in the end was a testament to their courage, their professionalism and, yes, their luck.'b'The importance of the human intelligence work done by officers like those we lost at Khost is only increasing over time. The growing sophistication of our enemies, as they react to the grievous losses they have suffered, makes us all the more reliant on human spies.'b'To outsiders, the counterterrorism struggle along the Pakistani-Afghan border can seem antiseptic \xe2\x80\x94 a war of drones, of terrorists who simply disappear in a puff of smoke. But make no mistake: the intelligence-led struggle fought in our name is, at its core, every bit as gritty and as visceral as conventional combat. But in this war, you come to know your enemies as well as your friends, and the battlefield encompasses the full scope of human character.'b'Trainees who aspire to join the National Clandestine Service, the undercover arm of the C.I.A., get careful instruction. They are instilled with a proper regard for their mission, for the laws they must follow, for the sacred obligation to sources, and for their duty to one another. Much stress is placed on loyalty. Loyalty can take many forms, but when all is said and done, loyalty is essentially tribal. That is as true for us as it is for any Afghan. C.I.A. officers undertake risks not for any ideology, but to protect Americans from those who would want only kill them. At a time when calamity is a poignant reminder of the loyalty displayed by C.I.A. officers toward us, we might reflect on what we owe them in return.'b'Yet over the past two weeks, we have watched the unedifying spectacle of politicians and bureaucrats, mired in a Washington environment defined by political fear, posturing shamelessly over the would-be airline bomber. A wealthy nation that refuses to invest sufficiently in available technology, or to put up with travel delays necessary to see whether passengers are carrying explosives onto airplanes, chooses instead to excoriate the intelligence community for failing to see unerringly into the minds and hearts of men.'b'Rather than admit to the hard fact that we must always rely on someone\xe2\x80\x99s subjective assessment of tolerable risk, politicians are vilifying those who put together our terrorism watch lists, who are simply following threat protocols. Meanwhile, intelligence analysts who are charged with making subjective judgments as to which of the hundreds of thousands of possible terrorists lurking in their databases merit their focused scrutiny to \xe2\x80\x9cconnect the dots\xe2\x80\x9d are being accused of dereliction for having underestimated the threat from a single African college student.'b'Sacrificing intelligence operatives out of political expediency is a bipartisan sport. Officials in the George W. Bush administration did not hesitate to blame the spies when it suited them \xe2\x80\x94 as though the decision to invade Iraq really depended on intelligence \xe2\x80\x94 and the Obama administration is proving, if anything, worse. Last spring\xe2\x80\x99s decision to release secret Justice Department memos on the interrogations of suspected terrorists was a blatantly partisan act. It was designed to win political advantage by holding intelligence officers \xe2\x80\x94 whose offense was to follow faithfully their lawful orders \xe2\x80\x94 up to opprobrium and scorn. Members of Congress who had enthusiastically encouraged aggressive interrogations in the wake of 9/11 suddenly suffered amnesia when the political zeitgeist shifted.'b'This is a curious way to reward those who risk everything to defend us. How, in the face of such betrayal, can we expect to bring new generations  into the intelligence ranks? It is possible to reward loyalty with loyalty while still insisting on the highest standards of professionalism from our intelligence officers. Indeed, we can better reinforce excellence in intelligence when we judge it with honesty, realism and a sense of proportion. Politicians will behave dishonorably so long as it benefits them. It is up to the rest of us to tell them, \xe2\x80\x9cEnough.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Living on Nothing but Food Stamps'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cThe Safety Net\xe2\x80\x9d series, front page, Jan. 3):'b'Economic hard times have thrown more men, white people and two-parent households into poverty. Before this, most people saw government benefits as the sole province of poor and demonized women on welfare, lazy welfare queens who had kids for money and cheated the government. But the pejorative comments have more or less died down.'b'Instead, service agencies and local officials welcome the newcomers while family and friends thank (once-maligned) government programs for saving the day.'b'As the nation discovers that people fall into poverty because of economic forces beyond their control, there seems to be more sympathy and understanding to go around. Let\xe2\x80\x99s hope this generosity of spirit outlasts the current downturn and spreads from the new poor to all the poor \xe2\x80\x94 especially since middle-class families and major corporations also take government benefits that cost taxpayers plenty but don\xe2\x80\x99t think of themselves as on the dole.'b'Mimi Abramovitz'b'\n New York, Jan. 6, 2010'b''b''b'The writer, a professor of social policy at Hunter College School of Social Work and the Graduate Center, City University of New York, is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cRegulating the Lives of Women: Social Welfare Policy From Colonial Times to the Present.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'Your article highlights the stark contrast between the effectiveness of food stamps and the weakness of other safety-net programs.'b'You report that in Florida last June, 192,000 families with children received food stamps and had no other income. According to state data, in that same month, only 56,000 families received cash assistance from the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families program. This means that for every family that received cash assistance, more than three families who were eligible for help did not.'b'Across the country, TANF programs are simply not responding adequately to the recession. The TANF block grant is due for reauthorization this year, and Congress must take timely action to extend the program with a renewed focus on poverty alleviation and preventing material hardship among children and families, especially those who are particularly vulnerable because of circumstances like disability, domestic violence or homelessness.'b'Congress should also extend the additional TANF financing provided under the recovery law, which will otherwise expire in September, so that state budget cuts do not cause even further hardship among these very poor families.'b'Elizabeth Lower-Basch'b'\n Washington, Jan. \n 4, 2010'b''b''b'The writer is a senior policy analyst at  the Center for Law and Social Policy.'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'You report that the main welfare program, Temporary Assistance for Needy Families, \xe2\x80\x9chas scarcely expanded during the recession.\xe2\x80\x9d But you did not mention certain details about some of the potential reasons for that lack of expansion.'b'As a state employee (now retired), I was an administrative hearing officer during Illinois\xe2\x80\x99s implementation of TANF in 1997. As a replacement for the prior federal welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, TANF imposed stricter requirements and longer waiting periods on applicants before qualifying for cash assistance.'b'While many middle-class people would applaud the idea of mandating that applicants/recipients attend several appointments during the process to determine or redetermine their eligibility, many destitute people simply do not have the carfare, gas money or reliable child care to comply.'b'Such people may have their applications denied or cases canceled as a result of missing such appointments if they are unable to prove \xe2\x80\x9cgood cause.\xe2\x80\x9d Others might not comply because of untreated depression.'b'Moreover, with some exceptions, TANF recipients face a five-year lifetime limit on cash benefits. Knowing this may lead some people who may already have received benefits during a prior period before the current recession hit to try to get by on no income for as long as possible so as not to exhaust the remaining time left during which they might qualify for benefits.'b'Amy Laiken'b'\n Chicago, Jan. 3, 2010'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'Public assistance like food stamps and welfare does not create dependency. It cripples people because it is inadequate, inaccessible and degrading. It forces people to wait too long for help and then gives them far less than they need to survive.'b'By the time they have received aid for even one year, they have borrowed from family, friends and high-interest, under-the-table lenders; sold off every asset they own, including most clothing; endured the frequent loss of phone, utilities, housing and transportation; and lost their self-esteem.'b'Why is a person worthy of help until the day he or she exhausts unemployment benefits, but the day after, when public assistance becomes necessary, folks like Representative John Linder of Georgia, quoted in your article, seem to view them as too lazy to work?'b'Joni Halpern'b'\n San Diego, Jan. \n 3, 2010'b''b'A federal judge in Washington, Ricardo Urbina, has provided another compelling argument against the outsourcing of war to gunslingers from the private sector. In throwing out charges against Blackwater agents who killed 17 Iraqis in Baghdad\xe2\x80\x99s Nisour Square in September 2007, Judge Urbina highlighted the government\xe2\x80\x99s inability to hold mercenaries accountable for crimes they commit.'b'Judge Urbina correctly ruled that the government violated the Blackwater agents\xe2\x80\x99 protection against self-incrimination. He sketched an inept prosecution that relied on compelled statements made by the agents to officials of the State Department, who employed the North Carolina security firm to protect convoys and staff in Iraq. That, he said, amounted to a \xe2\x80\x9creckless violation of the defendants\xe2\x80\x99 constitutional rights.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'During the presidential campaign, Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton competed over who would take the toughest line against mercenaries. It is clear that the only way for President Obama to make good on the rhetoric is to get rid of the thousands of private gunmen still deployed in Iraq, Afghanistan and elsewhere.'b'The killings in Nisour Square were hardly the first misdeeds by hired guns in Iraq, or the last. The army has said contractors from firms like CACI International Inc. were involved in more than a third of the proven incidents of abuse in 2003 and 2004 in the Abu Ghraib prison. Guards from Blackwater \xe2\x80\x94 which has renamed itself Xe Services \xe2\x80\x94 and other security firms, like Triple Canopy, have been involved in other wanton shootings.'b'On Jan. 7, two former Blackwater guards were arrested on murder charges stemming from a shooting in Afghanistan last May that left two Afghans dead.'b'Still, the government has failed to hold armed contractors accountable. When its formal occupation of Iraq ended in 2004, the Bush administration demanded that Baghdad grant legal immunity to private contractors.'b'Congress has tried to cover such crimes with American law. The Military Extraterritorial Jurisdiction Act extends civilian law to contractors supporting military operations overseas, and the Uniform  Code of Military Justice was broadened in 2006 to cover contractors.'b'But the government has not prosecuted a single successful case for killings by armed contractors overseas. An Iraqi lawsuit against American military contractors by Iraqi victims of torture at Abu Ghraib was dismissed by a federal appeals court that said the companies had immunity as government contractors.'b'Furious that the Nisour Square case was dismissed, the Iraqi government said it might file civil suits in the United States and Iraq against Xe. But its chances of success are not considered great. The families of many of the victims of the rampage accepted a settlement from Xe last week, worried that had they pursued their civil suit they might have gotten nothing.'b'There are many reasons to oppose the privatization of war. Reliance on contractors allows the government to work under the radar of public scrutiny. And freewheeling contractors can be at cross purposes with the armed forces. Blackwater\xe2\x80\x99s undersupervised guards undermined the effort to win Iraqi support.'b'But most fundamental is that the government cannot \xe2\x80\x94 or will not \xe2\x80\x94 keep a legal handle on its freelance gunmen. A nation of laws cannot go to war like that.'b'Just last June, the Supreme Court decided that when prosecutors rely on lab reports they must call the experts who prepared them to testify. It was an important ruling, based on a defendant\xe2\x80\x99s right to be confronted with witnesses against him, but the court is about to revisit it. The justices should reaffirm that the Sixth Amendment requires prosecutors to call the lab analysts whose work they rely on.'b'On Monday, the court hears arguments in Briscoe v. Virginia, in which a man was convicted on drug charges. The prosecutors relied on certificates prepared by forensic analysts to prove that the substance seized was cocaine. They did not call the analysts as witnesses.'b'The defendant should be able to get his conviction overturned based on Melendez-Diaz v. Massachusetts, the ruling from last June, which held, by a 5-to-4 vote, that using lab reports without calling the analysts violates the Sixth Amendment.'b'The amendment\xe2\x80\x99s confrontation clause guarantees defendants the right to see prosecution witnesses in person and to cross-examine them, unless they are truly unavailable. In cases that involve drugs, and many that do not, lab analysts\xe2\x80\x99 work can be a critical part of the prosecution\xe2\x80\x99s case. If the prosecutors want to use the reports, they should be required to call the analysts as witnesses.'b'Critics of the ruling last June argue that it imposes too great a burden and excessive costs on prosecutors. But in states where analysts have to testify, the burden is easily manageable. Ohio\xe2\x80\x99s 14 forensic scientists appeared in 123 drug cases in 2008, less than one appearance each per month.'b'It is not clear why the Supreme Court is rushing to reconsider this issue. There are some differences in the rules on witnesses between Virginia and Massachusetts. But it may be that with Justice Sonia Sotomayor having replaced Justice David Souter, the dissenters believe they have a fifth vote to erode or undo last June\xe2\x80\x99s ruling.'b'As a former assistant district attorney, some court analysts argue, she may be more sympathetic to the burden on prosecutors. As a circuit court judge, Justice Sotomayor did often rule for the government in criminal cases, but making predictions of this sort is perilous. Justice Antonin Scalia, one of the court\xe2\x80\x99s most conservative members, wrote the majority opinion in Melendez-Diaz.'b'If the court changes the rule, it would be a significant setback for civil liberties, and not just in cases involving lab evidence. Prosecutors might use the decision to justify offering all sorts of affidavits, videotaped statements and other evidence from absent witnesses.'b'Charter schools \xe2\x80\x94 which are run with public money but subject to fewer state regulations \xe2\x80\x94 have a lot of  supporters  in Washington. Education Secretary Arne Duncan wants states to close some chronically failing schools and turn them into charters. Congress is so enthusiastic that it has created a $50 million fund and given Mr. Duncan the authority to directly finance charter school operators who want to replicate or expand successful programs.'b'Proponents  initially  argued that charter schools could  provide a better education  because they were allowed to operate independently. But  the  research has turned up mixed results. To ensure that this new money goes only to operators with proven records of success, Mr. Duncan will need to be guided by well-designed studies like the one being carried out by Stanford University\xe2\x80\x99s Center for Research on Education Outcomes.'b'The center startled many education specialists last summer with a report that showed that a large number of charter schools are failing to deliver on their promises. It compared the performance of charter schools and traditional schools in 15 states and the District of Columbia and found that only about 17 percent of charters offered students a better education than traditional schools \xe2\x80\x94 and that 37 percent were worse.'b'A 'b'new study'b' from the center has turned up a brighter picture in New York City, where students at more than half of the charter schools are showing more academic improvement in math than their  traditional-school counterparts. The reading numbers were not as strong, but still nearly 30 percent of charters outperformed traditional schools.'b'The Stanford study does not explain why charter schools in New York City are outperforming charters elsewhere. But some ideas spring readily to mind.'b'New York City has a rigorous mechanism for licensing charters as well as strong oversight of performance. The city also gives charter operators free space, and provides them with administrative support so that they can more easily get up and running and comply with state and federal education law. This environment has been a magnet for strong operators that have been treated almost like pariahs in other states.'b'Critics have often charged that charter schools look better academically because they skim off the most talented students from neighboring traditional schools. The Stanford study rules out this explanation by carefully controlling for all known variables, including race, gender, ethnicity and achievement level.'b'The success of high-quality charter schools in places like New York supports Mr. Duncan\xe2\x80\x99s view that charters can play an important role in efforts to reform the country\xe2\x80\x99s flawed education system \xe2\x80\x94 but only if they are closely monitored and held to high standards.'b'Anyone who\xe2\x80\x99s spent time in Youngstown, Ohio, is entitled to nagging affection for the gritty old steeltown that has long struggled with lost jobs and serial political corruption. Bruce Springsteen lyricized its fate: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sinkin\xe2\x80\x99 down here Darlin\xe2\x80\x99 in Youngstown.\xe2\x80\x9d There\xe2\x80\x99s a touch of fresh hope at word that a collective yawn is greeting the return of former Representative James Traficant, who is on the streets vowing a political comeback after a seven-year prison stretch.'b'The politician once beloved as Jimbo is loudly threatening to run again for Congress and working his old shtick about government victimizing the little people. Trusted civic leaders \xe2\x80\x94 people who fight endlessly for reform \xe2\x80\x94 estimate Mr. Traficant\xe2\x80\x99s standing to be at best as a talk-radio grievance peddler, not as a resurrected politician capable of catching on, as he is trying to do, with the new tea-party theatrics.'b'Across nine Congressional terms Mr. Traficant became a cherished folk hero with his eagle\xe2\x80\x99s aerie of a toupee and House rants (\xe2\x80\x9cBeam me up, Scotty!\xe2\x80\x9d). Flamboyance didn\xe2\x80\x99t work in court. Despite strutting thunderously as his own defense counsel, he was convicted on 10 counts of official corruption and staff shakedowns.'b'Mr. Traficant was spellbinding in the courtroom \xe2\x80\x94 a self-absorbed bully, a tragic clown vowing vengeance as he was led off. You had to hope there was no second act for  a politician like him.'b'If there isn\xe2\x80\x99t, something is right in Youngstown. Political corruption is still bone-deep; another former judge pleaded guilty the other day to fraud charges. But the city by the Mahoning may have wised up enough to resist Traficant Redux.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Hate Begets Hate'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (editorial, Jan. 5):'b'You rightly call for \xe2\x80\x9cthe United States and others\xe2\x80\x9d to send a clear message to Uganda that passing the Anti-Homosexuality Bill would cost it \xe2\x80\x9cmillions of dollars in foreign aid.\xe2\x80\x9d It is best to use that pressure soon, however, because it isn\xe2\x80\x99t going to be available for much longer.'b'For decades, Uganda\xe2\x80\x99s president, Yoweri Museveni, has charmed donors while overseeing an increasingly centralized and corrupt regime. Marcus'b'\n New York, Jan. 5, 2010'b''b''b'The writer was a teacher for 30 years.'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'Carolyn Bucior describes an all too familiar dilemma confronting school districts on a daily basis when attempting to find well-qualified substitute teachers. To help resolve this problem, many school districts have formed partnerships with teacher training institutions, which provide teaching interns who are available to serve as substitutes in the schools for a year.'b'The interns are generally graduate students seeking to become certified teachers who are paid a small stipend of approximately $60 for each school day, which is used to help defray tuition expenses.'b'The interns become an integral part of the professional staff and do not require daily orientation, as is the case with most substitute teachers. The interns have an opportunity to observe and work with a variety of teachers who have different teaching styles and philosophies. Likewise, their exposure to a variety of students serves as a strong foundation for their own teaching once they have completed their certification requirements. Many schools find that these interns serve as a pool for hiring future teachers.'b'Needless to say, the hiring of teaching interns is a win-win situation for both the schools as well as the teacher training institutions.'b'Joseph A. 'b''b'As health care reform nears the finish line, there is much wailing and rending of garments among conservatives. And I\xe2\x80\x99m not just talking about the tea partiers. Even calmer conservatives have been issuing dire warnings that Obamacare will turn America into a European-style social democracy. And everyone knows that Europe has lost all its economic dynamism.'b'Strange to say, however, what everyone knows isn\xe2\x80\x99t true. Europe has its economic troubles; who doesn\xe2\x80\x99t? But the story you hear all the time \xe2\x80\x94 of a stagnant economy in which high taxes and generous social benefits have undermined incentives, stalling growth and innovation \xe2\x80\x94 bears little resemblance to the surprisingly positive facts. The real lesson from Europe is actually the opposite of what conservatives claim: Europe is an economic success, and that success shows that social democracy works.'b'Actually, Europe\xe2\x80\x99s economic success should be obvious even without statistics. For those Americans who have visited Paris: did it look poor and backward? What about Frankfurt or London? You should always bear in mind that when the question is which to believe \xe2\x80\x94 official economic statistics or your own lying eyes \xe2\x80\x94 the eyes have it.'b'In any case, the statistics confirm what the eyes see.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s true that the U.S. economy has grown faster than that of Europe for the past generation. Since 1980 \xe2\x80\x94 when our politics took a sharp turn to the right, while Europe\xe2\x80\x99s didn\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x94 America\xe2\x80\x99s real G.D.P. has grown, on average, 3 percent per year. America rules!'b'Or maybe not. All this really says is that we\xe2\x80\x99ve had faster population growth. Since 1980, per capita real G.D.P. \xe2\x80\x94 which is what matters for living standards \xe2\x80\x94 has risen at about the same rate in America and in the E.U. 15: 1.95 percent a year here; 1.83 percent there.'b'What about technology? In the late 1990s you could argue that the revolution in information technology was passing Europe by. But Europe has since caught up in many ways. Broadband, in particular, is just about as widespread in Europe as it is in the United States, and it\xe2\x80\x99s much faster and cheaper.'b'And what about jobs? Here America arguably does better: European unemployment rates are usually substantially higher than the rate here, and the employed fraction of the population lower. But if your vision is of millions of prime-working-age adults sitting idle, living on the dole, think again. In 2008, 80 percent of adults aged 25 to 54 in the E.U. 15 were employed (and 83 percent in France). That\xe2\x80\x99s about the same as in the United States. Europeans are less likely than we are to work when young or old, but is that entirely a bad thing?'b'And Europeans are quite productive, too: they work fewer hours, but output per hour in France and Germany is close to U.S. levels.'b'The point isn\xe2\x80\x99t that Europe is utopia. Like the United States, it\xe2\x80\x99s having trouble grappling with the current financial crisis. Like the United States, Europe\xe2\x80\x99s big nations face serious long-run fiscal issues \xe2\x80\x94 and like some individual U.S. states, some European countries are teetering on the edge of fiscal crisis. (Sacramento is now the Athens of America \xe2\x80\x94 in a bad way.) But taking the longer view, the European economy works; it grows; it\xe2\x80\x99s as dynamic, all in all, as our own.'b'So why do we get such a different picture from many pundits? Because according to the prevailing economic dogma in this country \xe2\x80\x94 and I\xe2\x80\x99m talking here about many Democrats as well as essentially all Republicans \xe2\x80\x94 European-style social democracy should be an utter disaster. And people tend to see what they want to see.'b'After all, while reports of Europe\xe2\x80\x99s economic demise are greatly exaggerated, reports of its high taxes and generous benefits aren\xe2\x80\x99t. Taxes in major European nations range from 36 to 44 percent of G.D.P., compared with 28 in the United States. Universal health care is, well, universal. Social expenditure is vastly higher than it is here.'b'So if there were anything to the economic assumptions that dominate U.S. public discussion \xe2\x80\x94 above all, the belief that even modestly higher taxes on the rich and benefits for the less well off would drastically undermine incentives to work, invest and innovate \xe2\x80\x94 Europe would be the stagnant, decaying economy of legend. But it isn\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'Europe is often held up as a cautionary tale, a demonstration that if you try to make the economy less brutal, to take better care of your fellow citizens when they\xe2\x80\x99re down on their luck, you end up killing economic progress. But what European experience actually demonstrates is the opposite: social justice and progress can go hand in hand.'b'Liberal democracy offers religious believers a bargain. Accept, as a price of citizenship, that you may never impose your convictions on your neighbor, or use state power to compel belief. In return, you will be free to practice your own faith as you see fit  \xe2\x80\x94  and free, as well, to compete with other believers (and nonbelievers) in the marketplace of ideas.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s the theory. In practice, the admirable principle that nobody should be persecuted for their beliefs often blurs into the more illiberal idea that nobody should ever publicly criticize another religion. Or say anything whatsoever about religion, outside the privacy of  church, synagogue or home.'b'A week ago, Brit Hume broke all three rules at once. The tendency to take offense at freewheeling religious debate is widespread. There are American Catholics who cry \xe2\x80\x9cbigotry\xe2\x80\x9d every time a newspaper columnist criticizes the church\xe2\x80\x99s teaching on sexuality. For many people \xe2\x80\x94 Woods perhaps included \xe2\x80\x94 the fact that Buddhism promotes an ethical life without recourse to Christian concepts like the Fall of Man, divine judgment and damnation is precisely what makes it so appealing. The knee-jerk outrage that greeted Hume\xe2\x80\x99s remarks buried intelligent responses from Buddhists, who made arguments along these lines \xe2\x80\x94 'b'explaining their faith'b', 'b'contrasting it with Christianity'b', and describing how a lost soul like 'b'Woods might use Buddhist concepts'b' to climb from darkness into light.'b'When liberal democracy was forged, in the wake of Western Europe\xe2\x80\x99s religious wars, this sort of peaceful theological debate is exactly what it promised to deliver. Theology has consequences: It shapes lives, families, nations, cultures, wars; it can change people, save them from themselves, and sometimes warp or even destroy them.'b'If we tiptoe politely around this reality, then we betray every teacher, guru and philosopher \xe2\x80\x94 including Jesus of Nazareth and the Buddha both \xe2\x80\x94 who ever sought to resolve the most human of all problems: 'b'How then should we live?'b''b'It\xe2\x80\x99s reasonable to doubt that a cable news analyst has the right answer to this question.
