He is immortal, not because he alone among creatures has an inexhaustible voice, but because he has a soul, a spirit capable of compassion and sacrifice and endurance.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In the darkest of moments, Plutarch is also a comfort. \xe2\x80\x9cGood fortune,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cwill elevate even petty minds, and give them the appearance of a certain greatness and stateliness, as from their high place they look down upon the world; but the truly noble and resolved spirit raises itself, and becomes more conspicuous in times of disaster and ill fortune.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'TO those of us who have seen all of Eric Rohmer\xe2\x80\x99s films it is impossible not to remember when, where, with whom we saw each one. I even remember the second and third time I saw his films. \xe2\x80\x9cMy Night at Maud\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cClaire\xe2\x80\x99s Knee,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cChloe in the Afternoon\xe2\x80\x9d are grafted onto my life. Something happened between me and these films at the Thalia, at the Brattle, at the old Cin\xc3\xa9math\xc3\xa8que, or at the old Olympia Theater on the Upper West Side. But I can no longer isolate what that something is. I don\xe2\x80\x99t even care to know what was exclusively Eric Rohmer\xe2\x80\x99s and what was mine, what he was ever so cautious to convey and what I most likely misunderstood completely. The mix, as sometimes happens, becomes the work of art.'b'But then with Mr. Rohmer, who died this week at the age of 89, the mix is not incidental; it is essential. To see an Eric Rohmer film is not to escape from the drudgery of our daily lives; it is to sit quietly and have someone show us lives that are not entirely different from ours but different enough, situations we\xe2\x80\x99ve all been in and couldn\xe2\x80\x99t wait to get out of but could have learned from, if only we\xe2\x80\x99d had the patience and the courage to sit through them.'b'Mr. Rohmer was the master of tact \xe2\x80\x94 tact in the way his characters behave with one another, tact in the way he himself, as a director, spun his tales, and ultimately tact with truth and fiction. In his hands, sex could be suspended, and passion, without ever boiling over, seldom went cold.'b'I can\xe2\x80\x99t forget the scene in \xe2\x80\x9cMy Night at Maud\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d when the very pious engineer in the business suit decides to sit on Maud\xe2\x80\x99s bed while she is lying under the covers with only a T-shirt on, determined to seduce him. They stare at each other, and they talk, and she tells him things, and he tells her things, and still they talk, and it\xe2\x80\x99s clear to everyone, including the characters themselves, that though this strange couple has just met hours earlier and may not share a sliver of love between them, what we\xe2\x80\x99ve just witnessed is one of the most intimate scenes in movie history.'b'It is impossible to watch this scene or certain moments in \xe2\x80\x9cTale of Autumn,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cA Good Marriage\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cFull Moon in Paris\xe2\x80\x9d and not envy the candor of Eric Rohmer\xe2\x80\x99s men and women, their impulse to dissect each nuance of desire and then turn around and confide it right away to those who\xe2\x80\x99d aroused them.'b'With my friends we used to call these situations Rohmerian. You meet A, you are drawn to A, but neither you nor A wish to rush things. You simply want to stop time a bit, and because neither of you cares to hide what you\xe2\x80\x99re really doing, you decide to confess your maneuvers and are wildly grateful when told they were by no means unknown to the other. Rohmerian. What comes after this is seldom the business of art; it is the stuff of humdrum prose.'b'Since his death, the usual clich\xc3\xa9s about Eric Rohmer are once again pullulating on the Internet. He was talky. He was a mannerist. He was a classicist. Eric Rohmer \xe2\x80\x94 whose men are more into themselves than the women they are allegedly trying to seduce. Eric Rohmer \xe2\x80\x94 whose films, in the words of the character played by Gene Hackman in \xe2\x80\x9cNight Moves,\xe2\x80\x9d are like \xe2\x80\x9cwatching paint dry.\xe2\x80\x9d Eric Rohmer \xe2\x80\x94 for whom courtship is a conceit for how people jockey into position vis-\xc3\xa0-vis the things they want and seldom believe they\xe2\x80\x99ll get.'b'What the commentary has missed is that Eric Rohmer was above all things a \xe2\x80\x9cmoraliste.\xe2\x80\x9d The word is difficult to translate. All the men in his \xe2\x80\x9cSix Moral Tales\xe2\x80\x9d are either married or engaged to be married but, through a series of accidents, find themselves tempted to betray their beloveds. Each therefore is faced with a \xe2\x80\x9cmoral\xe2\x80\x9d quandary.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s worth remembering that Mr. Rohmer was playing with words, using the word \xe2\x80\x9cmoral\xe2\x80\x9d in a way that harks back to the French Moralists of the 17th century. Despite their emphasis on morality, men like Pascal, La Rochefoucauld and La Bruy\xc3\xa8re were urbane and disabused analysts of manners, mores and the human psyche. They were perpetually on the lookout for every insidious motivation in others and every instance of self-delusion in themselves. In the hands of a moralist, even sex becomes a conceit.'b'For all their self-analysis, Eric Rohmer\xe2\x80\x99s men and women are not as penetrating as they wish to be. No one is evil, no one is too good either, and no one suffers, or at least not for long. They all muddle through courtship, never get their hands dirty; and the hard truths they must face are always given obliquely enough and never hurt. There are ugly facts enough on the outside.'b'With Eric Rohmer, as with Mozart, Austen, James and Proust, we need to remember that art is seldom about life, or not quite about life. Art is about discovery and design and reasoning with chaos. If there is one thing I will miss with Eric Rohmer\xe2\x80\x99s death, it is the clarity, the candor and the pleasure with which one human can sit with another and reason about love and not forget, in Pascal\xe2\x80\x99s words, that \xe2\x80\x9cthe heart has reasons that reason knows nothing of.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'When I drive from New York to California, as I did again last week, I always hope I\xe2\x80\x99m going to get a kind of backyard view of the present-day United States. But what I discover is that I\xe2\x80\x99m driving through the past. The road west is littered with the bones of old vehicles, taunting me in their rusted glory from just beyond the fence-line. Every echo of Route 66 is a reminder of a time when the highway was a trail of automotive woe, of engine failures and bad rubber, of drivers on bended knee in front of a jack.'b'This drive was entirely without incident \xe2\x80\x94 2,976 miles in four days, from my farm in upstate New York to the eastern edge of Los Angeles County. And yet all the way I kept expecting the car to act up. On a bitterly cold morning in Grove City, Ohio, I turned the key, ready to hear a moan from the engine. It fired right up, of course. There were no flats and there was not a mutter of perturbation from the muffler. An alarm light did come on once, but that was only because the other driver \xe2\x80\x94 a farming friend who needed a break from the pigs \xe2\x80\x94 pushed the wrong button while adjusting the mirrors.'b'The reason I always expect trouble is my father\xe2\x80\x99s cars. They were like horses that traveled well for him but always came up lame for his children. It bred chronic distrust. I learned to think of a car \xe2\x80\x94 my dad\xe2\x80\x99s especially \xe2\x80\x94 as a way of getting from one breakdown to the next and meeting unexpected strangers. Driving a nearly new car across the country felt like a mean but somehow gloating rejection of adventure.'b'The curious part is that as cars have become more and more sealed off in their technological dependability, they\xe2\x80\x99ve also become more porous. It was no trouble, using G.P.S. and our smartphones, to find Ingrid\xe2\x80\x99s Kitchen in Oklahoma City or Lumpy\xe2\x80\x99s in Joplin, Mo., or Taqueria Mexico in Albuquerque. I began, in fact, to glimpse a new geography. All those towering fast food signs clustered at freeway exits began to look like signs of paranoia as well as convenience \xe2\x80\x94 a warning against getting too far off the track. But information doesn\xe2\x80\x99t cluster at the exits \xe2\x80\x94 it takes you wherever you think you want to go.'b'And so, after four days, we came across Arizona and alongside the Mojave and over Cajon Pass to the high, whining, gospel yelp of Bill Monroe. Somehow that Joad-like music seemed just right, though we never found ourselves searching for radiator water or camping in the ditches or cursing the foul machine that carried us west.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s obvious  that many of the buildings that collapsed during the Haitian earthquake  were poorly designed or constructed. In Haiti, because there is virtually no lumber for building, structures have been made of concrete blocks, often with  inadequately reinforced concrete frames. But to suggest that the country simply be rebuilt to a technically higher standard is to take a shortsighted approach.'b'An internationally financed rebuilding effort, involving scores of architects and engineers drafted  to work with the Haitian authorities, should take a longer view of Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s future, supporting a gradual, profoundly well-thought-out physical transformation. Their work will demand determined physical reinvention and, where appropriate, architectural innovation.'b'Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s government had already begun considering new planning and building codes. It\xe2\x80\x99s still crucial to finish that job, to establish standards that not only reduce the risk that structures will collapse  in hurricanes and earthquakes but also help Haiti build for the future. But this isn\xe2\x80\x99t just a question of better-quality steel and concrete; it\xe2\x80\x99s also about choosing where not to build. Far too many buildings in Haiti have stood on deforested, unstable hillsides, and new building strategies must dovetail with environmental repair schemes.'b'Furthermore, the urge to rebuild rapidly should be tempered by a  thorough examination of new designs for safer, more energy-efficient and less expensive structures. (Keep in mind that the cost of construction relative to income in Haiti is at least five times greater than it is in the United States.) For architects and engineers from Haiti and overseas, that\xe2\x80\x99s a huge responsibility.'b'In few places can the usually glib phrase \xe2\x80\x9cdesign for life\xe2\x80\x9d have greater meaning. Now, for the most awful and imperative reason imaginable, Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s government and its international supporters have the opportunity to turn stark devastation into the beginning of a new standard of living.'b''b'When the immediate crisis passes, how can we ensure that Haiti becomes a functioning nation? Eight experts give their prescriptions. 'b''b'There are about a billion squatters in the world today, and over time many have transformed their once-squalid communities into normal urban neighborhoods. In the awful aftermath of the tremor that turned hundreds of thousands of Haitians into refugees in their own hometown, a few sensible squatter principles may hold out hope for the devastated residents of Port-au-Prince:'b'\xc2\x95 Squatting is not a crime. Rather than being put in refugee camps, people can seize the initiative and squat in their old communities, without aid groups clamping down on them. This doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean occupying unsafe houses, but erecting new shacks nearby. This way, families can share food, shelter and skills. And these nascent communities \xe2\x80\x94 self-organized and temporary at first \xe2\x80\x94 can serve  as the building blocks of new neighborhoods.'b'\xc2\x95 Scavenging is not wrong. In Mumbai, India, squatters build and rebuild their homes one wall at a time using materials that they find on the side of the road. Billboards, fence posts, bricks picked up from construction sites, scarred wooden panels: these are all incredibly valuable resources.'b'\xc2\x95 Not all theft is criminal. Looting is wrong, but lifting necessities like water or electricity is not. In Rio de Janeiro\xe2\x80\x99s favelas, squatters steal from the city\xe2\x80\x99s water mains and connect them directly to their homes using electric pumps (they pilfer the electricity, too) and long lines of plastic pipe. If any of Port-au-Prince\xe2\x80\x99s water system or electric grid has survived, shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t people be allowed to tap into them?'b'\xc2\x95 Self-reliant networks are key. In the favelas, families will join to create a mutir\xc3\xa3o \xe2\x80\x94 mutual construction society \xe2\x80\x94 and build their homes together. In Kibera, the largest mud hut community in Nairobi, Kenya, women form \xe2\x80\x9cmerry-go-rounds\xe2\x80\x9d to pool their money. In Lagos, Nigeria, every illegal market has a self-governing association. In Istanbul, squatter communities have elected governments that establish planning and zoning principles. Local cooperative efforts like these can help make rebuilding and recovery possible in Haiti.'b'America\xe2\x80\x99s efforts to assist Haiti over the last 20 years were hobbled by bitter partisan division over Jean-Bertrand Aristide, the country\xe2\x80\x99s elected, deposed and then reinstalled president. Unfortunately, as the American debate over policy toward Haiti subsided with Mr. Aristide\xe2\x80\x99s final ouster in 2004, so did American interest.'b'The latest disaster to befall Haiti creates the opportunity to combine bipartisan accord on Haiti in Washington with keen and perhaps sustained American public interest. The first priorities must be food, water, medicine and shelter. The second is to   repair hospitals, schools, roads, electricity and telephone service and government buildings.'b'But these institutions should not be rebuilt on the old inefficient and corrupt foundations. This disaster is an opportunity to accelerate oft-delayed reforms in each of these sectors. The port of Port-au-Prince has, for instance, long had one of the highest costs per ton of shipping in the hemisphere, despite also having the lowest wages. Any aid that goes to rebuilding the port should be conditional on ending this grossly inefficient management and distorted cost structure.'b'Likewise, money for repairing the country\xe2\x80\x99s telecommunications system should be linked to breaking up or at least reorganizing the government-controlled telephone monopoly. The same goes with the Education Ministry, the electric company, the Health Ministry and the courts. Repair or replace the buildings, by all means, but also insist on fundamental reforms in their management.'b'The standard approach to residential redevelopment projects is to take ground zero as a starting point \xe2\x80\x94 even if it means creating it. This often translates into shifting people from substandard but incrementally developing environments into apartment blocks that cut them off from their social networks and livelihoods. These projects often become housing-centric and blind to the relationship between neighborhoods and economic development. They end up benefiting the construction industry much more than the population they are supposed to serve.'b'Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s shattered urban landscapes were about communities, street life, resourcefulness, aspirations and dynamic local exchanges. As we have seen in the Dharavi area of Mumbai (the setting of \xe2\x80\x9cSlumdog Millionaire\xe2\x80\x9d), poverty often generates creative responses and initiatives. Local actors tend to produce piecemeal development that directly supports neighborhood-level activity.'b'As we consider how to rebuild Port-au-Prince, we can find an alternative to the usual top-down redevelopment model in postwar Tokyo. The Japanese government didn\xe2\x80\x99t have the money to rebuild housing and so focused instead on roads, sewage and rail transportation. It also encouraged lenders to give families money to build homes. A decentralized and highly participatory urban redevelopment process produced areas of low-rise, high-density structures built with local skills and material. This not only strengthened communities but also stimulated the local economies. Tokyo today has a landscape that is futuristic and yet retains many traditional Asian urban features including street markets, small-scale businesses and family enterprises. The incremental redevelopment of Tokyo was thus intricately connected to the rise of its middle class.'b'If aid in Haiti aims specifically at regenerating local economies, if it promotes existing skills and collective initiatives, if it consults with grassroots groups and residents directly, it may well bring about a real transformation.'b'When  Columbus landed on Hispaniola in 1492, he marveled at the island\xe2\x80\x99s luxuriant, towering forests. Today, on the Haitian side of the island, only 2 percent of the forest cover remains. During storms, water rushes off barren hillsides, causing deadly mudslides, clogging streams with soil and sewage and disappearing before it can  replenish Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s diminishing groundwater reserves.'b'As a result, nearly half of all Haitians lack satisfactory access to clean drinking water, and more than two-thirds live without adequate sanitation. Water poverty is the main reason for Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s abysmal illness and early mortality rates.'b'Designing and building pipes and sewage systems  is the easiest part of solving a nation\xe2\x80\x99s water problem; maintenance is what is always frustratingly intractable. In Haiti, meter readers and water bill collectors are  often  assaulted when they try to do their jobs, and service has deteriorated.'b'In rebuilding Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s water systems, it is imperative to focus on simple and affordable local projects that communities can take responsibility for. The network of water and sewer pipes should be built with flexible materials that can be shallowly buried and easily repaired. Bulk sewer services and drinking water should be delivered at wholesale costs to distribution points in urban neighborhoods, where local leaders can handle payments for the service and maintain the local network.'b'Before the earthquake, Haiti was working to expand its already modestly successful water initiatives in rural areas, including the local management of simple well pumps. This work should be revived as soon as possible. Local water management both inside and outside the cities is a necessary condition for rebuilding all of Haiti.'b'The  United States has a vast bureaucracy to scrutinize how our government spends money abroad. While this kind of oversight is often necessary, there must be an exception made for crisis response in failed states.  I base this on  my experience after the Iraq invasion.'b'In June 2003, we learned that most of Baghdad\xe2\x80\x99s hospitals had no emergency generators. We needed 22 of them. Logistically, there was no problem \xe2\x80\x94  they could be shipped in within a week. But we were told by Washington that we would have to follow standard federal contracting and acquisition regulations, which meant a seven-month delay.'b'That September, the Iraqi Water Ministry was trying to cope with the devastation caused to Iraq\xe2\x80\x99s ancient irrigation canals in the breadbasket areas south of Baghdad. The minister told us that if he could have $20 million, he could hire Iraqis to clean up the canals with shovels, pitchforks and rakes, resolving a humanitarian crisis and creating thousands of jobs. The same day, the Coalition Provisional Authority allocated $20 million of Iraqi government money for the project.'b'Unfortunately, the inspector general for Iraq reconstruction in Washington later objected, in an official report,  because we had no way of tracking the money after it had been turned over to the Water Ministry. Merely to state this argument is to understand its absurdity. We would have had to install an army of American accountants to track every expense to its end recipient.'b'Today, Haiti faces a similar crisis. If we are going to have American military units deployed in Haiti \xe2\x80\x94 and we should \xe2\x80\x94 it would be invaluable for the unit commanders to have access to the Commanders\xe2\x80\x99 Emergency Response Fund that was established for Iraq. This is a discretionary fund that American officers can dip into for development projects and crisis response without constantly looking over their shoulders at monitors in Washington. Congress recently set aside an additional $1.3 billion for the program, which has been expanded to Afghanistan. It should be expanded to Haiti, too.'b'Coinciding with the one-year anniversary of President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s unfulfilled pledge to close the American prison at Guant\xc3\xa1namo Bay, the disaster  in Haiti suggests a new mission for the United States naval base, one that might burnish America\xe2\x80\x99s reputation in the world, if not redeem the base itself. Guant\xc3\xa1namo is just 200 miles from Port-au-Prince, only 50 miles farther than Santo Domingo in the Dominican Republic, where American officials are staging earthquake recovery operations. Even as the United States works to close the prison, it should use the base for humanitarian intervention.'b'The base has two airfields, a state-of-the-art communication system and brand-new water and sewage lines that could accommodate as many as 45,000 refugees. And the base is large enough to stage an aid effort without impinging on prison operations.'b'Starting today, it might serve as a field hospital, a refugee camp or a depot for the distribution of food, medicine, clothing and other emergency supplies. It could also be a command-and-control center for the many aid groups now clogging Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s runways. Once the rescue mission is complete, Guant\xc3\xa1namo could continue to serve as the headquarters of what is sure to be an extended rebuilding effort in Port-au-Prince.'b'It would not be the first time that Guant\xc3\xa1namo served as a base for humanitarian relief in Haiti. In October 1935, after a hurricane brought deadly flooding to the country, washing away whole villages, the   Navy ship Woodcock set out from the base to deliver lumber, medicine, food, disinfectant and other necessities.'b'A re-imagined Guant\xc3\xa1namo could again be used to help relieve crises in the region, beginning with Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s earthquake recovery today.'b'The underground economy in places like Haiti is often viewed as a criminal sector, made up of thugs and warlords, that sets back economic growth. But this is a one-sided portrait. Informal trading may be critical for Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s recovery. Citizens in developing countries tend to find creative ways to make ends meet. The sharing of tools and workspaces, collective ownership of property, revolving credit associations and barter systems  make up the backbone of the economy.'b'New customs emerge to settle disputes and enforce contracts. Anyone might be a banker one day (lending small sums of money to others) and a policeman the next (resolving a disagreement between two local traders). This exchange system also brings together diverse groups who learn to interact across religious, ethnic, tribal and other social divides.'b'During disasters, however, things can turn for the worse, and those with force can take over. Countries now aiding Haiti should  ensure that organized crime doesn\xe2\x80\x99t take control of local economies. But they must be careful not to drum out the positives of informal development.'b'Haitians could benefit from outsiders who help them rebuild the ad hoc relationships that have engendered trust and cooperation. Nongovernmental groups could aid the creation of cooperatives that can be brought into decisions about the distribution of food, medical care and housing in their neighborhoods. We can take a cue from the Grameen \xe2\x80\x9cmicrobank\xe2\x80\x9d in South Asia by identifying informal economic leaders with the legitimacy to mobilize others, spread information and coordinate rebuilding efforts.'b'SAN FRANCISCO'b'It has been quite a journey for Ted Olson. He\xe2\x80\x99s gone from being the conservative lawyer who helped crown W. by winning the Bush v. Gore case before the Supreme Court, to being a lesbian.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cMaureen,\xe2\x80\x9d he told me in his gravelly voice, \xe2\x80\x9cone of the biggest lesbian groups in this country told me I\xe2\x80\x99m already an honorary lesbian.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Did it make you feel different, I wondered.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI still like women very much,\xe2\x80\x9d he wryly replied, as his biking pal, liberal adversary and now co-counsel David Boies laughed, snacking on a crust of sourdough bread in their temporary office on Mission Street.'b'In 2000, Olson and Boies sparred with each other in Washington over which candidate would marry the country. Now they have joined forces here to spar with Prop 8 defenders over who can marry.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTed Olson and David Boies, so what are they up to?\xe2\x80\x9d Olson laughed, summarizing the confusion and conspiracy theories that their union inspired.'b'As the sun set on the Bay Bridge behind him and the curtain dropped on the first week of the dramatic trial to challenge the constitutionality of the state\xe2\x80\x99s ban on same-sex marriage, Olson reviewed the case: \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re going to explain why allowing same-sex couples to have that same right that the rest of us have is not going to hurt heterosexual marriages. It has no point at all except some people don\xe2\x80\x99t want to recognize gays and lesbians as normal, as human beings.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Boies, wearing a flag pin on his lapel, said that the state of California is engaged in \xe2\x80\x9cgay bashing.\xe2\x80\x9d He spoke intensely about the gay and lesbian plaintiffs, who offered poignant testimony about their loving relationships and about wanting to be liked and accepted: \xe2\x80\x9cThese people are people you would want your child to grow up and marry. You can be a child molester and get married. You can be a wife beater and get married. You can be a child-support scofflaw and get married. The importance of that emotional relationship is so vital to the pursuit of happiness that even prison felons, who aren\xe2\x80\x99t really procreating, have a right to get married.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Noting the rabid effort being made to restrict marriage to only those who can protect its sanctity, a chuckling Olson reeled off some names: \xe2\x80\x9cTiger Woods, Eliot Spitzer, Mark Sanford, Kobe Bryant, Bill Clinton.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'I asked Olson if he misted up, as many in the courtroom did, when Jeff Zarrillo, a 36-year-old manager at AMC Entertainment, testified that he loved his partner \xe2\x80\x9cprobably more than I love myself.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d Olson replied, noting that he finds himself getting weepy a lot, including when a bright lawyer in his Washington law firm approached him in the library to tell him she was a lesbian mother of two and she was grateful to him.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI think there\xe2\x80\x99s something the matter with you if you don\xe2\x80\x99t care enough to feel the suffering that they\xe2\x80\x99ve been through and if you\xe2\x80\x99re not emotionally upset about the fact that we\xe2\x80\x99re doing an immense amount of harm to people,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re not treating them like Americans. We\xe2\x80\x99re not treating them like citizens.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Boies said the problem was generational, and they have to try the case before judges their own age who might find it hard to move beyond old prejudices. (Although this judge, a libertarian-tilting George H. W. Bush appointee, Vaughn Walker, who likes to hire magicians for the court\xe2\x80\x99s annual dinner, has been so accommodating to their side that Ed Meese complained he was tilting the case.)'b'\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve got a grandson who\xe2\x80\x99s a senior in college, and he can\xe2\x80\x99t imagine fighting over this issue,\xe2\x80\x9d Boies said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s like explaining to my daughter that there was a time when women didn\xe2\x80\x99t have the right to vote and couldn\xe2\x80\x99t own property.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The anti-gay-marriage proponents whipped up a moral frenzy in 2008,  suggesting conjugal parity would harm children, summon the devil, tear down churches and melt civilization. But Olson argued in his opening statement that the discrimination gays experience \xe2\x80\x9cweakens our moral fiber in this country.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'While Charles Cooper, the lawyer on the anti-gay-marriage side, cited President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s declaration that marriage should only be between a man and a woman, Olson noted that Obama\xe2\x80\x99s parents could not have married in Virginia before he was born.'b'I asked the lawyers if they were disappointed that the president who had once raised such hope in the gay community now seemed behind the curve.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cDamned right,\xe2\x80\x9d Boies snapped. \xe2\x80\x9cI hope my Democratic president will catch up to my conservative Republican co-counsel.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Olson added: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not talking about Obama, but that\xe2\x80\x99s what\xe2\x80\x99s so bad about politicians. They say, \xe2\x80\x98I must hasten to follow them, for I am their leader.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Obama sees himself as such a huge change that he can be cautious about other societal changes. But what he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t realize is that legalizing gay marriage is like electing a black president. Before you do it, it seems inconceivable. Once it\xe2\x80\x99s done, you can\xe2\x80\x99t remember what all the fuss was about.'b'Even given the low bar set by America\xe2\x80\x99s bogus conversations about race, the 'b'short-lived Harry Reid fracas'b' was a most peculiar nonevent. For all the hyperventilation in cable news land, this supposed racial brawl didn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to generate any controversy whatsoever in what is known as the real world.'b'Eugene Robinson, the liberal black columnist at The Washington Post, 'b'wrote'b' that he was \xe2\x80\x9cneither shocked nor outraged\xe2\x80\x9d at Reid\xe2\x80\x99s less-than-articulate observation that Barack Obama benefited politically from being \xe2\x80\x9clight-skinned\xe2\x80\x9d and for lacking a \xe2\x80\x9cNegro dialect unless he wanted to have one.\xe2\x80\x9d Besides, Robinson said, Reid\xe2\x80\x99s point was \xe2\x80\x9csurely true.\xe2\x80\x9d The black conservative Ward Connerly agreed, 'b'writing in The Wall Street Journal'b' that he was \xe2\x80\x9chaving a difficult time determining what it was that Mr. Reid said that was so offensive.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'President Obama immediately granted Reid absolution. A black columnist at The Daily News in New York, Stanley Crouch, even'b' stood up for the archaic usage'b' of \xe2\x80\x9cNegro.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'George Will defended'b' Reid from charges of racism as vociferously as Democrats did. Al Sharpton may have 'b'accepted Reid\xe2\x80\x99s apology'b', but for once there\xe2\x80\x99s no evidence that he ever cared enough to ask for one. So who, actually, was the aggrieved party here? What  \xe2\x80\x94  or who  \xe2\x80\x94  was really behind this manufactured race war with no victims?'b'It would be easy to dismiss the entire event as a credulous news media\xe2\x80\x99s collaboration with a publisher\xe2\x80\x99s hype for a new tell-all-gossip 2008 campaign book, \xe2\x80\x9cGame Change,\xe2\x80\x9d which breathlessly broke the Reid \xe2\x80\x9cbombshell.\xe2\x80\x9d But this is a more interesting tale than that. The true prime mover in this story was not a book publicist but Michael Steele, the chairman of the Republican Party and by far the loudest and most prominent Beltway figure 'b'demanding that Reid resign'b' as Senate majority leader as punishment for his \xe2\x80\x9cracism.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Steele is widely regarded as a clown by observers of all political persuasions, but he is clownish like a fox. His actions in this incident offer some hilarious and instructive insights into what\xe2\x80\x99s going on in the Republican hierarchy right now as it tries to cope not just with our first African-American president but with a restive base embracing right-wing tea-party populism that loathes the establishment in both parties. And though Steele is black, and perhaps the most enthusiastic player of the race card in American politics today, race was a red herring in his Reid vendetta. It threw most everyone off the scent of his real motivation, which had nothing to do with black versus white but everything to do with green, as in money.'b'A profligate spender, Steele had inaugurated his arrival  as party chairman by 'b'devoting nearly $20,000'b' to redecorate his office 'b'because'b' he found it \xe2\x80\x9cway too male\xe2\x80\x9d for his sensitive tastes. In the weeks just before \xe2\x80\x9cGame Change\xe2\x80\x9d emerged, Steele was in more hot water. Over the holidays, G.O.P. elders were shocked to learn that their front man had 'b'a side career as a motivational public speaker'b' at up to $20,000 a gig. The party treasury, which contained $22.8 million upon Steele\xe2\x80\x99s arrival at the end of January 2009, 'b'was down to $8.7 million by late November'b', with 2010 campaign expenditures rapidly arriving. \xe2\x80\x9cHe needs to raise money for the party, not his wallet,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'one Republican leader griped to Politico'b'.'b'Then, just after New Year, Steele published an unexpected book of his own, \xe2\x80\x9cRight Now: A 12-Step Program for Defeating the Obama Agenda.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'He hadn\xe2\x80\x99t told his employers'b' that the book was in the works, and, to add further insult, he attacks unnamed party leaders in its pages for forsaking conservative principles. Since it hit the stores, Steele has pursued a book tour for fun and personal profit, all the while daring his G.O.P. critics to bring it on. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t want me in the job, fire me,\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'he taunted them'b'. \xe2\x80\x9cBut until then, shut up. Get with the program, or get out of the way.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Fire him? Steele knows better than anyone that his party can\xe2\x80\x99t afford what Clarence Thomas might call a \xe2\x80\x9chigh-tech lynching\xe2\x80\x9d of the only visible black guy it has in even a second-tier office. 'b'Steele has said'b' that white Republicans are \xe2\x80\x9cscared\xe2\x80\x9d of him. They are. He loves to play head games with their racial paranoia and insecurities, whether he\xe2\x80\x99s publicly professing \xe2\x80\x9c'b'slum love'b'\xe2\x80\x9d for the Indian-American Louisiana governor, Bobby Jindal, or starting a blog on the R.N.C. site titled \xe2\x80\x9c'b'What Up?'b',\xe2\x80\x9d or announcing that he would use \xe2\x80\x9c'b'fried chicken and potato salad'b'\xe2\x80\x9d to recruit minority voters. As long as the G.O.P. remains largely a whites-only country club, Steele has job security. But he had real reason to fear some new restraints on the cash box; last year the party was driven to write a rule requiring him to get approval for expenditures over $100,000.'b'On Jan. 9 The Washington Post 'b'ran a front-page article headlined'b' \xe2\x80\x9cFrustrations With Steele Leaving G.O.P. in a Bind,\xe2\x80\x9d reporting, among other embarrassments, that the party had spent $90 million during Steele\xe2\x80\x99s brief reign while raising just $84 million. Enter \xe2\x80\x9cGame Change,\xe2\x80\x9d right in the nick of time for Steele to pull off his own cunning game change. On Jan. 10 he stormed \xe2\x80\x9cFox News Sunday\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cMeet the Press\xe2\x80\x9d to 'b'demand Reid\xe2\x80\x99s head'b'. There has been hardly a mention of Steele\xe2\x80\x99s sins since. He can laugh all the way to the bank.'b'His behavior is not anomalous. Steele is representative of a fascinating but little noted development on the right: the rise of buckrakers who are exploiting the party\xe2\x80\x99s anarchic confusion and divisions to cash in for their own private gain. In this cause, Steele is emulating no one if not Sarah Palin, whose hunger for celebrity and money outstrips even his own. As many suspected at the time, her 2008 campaign wardrobe, like the doomed campaign itself, was just a preview of coming attractions: she would surely dump the bother of serving as Alaska\xe2\x80\x99s besieged governor for a lucrative star turn on Fox News. Last week 'b'she made it official'b'.'b'Both Steele and Palin claim to be devotees of the tea party movement. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a tea partier, I\xe2\x80\x99m a town-haller, I\xe2\x80\x99m a grass-roots-er\xe2\x80\x9d is 'b'how Steele put it in a recent radio interview'b', wet-kissing a market he hopes will buy his book. Palin has far more grandiose ambitions. She recently signed on as a speaker for the first 'b'Tea Party Convention'b', scheduled next month in Nashville  \xe2\x80\x94  even though she had 'b'turned down a speaking invitation from the annual Conservative Political Action Conference'b', the traditional meet-and-greet for the right. The conservative conference doesn\xe2\x80\x99t pay. The Tea Party Convention does. A 'b'blogger at Nashville Scene reported'b' that Palin\xe2\x80\x99s price for the event was $120,000.'b'The entire Tea Party Convention is a 'b'profit-seeking  affair'b' charging $560 a ticket  \xe2\x80\x94  plus the cost of a room at the Opryland Hotel. Among the convention\xe2\x80\x99s eight 'b'listed sponsors'b' is 'b'Tea Party Emporium'b', which gives as its contact address 'b'444 Madison Avenue'b' in New York, also 'b'home to the high-fashion brand Burberry'b'. This emporium\xe2\x80\x99s  Web site offers a bejeweled tea bag at $89.99 for those furious at \xe2\x80\x9ca government hell bent on the largest redistribution of wealth in history.\xe2\x80\x9d This is almost as shameless as Glenn Beck, whose own tea party profiteering has included hawking gold coins merchandised by a sponsor of his radio show.'b'Last week a prominent right-wing blogger, Erick Erickson of 'b'RedState.com'b', 'b'finally figured out'b' that the Tea Party Convention \xe2\x80\x9csmells scammy,\xe2\x80\x9d likening it to one of those Nigerian e-mails promising untold millions. Such rumbling about the movement\xe2\x80\x99s being co-opted by hucksters may explain why Palin used her first paid appearance at Fox last Tuesday to 'b'tell Bill O\xe2\x80\x99Reilly that she would recycle her own tea party profits'b' in political contributions. But Erickson had it right: the tea party movement is being exploited  \xe2\x80\x94  and not just by marketers, lobbyists, political consultants and corporate interests but by the Republican Party, as exemplified by Palin and Steele, its most prominent leaders.'b'Tea partiers hate the G.O.P. establishment and its Wall Street allies, starting with the Bushies who created TARP, almost as much as they do Obama and his Wall Street pals. When Steele and Palin pay lip service to the movement, they are happy to glom on to its anti-tax, anti-Obama, anti-government, anti-big-bank vitriol. But they don\xe2\x80\x99t call for any actual action against the bailed-out perpetrators of the financial crisis. They\xe2\x80\x99d never ask for investments to put ordinary Americans back to work. They have no policies to forestall foreclosures or protect health insurance for the tea partiers who\xe2\x80\x99ve been shafted by hard times. Their only economic principle beside tax cuts is vilification of the stimulus that did save countless jobs for firefighters, police officers and teachers at the state and local level.'b'The Democrats\xe2\x80\x99 efforts to counter the deprivation and bitterness spawned by the Great Recession are indeed timid and imperfect. The right has a point when it says that the Senate health care votes of Ben Nelson of Nebraska and Mary Landrieu of Louisiana were bought with pork. But at least their constituents can share the pigout. Hustlers like Steele and Palin take the money and run. All their followers get in exchange is a lousy tea party T-shirt. Or a ghost-written self-promotional book. Or a tepid racial sideshow far beneath the incendiary standards of the party whose history from Strom to \xe2\x80\x9cmacaca\xe2\x80\x9d has driven away nearly every black American except Steele for the past 40 years.'b'Want to be happier in 2010? Then try this simple experiment, inspired by recent scholarship in psychology and neurology. Which person would you rather be:'b'Richard is an ambitious 36-year-old white commodities trader in Florida. He\xe2\x80\x99s healthy and drop-dead handsome, lives alone in a house with a pool, and has worked his way through a series of gorgeous women. Richard\xe2\x80\x99s job is stressful, but he spent Christmas in Tahiti. Unencumbered, he also has time to indulge such passions as reading (right now he\xe2\x80\x99s finishing a book called \xe2\x80\x9cHalf the Sky\xe2\x80\x9d), marathon running and writing poetry. In the last few days, he has been composing an elegy about the Haiti earthquake.'b'Lorna is a 64-year-old black woman in Boston. She\xe2\x80\x99s overweight and unattractive, even after a recent nose job. Lorna is on regular dialysis, but that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t impede her active social life or babysitting her grandchildren. A retired school assistant, she is close to her 67-year-old husband and is much respected in her church for directing the music committee and the semiannual blood drive. Lorna believes in tithing (giving 10 percent of her income to charity or the church) and in the last few days has organized a church drive to raise $10,000 for earthquake relief in Haiti.'b'I adapted those examples from ones that Jonathan Haidt, a psychology professor at the University of Virginia, develops in his fascinating book, 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Happiness Hypothesis.\xe2\x80\x9d'b' His point is that while most of us might prefer to trade places with Richard, Lorna is probably happier.'b''b'Men are no happier than women'b', and people in sunny areas no happier than people in chillier climates. 'b'The evidence on health is complex'b', but even chronic health problems (like those requiring dialysis) may have surprisingly little long-term effect on happiness, because we adjust to them. Beautiful people aren\xe2\x80\x99t happier than ugly people, although cosmetic surgery does seem to leave patients feeling brighter. Whites are happier than blacks, but only very slightly. And young people are actually a bit less happy than older folks, at least up to age 65.'b'Lorna has a few advantages over Richard. She has less stress and is respected by her peers  \xe2\x80\x94 factors that make us feel good. Happiness is tied to volunteering and to giving blood, and people with religious faith tend to be happier than those without. A solid marriage is linked to happiness, as is participation in social networks. And one study found that people who focus on achieving wealth and career advancement are less happy than those who focus on good works, religion or spirituality, or friends and family.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cHuman beings are in some ways like bees,\xe2\x80\x9d Professor Haidt said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe evolved to live in intensely social groups, and we don\xe2\x80\x99t do as well when freed from hives.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Happiness is, of course, a complex concept and difficult to measure, and John Stuart Mill had a point when he suggested: \xe2\x80\x9cIt is better to be a human being dissatisfied than a pig satisfied; better to be Socrates dissatisfied than a fool satisfied.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But in any case, nobility can lead to happiness. Professor Haidt notes that one thing that can make a lasting difference to your contentment is to work with others on a cause larger than yourself.'b'I see that all the time. I interview people who were busy but reluctantly undertook some good cause because (sigh!) it was the right thing to do. Then they  found that this \xe2\x80\x9csacrifice\xe2\x80\x9d became a huge source of fulfillment and satisfaction.'b'Brain scans by neuroscientists confirm that altruism carries its own rewards. A team including Dr. Jorge Moll of the National Institutes of Health 'b'found'b' that when a research subject was encouraged to think of giving money to a charity, parts of the brain lit up that are normally associated with selfish pleasures like eating or sex.'b'The implication is that we are hard-wired to be altruistic. To put it another way, it\xe2\x80\x99s difficult for humans to be truly selfless, for generosity feels so good.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe most selfish thing you can do is to help other people,\xe2\x80\x9d says Brian Mullaney, co-founder of 'b'Smile Train'b', which helps tens of thousands of children each year who are born with cleft lips and cleft palates. Mr. Mullaney was a successful advertising executive, driving a Porsche and taking dates to the Four Seasons, when he felt something was missing and began volunteering for good causes. He ended up leaving the business world to help kids smile again  \xe2\x80\x94 and all that makes him smile, too.'b'So at a time of vast needs, from Haiti to our own cities, here\xe2\x80\x99s a nice opportunity for symbiosis: so many afflicted people, and so much benefit to us if we try to help them. Let\xe2\x80\x99s remember that while charity has a mixed record helping others, it has an almost perfect record of helping ourselves. Helping others may be as primal a human pleasure as food or sex.'b'Taipei, Taiwan'b'Dick Cheney says President Obama is \xe2\x80\x9ctrying to pretend that we are not at war\xe2\x80\x9d with terrorists. There is only one thing I have to say about that: I sure hope so.'b'Frankly, if I had my wish, we would be on our way out of Afghanistan not in, we would be letting Pakistan figure out which Taliban they want to conspire with and which ones they want to fight, we would be letting Israelis and Palestinians figure out on their own how to make peace, we would be taking $100 billion out of the Pentagon budget to make us independent of imported oil  \xe2\x80\x94  nothing would make us more secure  \xe2\x80\x94  and we would be reducing the reward for killing or capturing Osama bin Laden to exactly what he\xe2\x80\x99s worth: 10 cents and an autographed picture of Dick Cheney.'b'Am I going isolationist? No, but visiting the greater China region always leaves me envious of the leaders of Hong Kong, Taiwan and China, who surely get to spend more of their time focusing on how to build their nations than my president, whose agenda can be derailed at any moment by a jihadist death cult using exploding underpants.'b'Could we just walk away? No, but we must change our emphasis. The \xe2\x80\x9cwar on terrorists\xe2\x80\x9d has to begin by our challenging the people and leaders 'b'over there'b'. If they\xe2\x80\x99re not ready to take the lead, to speak out and fight the madness in their midst, for the future of their own societies, there is no way we can succeed. We\xe2\x80\x99ll exhaust ourselves trying. We\xe2\x80\x99d be better off just building a higher wall.'b'As the terrorism expert Bruce Hoffman noted in an essay in The Washington Post: \xe2\x80\x9cIn the wake of the global financial crisis, Al Qaeda has stepped up a strategy of economic warfare. \xe2\x80\x98We will bury you,\xe2\x80\x99 Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev promised Americans 50 years ago. Today, Al Qaeda threatens: \xe2\x80\x98We will bankrupt you.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d And they will.'b'Our presence, our oil dependence, our endless foreign aid in the Middle East have become huge enablers of bad governance there and massive escapes from responsibility and accountability by people who want to blame all their troubles on us. Let\xe2\x80\x99s get out of the way and let the moderate majorities there, if they really exist, face their own enemies on their own. It is the only way they will move. We can be the wind at their backs, but we can\xe2\x80\x99t be their sails. There is some hope for Iraq and Iran today because their moderates are fighting for themselves.'b'Has anyone noticed the most important peace breakthrough on the planet in the last two years? It\xe2\x80\x99s right here: the new calm in the Strait of Taiwan. For decades, this was considered the most dangerous place on earth, with Taiwan and China pointing missiles at each other on hair triggers. Well, over the past two years, China and Taiwan have reached a quiet rapprochement  \xe2\x80\x94  'b'on their own'b'. No special envoys or shuttling secretaries of state. Yes, our Navy was a critical stabilizer. But they worked it out. They realized their own interdependence. The result: a new web of economic ties, direct flights and student exchanges.'b'A key reason is that Taiwan has no oil, no natural resources. It\xe2\x80\x99s a barren rock with 23 million people who, through hard work, have amassed the fourth-largest foreign currency reserves in the world. They got rich digging inside themselves, unlocking their entrepreneurs, not digging for oil. 'b'They took responsibility'b'. They got rich by asking: \xe2\x80\x9cHow do I improve myself?\xe2\x80\x9d Not by declaring: \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all somebody else\xe2\x80\x99s fault. Give me a handout.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'When I look at America from here, I worry. China is now our main economic partner and competitor. Sure, China has big problems. Nevertheless, I hope Americans see China\xe2\x80\x99s rise as the 21st-century equivalent of Russia launching the Sputnik satellite \xe2\x80\x94 a challenge to which we responded with a huge national effort that revived our education, infrastructure and science and propelled us for 50 years. Unfortunately, the Cheneyites want to make fighting Al Qaeda our Sputnik. Others want us to worry about some loopy remark Senator Harry Reid made about the shade of Obama\xe2\x80\x99s skin.'b'Well, what is our national project going to be? Racing China, chasing Al Qaeda or parsing Harry? Of course, to a degree, we need to both race China and confront Al Qaeda \xe2\x80\x94 but which will define us?'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOur response to Sputnik made us better educated, more productive, more technologically advanced and more ingenious,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Johns Hopkins foreign policy expert Michael Mandelbaum. \xe2\x80\x9cOur investments in science and education spread throughout American society, producing the Internet, more students studying math and people genuinely wanting to build the nation.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'And what does the war on terror give us? Better drones, body scanners and a lot of desultory T.S.A. security jobs at airports. \xe2\x80\x9cSputnik spurred us to build a highway to the future,\xe2\x80\x9d added Mandelbaum. \xe2\x80\x9cThe war on terror is prompting us to build bridges to nowhere.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'We just keep thinking we can do it all  \xe2\x80\x94  be focused, frightened and frivolous. We can\xe2\x80\x99t. We don\xe2\x80\x99t have the money. We don\xe2\x80\x99t have the time.'b'WHEN The Times interviewed Michael Chertoff about airport security after the underwear bomber 'b'tried to blow up'b' a passenger jet on Christmas Day, he 'b'said'b' full-body scanners should be deployed at airports. Chertoff, the former secretary of homeland security, did not volunteer that he is a consultant to a company that makes such equipment, and though they spoke to him twice, reporters never asked if he had a financial stake in the matter.'b'Peter Galbraith, a former diplomat, wrote several Op-Ed columns a few years ago supporting a strong and independent Kurdistan. The editors who published his pieces learned only in November \xe2\x80\x94 from 'b'a front-page article'b' \xe2\x80\x94 that Galbraith\xe2\x80\x99s business ties to a Norwegian oil company operating in Kurdistan positioned him to earn millions.'b''b'Jonathan Gruber'b', a prominent M.I.T. health economist, wrote an Op-Ed 'b'column'b' and was quoted frequently in other Times columns, news articles and blogs on health care reform before it came to light that he had a 'b'contract'b' worth nearly $400,000  to analyze health proposals for the Obama administration.'b''b'Neil Sadick'b', a famed Manhattan dermatologist, was quoted in a 'b'Skin Deep column'b' discussing electronic devices for the home treatment of acne, but the article did not say that Sadick has a business relationship with a company that makes one of the devices.'b'These examples have resulted in five embarrassing editors\xe2\x80\x99 notes in the last two months \xe2\x80\x94 two of them last week \xe2\x80\x94 each of them saying readers should have been informed of the undisclosed interest.  And on Thursday,  the standards editor sent Times journalists a memo urging them to be \xe2\x80\x9cconstantly alert\xe2\x80\x9d to the outside interests of expert sources.  The cases raised timeless issues for journalists and sources about what readers have a right to know and whose responsibility it is to find it out or disclose it.'b'The ideal expert source is entirely independent, with no stake in an outcome. But in reality, the most informed sources often have involvements, which is why they know what they know. Readers are entitled to disclosure so they can decide if there is a conflict that would affect the credibility of the information.'b'But each recent Times case showed how tricky it can be to navigate the ethics of disclosure.'b'Chertoff, who championed full-body scanners as head of the Department of Homeland Security, long before he went into private business, said it was no secret that he had become a consultant to corporate clients through 'b'the Chertoff Group'b', a risk-management firm he formed in March. He said that when two Times reporters, 'b'Eric Lipton'b'and 'b'John Schwartz'b', called and the subject turned to scanners, it was up to them to ask whether he had ties to that industry. \xe2\x80\x9cI always answer when I\xe2\x80\x99m asked,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cBut I don\xe2\x80\x99t think it is my obligation to put myself in the head of a reporter\xe2\x80\x9d to decide what the reporter needs to know.'b'Chertoff did tell NPR and CNN interviewers when they asked.'b'Lipton and Schwartz agreed that they should have asked Chertoff, but both expressed disappointment that he did not volunteer obviously germane information. 'b'Bob Steele'b', a professor at DePauw University and a journalism values scholar at the Poynter Institute, said, \xe2\x80\x9cI believe a source does have an affirmative obligation to reveal any competing loyalties, even if the source isn\xe2\x80\x99t sure they create a direct conflict of interest.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Interestingly, Chertoff wrote 'b'an Op-Ed article'b' for The Washington Post, published New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Day, that carried a one-sentence biography divulging that his clients included a scanner manufacturer \xe2\x80\x94 a note he said he volunteered.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf I\xe2\x80\x99m affirmatively getting out there,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as opposed to being called by a reporter, \xe2\x80\x9cI make it my business to disclose.\xe2\x80\x9d That\xe2\x80\x99s a distinction I don\xe2\x80\x99t buy. What difference does it make whether a source seeks a forum or a reporter happens to call? Knowing Washington\xe2\x80\x99s culture of revolving doors and news spin, the Times reporters should have asked the obvious question. But if Chertoff had a connection he thought the public needed to know in one instance, he should have made it clear in the others.'b'Galbraith said he regretted not telling Times editors that he had business interests in Kurdistan when he wrote Op-Ed columns published 'b'in 2005'b' and 'b'2006.'b' He did provide a vague disclosure for 'b'one in 2007'b'. But he disputed the 'b'November editors\xe2\x80\x99  note'b' that said he could have benefited from an independent Kurdistan because he had a stake in an oil field there.'b'He said his support of an independent Kurdistan was against the interests of 'b'DNO International'b', the oil company with which he had a relationship, because it had invested $300 million in Iraq, expecting it to remain unified. \xe2\x80\x9cI did not promote or discuss matters of specific interest to my clients and, indeed, my generally pessimistic view of Iraq\xe2\x80\x99s future was not consistent with the interests of companies trying to attract investors for projects in the country,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'Galbraith asked where the line was if an Op-Ed contributor was writing about political issues in a country where he also had economic interests. Because politics and economics so often go hand in hand, I would say someone in his shoes should disclose all interests to editors and discuss whether any pose a conflict that needs to be disclosed to readers. That is what The Times requires of all Op-Ed columnists, in plain, written language.'b'Gruber, the health care economist, wrote an Op-Ed column in July supporting an excise tax on so-called Cadillac health plans. Not long before, he had signed a contract with the Department of Health and Human Services to analyze the economic impact of various health care proposals in Congress. He did not tell Op-Ed editors, nor was the contract mentioned on at least 12 other occasions when he was quoted in The Times after he was consulting for the administration. After a 'b'blogger reported'b' on Gruber\xe2\x80\x99s government contract on the Daily Kos Web site, Gruber did volunteer it to Steven Greenhouse, a Times reporter interviewing him for an article on the excise tax. Greenhouse said he included the fact in a draft but struck it because the article was too long.  Greenhouse said that Gruber\xe2\x80\x99s views on the tax were so well-known that he did not think they would be influenced by a consulting contract. But had he realized how large the contract was, Greenhouse said, \xe2\x80\x9cI would have stood up and paid lots more attention.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Gruber said, \xe2\x80\x9cI guess it never occurred to me that the fact that I was doing technical modeling would matter.\xe2\x80\x9d He said he has long supported the tax and that the administration opposed it when he wrote his column, so he was hardly bending his views to a government paymaster.'b'Sometimes, there can be misunderstandings even when a reporter asks. Camille Sweeney, the freelancer who interviewed Sadick about acne treatments, said she asked the dermatologist a specific question: Had he been paid by any manufacturer for tests he performed on the products? He said he had not. But after the article was published, a Times editor recalled seeing an endorsement by Sadick for a hair removal product by one of the manufacturers.'b'What is the lesson from all this? Lipton said, \xe2\x80\x9cI do need to ask whenever I call a person for comment as an expert if they have any financial relationship with the topic.\xe2\x80\x9d He said he has posted a reminder on his computer: \xe2\x80\x9cAsk if hired gun.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The American Federation of Teachers, the second-largest teachers\xe2\x80\x99 union, has been working hard to distance itself from its competitor, the National Education Association, which tends to resist sensible reforms.'b'The federation\xe2\x80\x99s  president, Randi Weingarten, set the contrast quite effectively with a speech last week in Washington,  in which she offered a proposal to reform teacher evaluation. She not only echoed Education Secretary Arne Duncan\xe2\x80\x99s call for evaluation systems that take student achievement into account but also expressed support for \xe2\x80\x9ca fair, transparent and expedient process to identify and deal with ineffective teachers.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The shortcomings of evaluations were laid out last year in an eye-opening study by a New York research group, the New Teacher Project. Where they can be said to exist at all, evaluations are typically short, pro forma and almost universally positive. Poorly trained evaluators visit the classroom once or twice for observations that last for a total of an hour or less. Nearly every teacher passes and the overwhelming majority of teachers receive top ratings. Yet more than half the teachers surveyed said they knew a tenured teacher who deserved to be dismissed for poor performance.'b'The process shortchanges students, who are saddled with ineffective teachers. It also hurts the careers of the talented beginners who rarely get the help and guidance they need to become master teachers.'b'Ms. Weingarten called for a new collaboration between schools and unions that would replace this \xe2\x80\x9cperfunctory waste of time.\xe2\x80\x9d She called on the states to adopt basic professional teaching standards that would spell out what teachers should know and be able to do.'b'She rightly warned against using test scores in crude, statistically invalid ways, and proposed a sophisticated analysis to determine if students were showing real growth under a given teacher. Just as important, Ms. Weingarten said districts that so often take a sink-or-swim approach to teaching should develop support and mentoring programs that both improve teachers\xe2\x80\x99 abilities and keep them from leaving the profession.'b'These proposals should help to change the national conversation on the subject by putting pressure on the N.E.A. At the same time, critics of unions who are pleased to see Ms. Weingarten talk the talk will be watching closely in the coming months to see if she walks the walk.'b'Over the past year, the New York Mayor\xe2\x80\x99s Office of Special Enforcement has closed at least 64 of the storefront businesses that line the sidewalks of Canal Street from West Broadway to Lafayette Street, an area known as the Counterfeit Triangle. On one  recent night, 10 buildings and 31 stalls were shut down, and a daisy chain of undercover and uniformed police officers filled an 18-wheeler with garbage bags holding $1 million worth of knockoff merchandise.'b'If this turns out to be the end for the Counterfeit Triangle, we want to remember the Canal Street we\xe2\x80\x99ve always loved: a place notorious the world over for providing customers with what they want, for as cheaply as they want it.'b'Political theater and public scolding are good ways to draw attention to important issues and bad behavior, and Phil Angelides, chairman of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission, made use of both last week. As he swore in four of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s top bankers, it was impossible not to think of that famous scene with executives from the tobacco industry. During the questioning, he rebuked Lloyd Blankfein, head of Goldman Sachs, for his firm\xe2\x80\x99s practice of selling mortgage-related securities and at the same time betting they would fall in value.'b'Now that he has everyone\xe2\x80\x99s attention, Mr. Angelides and his fellow commissioners can get to the hard part.'b'Inconclusive sparring at hearings will not fulfill the mandate Congress gave the panel to investigate the causes of the crisis. Indeed, the bankers who testified last week did not say much they had not said before.'b'The commission must uncover what bankers, investors, government officials and other people in positions of power, past and present, would prefer not to say \xe2\x80\x94 or perhaps do not know or understand \xe2\x80\x94 about the crash and the bailouts. The primary aim is not to air issues and foster debate, but to test views, resolve contradictions and arrive at evidence-based conclusions.'b'Yet the commission \xe2\x80\x94 which is supposed to file a final report by Dec. 15 \xe2\x80\x94 has not issued a single subpoena for documents. Instead, investigators have apparently been relying on voluntary cooperation, public records and information-sharing agreements that have been negotiated with federal agencies. A thorough investigation requires source documents that reveal what people were thinking and doing at the time of the events and that illuminate, buttress or contradict testimony.'b'Take, for example, Mr. Blankfein\xe2\x80\x99s explanation that the clients Goldman bet against were sophisticated investors who demanded the doomed securities that Goldman sold them. Apart from the fact that the notion of \xe2\x80\x9csophisticated investors\xe2\x80\x9d has been discredited by the crisis, does that explanation go far enough?'b'Without peering into the internal workings of Goldman and other financial firms that engaged in similar practices, it is hard to know how far bankers went in creating demand rather than responding to it, or if the securities were purposely designed to perform poorly.'b'The answers could cast light on when Wall Street practices cross the line from prudent hedging to excessive speculation.'b'A crucial related issue is whether Wall Street\xe2\x80\x99s role as the underwriter of securities, which implies a level of approval of the investments being offered for sale, misled investors into buying questionable securities, and thus contributed to the credit bubble. If so, that would make the argument for barring too-big-to-fail banks from operating hedge funds all the more compelling.'b'Given the stakes, the chances seem remote that Wall Street will voluntarily hand over the papers that could get to the bottom of it all.'b'The inquiry is getting under way at a critical moment. The House has passed a financial regulatory reform bill that was enfeebled in important respects by bank lobbyists. The Senate banking committee recently rejected a generally robust proposal by Senator Christopher Dodd. It has yet to produce an alternative, but it is likely that lobbying and partisan politics will generate a weak bill. President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s call for a new tax on big banks is a good idea, but must not pre-empt other needed changes, including a tax on bankers\xe2\x80\x99 bonuses and more direct regulation to limit the size of financial firms.'b'Serious investigative work is the only way to counter the banks\xe2\x80\x99 political power and alter the course of a reform effort that is headed in the wrong direction.'b'Barring marriage by same-sex couples is not the only way that New York State\xe2\x80\x99s policies on marriage are stuck in the past and inflict needless pain.'b'In 2006, a special blue-ribbon state commission sensibly called for overhauling state law to allow no-fault divorce.
