Their goal was to eliminate birth defects, but increasing the number of biological parents beyond two could add a futuristic twist to an area where the law already is a mess: the question of who, in this age of artificial insemination and surrogacy, should be considered the legal parents of a baby.'b'Researchers at the Oregon National Primate Research Center were looking for ways to eliminate diseases that can be inherited through maternal DNA. They developed, as the magazine Nature reported last summer, a kind of swap in which defective DNA from the egg is removed and replaced with genetic material from another female\xe2\x80\x99s egg. The researchers say the procedure is also likely to work on humans.'b'The result would be a baby with three biological parents \xe2\x80\x94 or \xe2\x80\x9cfractional parents,\xe2\x80\x9d as Adam Kolber, a professor at the University of San Diego School of Law, calls them.'b'He mentioned the idea over lunch at The Times, and it provided plenty of grist for debate among law junkies: Could a baby one day have 100 parents? Could anyone who contributes DNA claim visitation rights? How much DNA is enough? Can a child born outside the United States to foreigners who have DNA from an American citizen claim U.S. citizenship?'b'One reason these questions are so difficult to resolve definitively is that, even in simpler cases, the law of parenthood is badly muddled. That has been true since the 1980s saga of Baby M.'b'Mary Beth Whitehead had agreed to a payment of $10,000 to bear a child for William and Elizabeth Stern. The baby girl was conceived with Whitehead\xe2\x80\x99s egg and Mr. Stern\xe2\x80\x99s sperm. After the birth, Ms. Whitehead sued to keep the baby.'b'The New Jersey Supreme Court declared Ms. Whitehead \xe2\x80\x9cthe legal mother\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cnot to be penalized one iota because of the surrogate contract.\xe2\x80\x9d But it allowed the Sterns to raise the child.'b'In 1993, California came out the other way in a dispute between Crispina and Mark Calvert and a woman they had hired to carry a baby produced with their egg and sperm. All three courts that heard the case ruled for the Calverts, but each gave a different reason. The California Supreme Court finally decided that the person who intended to create the child and to raise it was the mother \xe2\x80\x94 in this case, Ms. Calvert.'b'There is confusion nationwide. Some states have laws expressly permitting surrogate parenthood; others make it illegal; and others have no law at all.'b'The problem, as Janet Dolgin, a Hofstra Law School professor, wrote in the Akron Law Review, is that legal thinking is deeply divided over how to judge what makes a family.'b'Since the 1960s, there has been a shift toward recognizing people\xe2\x80\x99s intent in creating familial relationships, as reflected in the rise of no-fault divorce, prenuptial agreements and civil unions. But when it comes to deciding parenthood, courts remain deeply influenced by biology, even when it clashes with intent.'b'This concern is playing out now in A.G.R. v. D.R.H. &amp; S.H., the biggest surrogacy case in New Jersey since Baby M\xe2\x80\x99s. A woman served as a surrogate for her brother and his male spouse, giving birth to twins conceived with the spouse\xe2\x80\x99s sperm and donor eggs. She signed a contract agreeing that her brother would adopt the children, but the trial court, saying it was following the Baby M decision, ruled that the spouse and the surrogate mother are the legal parents. The surrogate\xe2\x80\x99s brother was given no parental rights.'b'When technology transforms a legal field \xe2\x80\x94 as the Internet is doing now for privacy, and digital music and video are doing for copyright \xe2\x80\x94 judges and legal thinkers have to decide what are the important values.'b'Parenthood cannot be reduced to a formula, but the law should move toward a greater recognition that the intent of the people involved is more important than the genes. That would provide useful guidance for courts to think about fractional parents \xe2\x80\x94 especially if the day comes when three or more people want to combine their DNA to create a baby.'b'Who is Barack Obama?'b'Americans are still looking for the answer, and if they don\xe2\x80\x99t get it soon  \xe2\x80\x94  or if they don\xe2\x80\x99t like the answer  \xe2\x80\x94  the president\xe2\x80\x99s current political problems will look like a walk in the park.'b'Mr. Obama may be personally very appealing, but he has positioned himself all over the political map: the anti-Iraq war candidate who escalated the war in Afghanistan; the opponent of health insurance mandates who made a mandate to buy insurance the centerpiece of his plan; the president who stocked his administration with Wall Street insiders and went to the mat for the banks and big corporations, but who is now trying to present himself as a born-again populist.'b'Mr. Obama is in danger of being perceived as someone whose rhetoric, however skillful, cannot always be trusted. He is creating a credibility gap for himself, and if it widens much more he won\xe2\x80\x99t be able to close it.'b'Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s campaign mantra was \xe2\x80\x9cchange\xe2\x80\x9d and most of his supporters took that to mean that he would change the way business was done in Washington and that he would reverse the disastrous economic policies that favored mega-corporations and the very wealthy at the expense of the middle class and the poor.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cTonight, more Americans are out of work, and more are working harder for less,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Obama in his acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention in August 2008. \xe2\x80\x9cMore of you have lost your homes and even more are watching your home values plummet. More of you have cars you can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to drive, credit card bills you can\xe2\x80\x99t afford to pay, and tuition that\xe2\x80\x99s beyond your reach.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Voters watching the straight-arrow candidate delivering that speech, in the midst of the worst economic crisis since the Depression, would not logically have thought that an obsessive focus on health insurance would trump job creation as the top domestic priority of an Obama administration.'b'But that\xe2\x80\x99s what happened. Moreover, questions were raised about Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s candor when he spoke about health care. In his acceptance speech, for example, candidate Obama took a verbal shot at John McCain, sharply criticizing him for offering \xe2\x80\x9ca health care plan that would actually tax people\xe2\x80\x99s benefits.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Now Mr. Obama favors a plan that would tax at least some people\xe2\x80\x99s benefits. Mr. Obama also repeatedly said that policyholders who were pleased with their plans and happy with their doctors would be able to keep both under his reform proposals.'b'Well, that wasn\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily so, as the president eventually acknowledged. There would undoubtedly be changes in some people\xe2\x80\x99s coverage as a result of \xe2\x80\x9creform,\xe2\x80\x9d and some of those changes would be substantial. At a forum sponsored by ABC News last summer, Mr. Obama backed off of his frequent promise that no changes would occur, saying only that \xe2\x80\x9cif you are happy with your plan, and if you are happy with your doctor, we don\xe2\x80\x99t want you to have to change.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'These less-than-candid instances are emblematic of much bigger problems. Mr. Obama promised during the campaign that he would be a different kind of president, one who would preside over a more open, more high-minded administration that would be far more in touch with the economic needs of ordinary working Americans. But no sooner was he elected than he put together an economic team that would protect, above all, the interests of Wall Street, the pharmaceutical industry, the health insurance companies, and so on.'b'How can you look out for the interests of working people with Tim Geithner whispering in one ear and Larry Summers in the other?'b'Now with his poll numbers down and the Democrats\xe2\x80\x99 filibuster-proof margin in the Senate about to vanish, Mr. Obama is trying again to position himself as a champion of the middle class. Suddenly, with the public appalled at the scandalous way the health care legislation was put together, and with Democrats facing a possible debacle in the fall, Mr. Obama is back in campaign mode. Every other utterance is about \xe2\x80\x9cfighting\xe2\x80\x9d for the middle class, \xe2\x80\x9cfighting\xe2\x80\x9d for jobs, \xe2\x80\x9cfighting\xe2\x80\x9d against the big bad banks.'b'The president who has been aloof and remote and a pushover for the health insurance and pharmaceutical industries, who has been locked in the troubling embrace of the Geithners and Summers and Ben Bernankes of the world, all of a sudden is a man of the people. But even as he is promising to fight for jobs, a very expensive proposition, he\xe2\x80\x99s proposing a spending freeze that can only hurt job-creating efforts.'b'Mr. Obama will deliver his State of the Union address Wednesday night. The word is that he will offer some small bore assistance to the middle class. But more important than the content of this speech will be whether the president really means what he says. Americans want to know what he stands for, where his line in the sand is, what he\xe2\x80\x99ll really fight for, and where he wants to lead this nation.'b'They want to know who their president really is.'b'Politics, some believe, is the organization of hatreds. The people who try to divide society on the basis of ethnicity we call racists. The people who try to divide it on the basis of religion we call sectarians. The people who try to divide it on the basis of social class we call either populists or elitists.'b'These two attitudes \xe2\x80\x94 populism and elitism \xe2\x80\x94 seem different, but they\xe2\x80\x99re really mirror images of one another. They both assume a country fundamentally divided. They both describe politics as a class struggle between the enlightened and the corrupt, the pure and the betrayers.'b'Both attitudes will always be with us, but these days populism is in vogue. The Republicans have their populists. Sarah Palin has been known to divide the country between the real Americans and the cultural elites. And the Democrats have their populists. Since the defeat in Massachusetts, many Democrats have apparently decided that their party has to mimic the rhetoric of John Edwards\xe2\x80\x99s presidential campaign. They\xe2\x80\x99ve taken to dividing the country into two supposedly separate groups \xe2\x80\x94 real Americans who live on Main Street and the insidious interests of Wall Street.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s easy to see why politicians would be drawn to the populist pose. First, it makes everything so simple. The economic crisis was caused by a complex web of factors, including global imbalances caused by the rise of China. But with the populist narrative, you can just blame Goldman Sachs.'b'Second, it absolves voters of responsibility for their problems. Over the past few years, many investment bankers behaved like idiots, but so did average Americans, racking up unprecedented levels of personal debt. With the populist narrative, you can accuse the former and absolve the latter.'b'Third, populism is popular with the ruling class. Ever since I started covering politics, the Democratic ruling class has been driven by one fantasy: that voters will get so furious at people with M.B.A.\xe2\x80\x99s that they will hand power to people with Ph.D.\xe2\x80\x99s. The Republican ruling class has been driven by the fantasy that voters will get so furious at people with Ph.D.\xe2\x80\x99s that they will hand power to people with M.B.A.\xe2\x80\x99s. Members of the ruling class love populism because they think it will help their section of the elite gain power.'b'So it\xe2\x80\x99s easy to see the seductiveness of populism. Nonetheless, it nearly always fails. The history of populism, going back to William Jennings Bryan, is generally a history of defeat.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s because voters aren\xe2\x80\x99t as stupid as the populists imagine. Voters are capable of holding two ideas in their heads at one time: First, that the rich and the powerful do rig the game in their own favor; and second, that simply bashing the rich and the powerful will still not solve the country\xe2\x80\x99s problems.'b'Political populists never get that second point. They can\xe2\x80\x99t seem to grasp that a politics based on punishing the elites won\xe2\x80\x99t produce a better-educated work force, more investment, more innovation or any of the other things required for progress and growth.'b'In fact, this country was built by anti-populists. It was built by people like Alexander Hamilton and Abraham Lincoln who rejected the idea that the national economy is fundamentally divided along class lines. They rejected the zero-sum mentality that is at the heart of populism, the belief that economics is a struggle over finite spoils. Instead, they believed in a united national economy \xe2\x80\x94 one interlocking system of labor, trade and investment.'b'Hamilton championed capital markets and Lincoln championed banks, not because they loved traders and bankers. They did it because they knew a vibrant capitalist economy would maximize opportunity for poor boys like themselves. They were willing to tolerate the excesses of traders because they understood that no institution is more likely to channel opportunity to new groups and new people than vigorous financial markets.'b'In their view, government\xe2\x80\x99s role was not to side with one faction or to wage class war. It was to rouse the energy and industry of people at all levels. It was to enhance competition and make it fair \xe2\x80\x94 to make sure that no group, high or low, is able to erect barriers that would deprive Americans of an open field and a fair chance. Theirs was a philosophy that celebrated development, mobility and work, wherever those things might be generated.'b'The populists have an Us versus Them mentality. If they continue their random attacks on enterprise and capital, they will only increase the pervasive feeling of uncertainty, which is now the single biggest factor in holding back investment, job creation and growth. They will end up discrediting good policies (the Obama bank reforms are quite sensible) because they will persuade the country that the government is in the hands of reckless Huey Longs.'b'They will have traded dynamic optimism, which always wins, for combative divisiveness, which always loses.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Jamaica High May Close, but Memories Will Live On'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Jan. 24):'b'I, too, benefited from a fine education at Jamaica High School. I, too, mourn its imminent demise as New York City prepares to close it along with other ailing public schools. But let us temper our nostalgia with a reality check.'b'Jamaica High in its heyday thrived in a different city. It was a zoned neighborhood school, its boundaries surely deliberately drawn to include middle-class and wealthy white neighborhoods and exclude poor black neighborhoods nearby. I went through my yearbook the other day and saw that out of 1,050 students in my 1963 graduating class, 40 were African-American \xe2\x80\x94 less than 4 percent. Our class had a smattering of Asian students \xe2\x80\x94 I counted seven \xe2\x80\x94 and even fewer students with apparently Latino names.'b'New York\xe2\x80\x99s neighborhoods were even more segregated then than they are today, and the public schools reflected that. But the segregation at Jamaica went even further. The stronger academic students studied together in honors classes, more solidly white (and Jewish because Jamaica\xe2\x80\x99s zoned catchment area was overwhelmingly Jewish) than the school at large.'b'We honors students attended the equivalent of a private school within a restricted school, taught by the best, most dedicated teachers on the faculty. Our principal, a demanding, old-line disciplinarian, saw to that, focusing on the strong academic students \xe2\x80\x94 encouraging them to apply to the Ivy League and to compete in national science contests \xe2\x80\x94 and ignoring the rest.'b'Small wonder that the neighborhood\xe2\x80\x99s most affluent parents sent their children to Jamaica High instead of private schools.'b'Jamaica High was once a great place \xe2\x80\x94 for some. We can remember it fondly, but see it for what it was \xe2\x80\x94 an educational artifact of an era long gone.'b'Joyce Purnick'b'\n  New York, Jan. 25, 2010'b''b''b'The writer, a former columnist and editor at The New York Times, is the author of \xe2\x80\x9cMike Bloomberg: Money, Power, Politics.\xe2\x80\x9d 'b''b'To the Editor:'b'In \xe2\x80\x9c'b'A Leaner Budget for Lean Times'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (editorial, Jan. 20), you call mixed martial arts, which Gov. David A. Paterson is proposing to legalize, \xe2\x80\x9ccontroversial.\xe2\x80\x9d In fact, the sport is not only legal in all but eight states, but if it should come to New York, our State Athletic Commission already has the mechanisms in place to ensure that such competitions follow the highest guidelines of health and safety.'b'Across the country, mixed martial arts matches do not represent something out of \xe2\x80\x9cFight Club\xe2\x80\x9d; rather, they are akin to boxing in how closely they are watched by highly trained medical staff and referees. Just like boxers, mixed martial arts competitors receive comprehensive neurological and physical examinations before fighting. They are drug-tested and are placed in strict weight classes, and all matches must be approved by a regulating body to reduce the likelihood of a mismatch resulting in serious injury.'b'In New York, a medical advisory board would be established and charged with developing educational programs for medical staff and officials, so that health risks may be readily identified, minimized and prevented.'b'In terms of revenue for the state, a recent study found that one event in the New York City area, for example, would generate $5.3 million in event spending and a total of $11.3 million in total economic activity for the local economy.'b'Governor Paterson understands that this is a sport that when properly regulated will provide the citizens of New York with both financial and entertainment value while maintaining high standards regarding the safety and health of participants.'b'Lorraine Cortes-Vazquez'b'\n  Secretary of State'b'\n  Albany, Jan. 20, 2010'b''b''b'It would be a terrible mistake for Democrats to abandon comprehensive health care reform just because voters in the Massachusetts Senate race last week decided that they liked the Republican, Scott Brown, more than the Democrat, Martha Coakley.'b'There is no question that without a filibuster-proof majority it will be a lot harder to pass a bill. But it should not be impossible if Congressional Democrats and the White House show courage and creativity. Health care reform is too important to throw away, and it is not too late to persuade voters that it is in their interest.'b'Congress is achingly close to passing legislation that would cover most uninsured Americans and provide much more security for all Americans \xe2\x80\x94 guaranteeing that if they lose their jobs they will be able to buy affordable policies and can\xe2\x80\x99t be denied coverage because of pre-existing conditions.'b'If the Democrats quit now, so close to the goal line, the opportunity for large-scale reform could be lost for years. Meanwhile, the number of uninsured, currently more than 46 million, will keep going up and the cost of health care will continue to soar.'b'Many panicky Democrats see Mr. Brown\xe2\x80\x99s win as proof that angry voters will punish them in November if they press ahead with reform. We believe that is a misreading of what happened and what\xe2\x80\x99s possible.'b'Ms. Coakley ran an inept campaign. And the White House hasn\xe2\x80\x99t done enough to address voters\xe2\x80\x99 profound and legitimate fears about losing their jobs and their homes. But President Obama and Congressional Democrats have also clearly failed to explain why reform will make Americans\xe2\x80\x99 lives more secure \xe2\x80\x94 not less.'b'What makes this all the more frustrating is that Massachusetts, which adopted its own very similar health care reform in 2006, is a compelling example of both the benefits and popularity of the effort.'b'A 'b'poll taken in Massachusetts'b' after the election by The Washington Post, the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation and the Harvard School of Public Health found that a surprising 68 percent of those who had voted said that they supported their own state\xe2\x80\x99s plan, including slightly more than half of those who had voted for Mr. Brown.'b'Mr. Brown, who promised to block reform in Washington, voted for his state\xe2\x80\x99s program in 2006 and did not campaign against it this year. Instead, he argued that since Massachusetts\xe2\x80\x99 citizens already have coverage, why should they help pay to expand coverage elsewhere.'b'That cynical I\xe2\x80\x99ve-got-mine argument doesn\xe2\x80\x99t make a lot of sense \xe2\x80\x94  even in Massachusetts. The Senate bill would funnel additional money into the Massachusetts program and federal efforts to rein in costs should ultimately benefit all of the states.'b'Democrats should take another look at what really happened in Massachusetts and then summon the nerve to enact comprehensive reform. They must make clear to voters that they have little to fear. Even the mandate requiring everyone to buy insurance doesn\xe2\x80\x99t kick in until 2014. And they must make clear that reform offers immediate gains, especially for middle-class Americans.'b'Once the bill becomes law, many dependent children could remain on their parents\xe2\x80\x99 policies until age 26. Insurers would no longer be able to set lifetime caps on the amount they will pay for health care. Children could not be denied coverage because of pre-existing conditions. The gap in drug coverage for Medicare beneficiaries, known as the doughnut hole, would begin to close. And small businesses would immediately get tax credits to cover their employees.'b'Recent polls show that the public is divided, with more opposing the bills than favoring them. The negatives have been driven up by critics\xe2\x80\x99 distortions about a supposed government takeover of medicine and the tawdry deal-making necessary to win 60 votes to overcome a Republican filibuster in the Senate.'b'Still, 'b'a recent national poll'b' by the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation found that large shares of people became more supportive when told about such provisions as tax credits for small businesses that offer coverage, exchanges where people could choose among competing policies, and rules against denying coverage.'b'We are hearing a lot of talk in Washington, including from President Obama, about possibly paring down the current bills \xe2\x80\x94 to cover many fewer of the uninsured and focus instead on reeling in the worst abuses of the insurance industry and reining in health care costs. That could be difficult technically; many of the parts are not easy to disentangle without undermining their effectiveness. And the politics on Capitol Hill \xe2\x80\x94 where the Republicans are determined to oppose pretty much anything President Obama endorses \xe2\x80\x94 are unlikely to get easier.'b'The most promising path forward would be for House Democrats to pass the Senate bill as is and send it to the president for his signature. That would allow the administration and Congress to pivot immediately to job creation and other economic issues. The Senate bill is not perfect, but it would expand coverage to 94 percent of all citizens and legal residents by 2019, reduce the deficit for decades to come, and create pilot programs to move the medical system toward better care at lower costs.'b'Rank-and-file House Democrats apparently won\xe2\x80\x99t accept the Senate bill without modification. So Congressional leaders are looking for ways to commit both the House and the Senate to changes  \xe2\x80\x94 such as better subsidies to make insurance more affordable \xe2\x80\x94 that could be approved through parallel \xe2\x80\x9cbudget reconciliation\xe2\x80\x9d legislation that could be approved by a simple majority in both the Senate and House.'b'This is a once-in-a-generation chance. President Obama must explain to the American people why reform is essential to their health and security and this nation\xe2\x80\x99s future. And he must insist that Congress finish the job.'b'\xc2\x95'b''b'This editorial is a part of a comprehensive examination of the debate over health care reform. You can read all of these articles at: 'b'nytimes.com/editorials'b'.'b''b'Because of a disagreement over charter schools, legislative leaders in Albany are in danger \xe2\x80\x94 once again \xe2\x80\x94 of letting hundreds of millions of federal dollars slip through their fingers.'b'Washington is making $4 billion in education funds available under a program called Race to the Top. The money is aimed at encouraging states to improve or close failing schools, keep the most-qualified teachers and expand well-run charter schools. New York\xe2\x80\x99s share could be as much as $700 million.  The deadline for state applications was last Tuesday,  and most states jumped at the opportunity. New York submitted its application, but it lacked a crucial ingredient: a plan that would allow for more charter schools.'b'A bill favored by legislative leaders would have doubled the number of charter schools allowed in the state to 400. But the bill was flawed and faced an almost certain veto from Gov. David Paterson. The big problem was that it would have undercut the schools\xe2\x80\x99 independence by transferring the power to create charter schools from local authorities to the Board of Regents, which is appointed by the Legislature.'b'This shift particularly offended Mayor Michael Bloomberg. He called the bill a \xe2\x80\x9cwolf in sheep\xe2\x80\x99s clothing.\xe2\x80\x9d It would definitely have been a step backward from a system that has mostly worked well, especially in New York City. Charter schools are not without flaws. Their finances should be more transparent. And public-school parents often resent sharing much-needed space with charter schools. But none of these criticisms are a reason for Albany to undercut the whole system or give up on federal funds, especially during a state budget crisis.'b'A second round of applications for federal aid is due this summer. By then, the Legislature should be able to organize hearings and come up with a plan for the entire state. Otherwise, New York runs the risk of forfeiting, once again, money it needs badly. In 2008, Albany failed to approve even an experimental version of Mayor Bloomberg\xe2\x80\x99s congestion pricing plan that would have imposed fees on cars coming into Manhattan during rush hours. That cost the city millions of dollars in federal transportation funds. New York can\xe2\x80\x99t afford a repeat performance.'b'Washington'b'WITH the national unemployment rate at 10 percent, and more than 15 million Americans looking for work,  ideas to spur job creation are at the forefront of everyone\xe2\x80\x99s minds. While we may represent different political philosophies, we recognize that high unemployment \xe2\x80\x94 particularly long-term unemployment \xe2\x80\x94 is not a liberal problem or a conservative problem; it\xe2\x80\x99s a national problem that takes a huge toll on families.'b'The idea for some sort of jobs tax credit is percolating again, but the jobs credit that existed in the late 1970s was of limited success, and it was excruciatingly complicated. Recalling this experience, members of Congress from both parties have been lukewarm to such a credit, and the idea was dropped from the stimulus package last year.'b'We have an idea that is simple, straightforward and easy to explain and administer. In fact, it is so simple that the legislative text of the proposal is only a few pages long \xe2\x80\x94 a rarity when it comes to tax policy.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s the idea: Starting immediately after enactment, any private-sector employer that hires a worker who had been unemployed for at least 60 days will not have to pay its 6.2 percent Social Security payroll tax on that employee for the duration of 2010. The Social Security trust fund will then be made whole with spending cuts elsewhere in the budget between now and 2015. That\xe2\x80\x99s it. Simple to understand, and easy to explain.'b'The beauty of this proposal goes beyond its simplicity. Unlike a jobs tax credit of a specific dollar amount, this credit is \xe2\x80\x9cfront-loaded\xe2\x80\x9d in that it provides an incentive for businesses to hire workers earlier in the year \xe2\x80\x94 because the tax benefit will be greater. A $60,000 worker hired on Feb. 1 will save a business about $3,400 in taxes, while that same worker hired on  May 1 will save it about $2,500.'b'Unlike some versions of a payroll-tax holiday, which provide a much bigger benefit for higher-paid workers, this proposal is not biased toward either low-wage or high-wage workers. Yes, if you pay people more, you save more in taxes \xe2\x80\x94 but the savings as a percentage of pay remains constant. Under this plan, a business saves 6.2 percent on both a $40,000 worker and a $90,000 worker.'b'In the current environment, no business wants to wait until 2011 to receive a tax credit for someone it hires today. Another obvious benefit of this proposal to forgive payroll taxes is that it keeps  money in a business\xe2\x80\x99s pockets, since the tax is simply not collected in the first place.'b'In addition, because the benefit starts on the date of hiring and does not have an arbitrary cap, more businesses will want to use it. And since it is an elimination of the employer\xe2\x80\x99s share of the Social Security  tax for these workers \xe2\x80\x94 rather than a fixed or capped dollar amount \xe2\x80\x94 the complexities of making the incentive work with a firm\xe2\x80\x99s payroll software are greatly reduced because employers will know simply to zero out the tax for these workers.'b'To promote long-term employment as the recovery gains steam, we would also add the following bonus: For any eligible employee kept on payroll for a continuous 52 weeks, the employer would receive an additional $1,000 credit on its 2011 tax return. (This would apply to any worker hired in 2010.)'b'Our two-pronged approach would be a far more efficient use of taxpayer dollars than other proposals  under discussion, all of which could cost many times more with very little guaranteed improvement in unemployment.'b'Imagine that three million unemployed workers were to be hired this year under our plan. If they all worked an average of six months in 2010 at a salary of $50,000, and every single one stayed on payroll for 52 consecutive weeks into 2011, the gross cost of the Social Security tax cut and the additional credit would be only $7.6 billion. And that\xe2\x80\x99s before we consider the offsets from income and payroll taxes paid by these workers.'b'There are some additional rules that would have to be put in place. For example, eligible workers would have to be hired for a minimum of 30 hours per week, and workers who are family members of the employer would not be eligible. The payroll tax reduction would be for private-sector jobs only; new jobs that are created by tax dollars in the first place would not be eligible. And any employer with a lower total payroll in 2010 than it had in 2009 would have to forfeit the benefit \xe2\x80\x94 businesses shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be allowed to shed jobs and still receive a tax benefit.'b'We urge Congress and President Obama to consider this idea to help jumpstart hiring and turn our focus back on jobs.'b'Washington'b'IN just seven years, the Supreme Court has declared most of the fabled McCain-Feingold law unconstitutional. The court has struck down the law\xe2\x80\x99s bans on contributions by minors, on independent spending by political parties and on issue ads within 30 days of a primary or 60 days of a general election, as well as restrictions on \xe2\x80\x9cmillionaire\xe2\x80\x9d candidates. With last week\xe2\x80\x99s ruling in 'b'Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission'b', the court has now declared that corporations and unions may spend money on political advertising that urges the election or defeat of a candidate for public office.'b'The reaction was swift and intense. Conservatives and libertarians praised the ruling\xe2\x80\x99s preservation of the First Amendment and freedom of speech. Liberals and reformers expressed horror. 'b'President Obama predicted'b' a \xe2\x80\x9cstampede of special-interest money in our politics\xe2\x80\x9d  and 'b'declared'b', \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t think of anything more devastating to the public interest.\xe2\x80\x9d (Disclosure: I filed a brief with the Supreme Court in support of Citizens United.)'b'One would think from all this that corporations and unions are now free to buy candidates on the open market. But what, if anything, will be different in our elections?'b'Will corporations and unions be able to give money to candidates or political parties? No. Federal law, which regulates campaigns for president, the Senate and the House, prohibits such contributions. The ban was left untouched by the Supreme Court.'b'Can corporations spend money in cahoots with candidates and political parties? No. The Supreme Court decision addressed only \xe2\x80\x9cindependent expenditures,\xe2\x80\x9d which are, by definition, \xe2\x80\x9cnot coordinated with a candidate.\xe2\x80\x9d Monies spent in collaboration with candidates or parties are treated as contributions \xe2\x80\x94 and are still banned.'b'Perhaps all of this corporate spending will be secret? Wrong again. The Supreme Court upheld the laws that require any corporate or union spender to file reports with the Federal Election Commission within 24 hours of spending the first dime.'b'What about the \xe2\x80\x9cstampede of special-interest money\xe2\x80\x9d? The president\xe2\x80\x99s comment implies there must not have been any corporate or union spending before Citizens United. In fact, in the final days of the Massachusetts special election for senator, corporations and unions spent at least $2.7 million on television and radio advertising.  How do we know? Those reports were filed with the F.E.C. And while this was a good deal of spending, it was not unusual.'b'So what will actually occur as a result of the Citizens United case? The answer is at once mundane and momentous.'b'Since the 1970s, Congress has passed an assortment of laws that banned anyone from spending money on independent ads \xe2\x80\x94 laws that were uniformly declared unconstitutional when they restricted spending by individuals, political action committees and political parties. But in a 1990 decision, 'b'Austin v. Michigan Chamber of Commerce'b', the court upheld a ban on corporate spending to expressly advocate the election or defeat of a candidate.'b'Because of the 1990 ruling, corporations and unions have been limited to so-called issue ads, which usually end with statements like \xe2\x80\x9ccall Candidate Jones and tell her\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 take your choice \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cto stop raising taxes/ support health care reform/ support alternative energy sources.\xe2\x80\x9d Now that Citizens United has overturned Austin, corporations and unions can run independent ads that contain words of express advocacy. So instead of \xe2\x80\x9cCall Candidate Jones and demand that she not  raise taxes,\xe2\x80\x9d it can be: \xe2\x80\x9cVote for Candidate Smith because Candidate Jones wants to raise taxes.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'There is also no factual basis to predict that there will be a \xe2\x80\x9cstampede\xe2\x80\x9d of additional spending. As the court noted, 26 states and the District of Columbia already permit independent corporate and union campaign spending. There have been no stampedes in those states\xe2\x80\x99 elections. Having a constitutional right is not the same as requiring one to exercise it, and there are many reasons  businesses and unions may not spend much more on politics than  they already do. As such, the effect of Citizens United on the  2010 campaigns is debatable.'b'However, the effect of Citizens United on further legislative meddling with campaign speech is clear. In recent years, Congress interpreted its power to regulate campaigns as a license to limit, restrict, burden and confuse anyone who wished to engage in political campaigns.'b'But the court has reminded us that the First Amendment is not a license to regulate \xe2\x80\x94 it is a limitation on Congress. As the court said in its ruling, \xe2\x80\x9cThe First Amendment does not permit laws that force speakers to retain a campaign finance attorney, conduct demographic marketing research, or seek declaratory rulings before discussing the most salient political issues of our day.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'While this may be disheartening to Washington lawyers and lawmakers, it should be a breath of fresh air to everyone else. The greatest benefit of Citizens United is that it will restrain Congress from flooding us with arcane, burdensome, convoluted campaign laws that discourage political participation.'b'The history of campaign finance reform is the history of incumbent politicians seeking to muzzle speakers, any speakers, particularly those who might publicly criticize them and their legislation. It is a lot easier to legislate against unions, gun owners, \xe2\x80\x9cfat cat\xe2\x80\x9d bankers, health insurance companies and any other industry or \xe2\x80\x9cspecial interest\xe2\x80\x9d group when they can\xe2\x80\x99t talk back.'b''b'Americans tend to think of the State of the Union as our singular event. But while it is a special night, it\xe2\x80\x99s  not  unique. In fact, leaders around the world   deliver a yearly address in which they step onto the podium to score points, lay out agendas and offer up a flourish or two. So how does American rhetoric measure up? No political gain can justify hate-mongering.'b'Radiation treatments have helped save the lives of countless cancer patients, but when medical personnel get sloppy and manufacturers fail to provide technical safeguards the results can be devastating. Two tragic cases at hospitals in New York City illustrate the dangers, and a look at cases elsewhere reinforces the feeling that much more needs to be done to protect patients.'b'The dark side of radiation therapy in an age when the technology is getting more powerful, complex and medically useful was laid bare in two investigative articles in The Times this week by Walt Bogdanich.'b'The first, 'b'published Sunday'b', described the plight of two patients who died in New York City after receiving extremely high doses of radiation from linear accelerators. Our economy is still very fragile, yet you would never know that by the way the political class is acting. We\xe2\x80\x99re like a patient that just got out of intensive care and is sitting up in bed for the first time when, suddenly, all the doctors and nurses at bedside start bickering. One of them throws a stethoscope across the room; someone else threatens to unplug all the monitors unless the hospital bills are paid by noon; and all the while the patient is thinking: \xe2\x80\x9cAre you people crazy? I am just starting to recover. Do you realize how easily I could relapse? Aren\xe2\x80\x99t there any adults here?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Sometimes you wonder: Are we home alone? Obviously, the political and financial elites to whom we give authority often act on the basis of personal interests. But we still have a long way to go to get out of the mess we are in, and if our elites do not behave with a greater sense of the common good we could find our economy doing a double dip with a back flip.'b'Dov Seidman, the C.E.O. of LRN, which helps companies build ethical cultures, likes to talk about two kinds of values: \xe2\x80\x9csituational values\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9csustainable values.\xe2\x80\x9d Leaders, companies or individuals guided by situational values do whatever the situation will allow, no matter the wider interests of their communities. A banker who writes a mortgage for someone he knows can\xe2\x80\x99t make the payments over time is acting on situational values, saying: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll be gone when the bill comes due.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'People inspired by sustainable values act just the opposite, saying: \xe2\x80\x9cI will never be gone. I will always be here. Therefore, I must behave in ways that sustain  \xe2\x80\x94  my employees, my customers, my suppliers, my environment, my country and my future generations.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Lately, we\xe2\x80\x99ve seen an explosion of situational thinking. I support the broad proposals President Obama put forth last week to prevent banks from becoming too big to fail and to protect taxpayers from banks that get in trouble by speculating and then expect us to bail them out. But the way the president unveiled his proposals  \xe2\x80\x94  \xe2\x80\x9cif those folks want a fight, it\xe2\x80\x99s a fight I\xe2\x80\x99m ready to have\xe2\x80\x9d  \xe2\x80\x94  left me feeling as though he was looking for a way to bash the banks right after the Democrats\xe2\x80\x99 loss in Massachusetts, in order to score a few cheap political points more than to initiate a serious national discussion about an incredibly complex issue.'b'President Obama is so much better when he takes a heated, knotty issue, like civil rights or banking reform, and talks to the country like adults. He is so much better at making us smarter than angrier. Going to war with the banks for a quick political sugar high after an electoral loss will just work against him and us. It will spook the banks into lending even less and slow the recovery even more.'b'That said, part of me can\xe2\x80\x99t blame the president. He absolutely deserves reappointment.'b'No doubt, this is a lousy season to be the leader of any institution. Without that, we\xe2\x80\x99ll just be digging our hole deeper and making the reckoning, when it comes, that much more ferocious.'b'We all have blind spots, and I think one of mine  \xe2\x80\x94  shared by many other Americans, perhaps including you  \xe2\x80\x94  has to do with prisons.'b'Over the years, I\xe2\x80\x99ve written many columns about Guant\xc3\xa1namo Bay, Abu Ghraib and torture, not to mention the abuses that go on in Chinese and North Korean prisons. But I\xe2\x80\x99ve never written about the horrors that unfold in American prisons  \xe2\x80\x94  especially juvenile correctional facilities  \xe2\x80\x94  on a far larger scale than at Guant\xc3\xa1namo.'b'Consider Rodney Hulin Jr., who was a 16-year-old when he was convicted of arson. A first-time offender and a slight figure at 5 feet 2 inches tall and some 125 pounds, he was sent to a men\xe2\x80\x99s prison. There, he was the smallest person around. Within a week, he was raped, according to an account by Human Rights Watch, an advocacy group. The prison doctor  ordered an H.I.V. test, since up to one-third of the inmates were H.I.V.-positive.'b'Rodney asked to be placed in protective custody, but he was denied. His father,  Rodney Hulin Sr., 'b'picks up the story'b': \xe2\x80\x9cFor the next several months, my son was repeatedly beaten by the older inmates, forced to perform oral sex, robbed, and beaten again. ... He could no longer stand to live in continual terror.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Rodney Jr. hanged himself.'b'Maybe Rodney would have been safer in a juvenile correctional facility, but then again maybe not. A stunning new Justice Department 'b'special report'b', released just this month, underscores how widespread rape is in youth correctional facilities. It found that almost one youth in eight reported being sexually assaulted while behind bars in the last year.'b'That means that a child in custody is about twice as likely to be raped as an adult behind bars, based on similar surveys of adult prisoners. As The New York Review of Books 'b'wrote on its blog'b', we face a \xe2\x80\x9ccrisis of juvenile prison rape.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The National Prison Rape Elimination Commission, a blue-ribbon panel that issued 'b'its final report'b' last year, described how a 14-year-old boy weighing 98 pounds was assaulted after he was made to share a cell with two older teenagers. Both were 6 feet 2 inches, and one weighed 160 pounds and the other 195 pounds.'b'Surprisingly, the new survey suggests that the biggest predators are not other inmates but prison staff  \xe2\x80\x94  and female staff members offend as much as the males do. More than 10 percent of boys in juvenile correctional facilities said that they had had sex with staff, most of whom were women.'b'Among girls, almost 5 percent said that they had engaged in sexual activity with staff, most of whom were men.'b'Reggie Walton, a federal judge in the District of Columbia who led the prison rape commission, said that the figures may even be an undercount because of the stigma of rape. \xe2\x80\x9cI was shocked at the level of abuse,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'One lesson from the surveys is that we should rethink the way male guards are sometimes assigned to female inmates, and female guards to male inmates, without sufficient respect for inmates\xe2\x80\x99 privacy or dignity. That won\xe2\x80\x99t stop same-sex violence or inmate-on-inmate abuses, but it would address one important component of the abuse problem.'b'By some accounts, the majority of guards at women\xe2\x80\x99s prisons are now men. Investigators at one juvenile correctional facility found that a male guard watched as girls showered, while a woman watched over boys showering.'b'Jamie Fellner of Human Rights Watch, also a member of the prison rape commission, described a Virginia prison where men were stripped naked and asked to spread their buttocks in front of a female officer. When a male inmate asked to be searched in front of  a man instead, Ms. Fellner said he was Tasered.'b'In the last few years, a growing number of states have limited the ability of guards to strip-search members of the opposite sex or watch them showering. And a landmark law, the Prison Rape Elimination Act, created Judge Walton\xe2\x80\x99s commission, which has made excellent recommendations to reduce violence and abuse behind bars. The Obama administration should quickly implement those recommendations.'b'Surveys have found that well-managed prisons and correctional facilities with strong accountability have almost no rape, by guards or inmates. Others have astonishingly high levels. If we want to rehabilitate young offenders and help them get their lives in order, a starting point is to end the criminal abuse of them.'b'The legacy of Rodney Hulin Jr. should be a concerted drive to end the way inmates are raped with impunity behind bars. The survey results indicating the ubiquity of sexual assault behind bars, often by guards, should be an awakening  \xe2\x80\x94  and an end to this blind spot that so many of us have shown. But there is a different tradition of democratic populism, based on the view that while leaders like Alexander Hamilton and Abraham Lincoln play noteworthy roles, it takes ordinary citizens to \xe2\x80\x9cbuild America.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'This view was central to the cooperatives of black and white small farmers of the late 19th century at the base of the Populist Party, the labor movements of the 1930s and the civil rights struggle in the 1950s and 1960s. 'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s not just the populist who, as David Brooks says, \xe2\x80\x9cabsolves voters of responsibility for their problems.\xe2\x80\x9d  It\xe2\x80\x99s also almost every politician and elected official.'b'One of the bedrock rules of political life is never to blame the American people: we are invariably decent, generous, hard-working, wise and, always, better than the people who govern us.'b'Steven Berkowitz'b'\nNew York, Jan.\n26, 2010'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'Republicans have been incredibly successful in harnessing populism while directing their policy efforts to support the elite and big business. It\xe2\x80\x99s an unbelievable balancing act.'b'Ronald Schaeffer'b'\nLewes, Del., Jan.\n26, 2010'b''b'Internet voting is in its infancy, and still far too unreliable, but states are starting to allow it and the trend is accelerating because of a new federal law that requires greater efforts to help military and other overseas voters cast ballots. Men and women in uniform must have a fair opportunity to vote, but allowing online voting in its current state could open elections up to vote theft and other mischief.'b'It is often hard for military voters to get ballots, and because of distance and unreliable mail service, it can be difficult or impossible for them to meet election deadlines. A year ago, the Pew Center on the States found that more than one-third of states do not provide military voters stationed abroad with enough time to vote, or are at high risk of not providing enough time. To address this problem, the new Military and Overseas Voter Empowerment Act requires states in most cases to get ballots to military and overseas voters well in advance of   regularly scheduled federal elections.'b'But the value of removing roadblocks is undermined when votes are put at risk, which can happen when ballots are returned by e-mail or are actually cast on a Web site. Massachusetts recently enacted a law allowing service members to vote by e-mail overseas. According to Verified Voting, a group that works to ensure reliable elections, 16 states  allow some form of Internet voting, and more than a dozen \xe2\x80\x94 including Alabama, Hawaii, Illinois and Washington \xe2\x80\x94 are considering it.'b'E-mail can be intercepted, and voting Web sites can be hacked or taken down by malicious attacks. There are not even agreed-upon standards for what safety measures are necessary.'b'In many cases, it is not possible to ensure a secret ballot when votes are cast online or by e-mail. That is a particular concern for military voting, where soldiers could come under pressure from commanding officers about their choice of a candidate.'b'The Internet can help improve overseas voting if it is used wisely. The United States government and other governments around the world, for their part, have sent thousands of relief workers and have pledged $1 billion so far. But Haitians need something more fundamental than relief from the present situation; they need  jobs that they can count on for years ahead. For this, the private business sector is essential. Luckily, business leaders  are meeting now in Davos, Switzerland, and Haiti is prominent on their agenda.'b'Haiti is by far the poorest country in the Western Hemisphere, and yet it need not be so, because unexploited economic opportunities abound there. Some of the best mangoes in the world grow in Haiti \xe2\x80\x94 though  too many of them rot, offshore from the world\xe2\x80\x99s largest market, for want of adequate roads and well-governed ports. Excellent coffee is grown in the Haitian mountains, but much of it is sold informally across the border to coffee producers in the Dominican Republic, who reap most of the profits.'b'Haiti also has many qualities attractive to tourists: a warm climate; magnificent white-sand beaches and turquoise water; Tortuga, the famous pirate island off the northern coast; and the Citadel, a mountain fortress erected after Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s independence in the early 19th century to fend off colonial powers, now a World Heritage site. Still, it is one of the least  visited places in the Caribbean.'b'The Hope II trade pact with the United States, signed in 2008, granted Haiti duty-free access to the American apparel market for the next decade. Already, as a result of the deal, many garment factories situated along Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s eastern border (so as to use Dominican electricity and ports) have become profitable and competitive with Chinese garment makers. But light manufacturing could be much bigger in Haiti \xe2\x80\x94 if the Haitian government and donors would credibly commit  to providing functioning roads, electrical grids and ports, and if outside private capital would invest, patiently, in Haitian businesses.'b'Poverty and a history of  coups and trade embargoes have pushed Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s reputation as a place to do business to near the bottom of the global pile, alongside countries like Afghanistan, Somalia and Iraq. But Haiti is far safer and offers far more  market opportunities  than those conflict-ridden nations.'b'The obvious difficulty in Haiti is that its economic center, Port-au-Prince, is now in shambles. Private investors are naturally wary of jumping into a market too soon, before it is lively enough to provide certain kinds of support. After all, many businesses can be profitable only if other businesses exist alongside them. Ships don\xe2\x80\x99t sail directly from Haiti to Florida because  there aren\xe2\x80\x99t enough goods to warrant dedicated routes. In the meantime, without reliable routes for direct export of goods, investment in production in Haiti is stymied.'b'Even within a single manufacturing sector, it helps to have many businesses operating together. Garment factories, for example, cluster together, because they share a common need for support services. In Haiti, the cluster of garment makers has been too small even to keep repair shops  in business; it can take weeks to fly in a technician to fix a broken sewing machine. So, production costs are high because there are too few investors, and there are too few investors because costs are so high.'b'The way to address this chicken-and-egg problem is for individual private investors to coordinate with one another. This would not be a new strategy; in the 19th century, the American West was developed not as a process of gradual diffusion but in spasms of local investment booms, financed by enthusiastic outsiders. The earthquake could usher in such a boom in Haiti.'b'The World Economic Forum in Davos provides an opportunity for businesses that might invest in Haiti \xe2\x80\x94 international fashion brands, hotels and coffee chains, for example \xe2\x80\x94 to coordinate with companies that provide logistics and markets, so that together they could make mutual commitments. The foundation for such coordination has already been laid \xe2\x80\x94 by Bill Clinton, who led 200 international investors to Haiti last October. As a result of this effort, international chains like Best Western and Choice Hotels started building new hotels in Haiti.'b'The earthquake has, of course, changed opportunities in Haiti, but it has not necessarily reduced them. The American construction industry is mired in deep recession and so has the excess capacity to meet Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s sudden need for low-cost housing, roads, bridges and other structures. If American construction firms can harness Haitian labor to reconstruct (safer) homes, then the challenge will be to lure other businesses in their wake  so that temporary jobs in reconstruction are replaced by long-term jobs in manufacturing, agriculture and tourism.'b'In meeting this challenge, banks and private venture capital also have an important role to play. Haiti needs generous venture capital that encourages some firms to move in first. George Soros, the investor and philanthropist, has recognized this need by committing $25 million for smart investments that catalyze Haiti\xe2\x80\x99s competitive advantages. Many more such commitments are needed.'b'For now, even public sources of risk capital like the World Bank\xe2\x80\x99s International Finance Corporation and Britain\xe2\x80\x99s Commonwealth Development Corporation have no special provision for the kind of coordinated pump-priming investment that\xe2\x80\x99s required in Haiti. Most public capital goes to emerging market economies where private investment no longer needs to be encouraged. Haiti, with its genuine opportunities and immediate needs, provides a chance for public finance organizations to find new relevance. It is also a chance for private business to show it can take a major role in meeting the gravest human needs.'b'Toward the end of his State of the Union address Wednesday night, President Obama said something that untold numbers of Americans who suffer discrimination had wanted to hear for more than 16 years. Mr. Paterson has to remember that he is governor for the whole state, including New York City.'b'On Jan. 29, 2009, in the East Room of the White House, President Obama signed his first bill into law, the Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act. It overturned a notorious 5-to-4 Supreme Court decision from 2007 that had denied Ms. Ledbetter restitution for years in which her employer, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, had paid her less than her male colleagues.'b'The new law could not restore Ms. Ledbetter\xe2\x80\x99s lost wages because her case could not be retried. But it brought justice, if belatedly, by ensuring that legal protections and civil rights denied to Ms. Ledbetter would not be denied to others. It is past time for Mr. Obama to see that similar justice is done for Evelyn Coke.'b'In 2007, Ms. Coke also had her day in Supreme Court \xe2\x80\x94 and also lost. A retired home care aide, she had sued her employer for decades of unpaid overtime. No one disputed that she had worked extra long hours for no extra pay. But in a 9-to-0 decision, the justices upheld a 1975 federal labor regulation that defines home care aides as \xe2\x80\x9ccompanions.\xe2\x80\x9d That designation exempts home care agencies from having to pay the federal minimum wage or time-and-a-half for overtime.'b'The justices were clear that the law gives the Labor Department the power to change the regulation. Congress also could change the rule. Yet the rule stands more than two years after the Coke decision and a year after lawmakers and Mr. Obama took a bow for the Ledbetter fair-pay law.'b'Like Ms. Coke, who was born in Jamaica, home care workers are often immigrants. Most are women, minorities and earn a low income. They are not mere companions. They typically help to feed, dress and move their elderly and disabled clients, plus keep house. Home care also is one of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s fastest-growing occupations. Currently numbering around two million, they are among the lowest-paid and most-exploited in the work force.'b'After signing the Lilly Ledbetter law last year, Mr. Obama gave Ms. Ledbetter the last of many pens used in the ceremony. Ms. Coke 'b'died last July'b' before she saw justice, let alone a White House ceremony. In her memory, Mr. Obama should instruct his Labor Department to undo the companionship exemption. If he does not act, Congress should introduce and pass, without delay, the Evelyn Coke Fair Pay for Caregivers Act.'b'The last, long stage of J. D. And it ended 'b'with his death'b' this week at the age of 91.'b'Whether he expected such a substantial stretch of privacy when he withdrew from New York is unknown, as is almost everything about his private life in a place that is not nearly so remote from the world as most of his readers supposed. But then remoteness is also a matter of will, as Mr. Salinger succeeded in proving.'b'Publishing for him was clearly full of a susceptibility that most authors never feel. To send a work out into the world was, to Mr. Salinger, an intrusion. And so he ends up raising, in its purest form, a question that many writers have struggled with: Is it really possible to be a writer without publishing?'b'Mr. Salinger had it both ways. His work was not merely popular. There was an almost idolatrous quality in the public response to \xe2\x80\x9cCatcher\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cNine Stories,\xe2\x80\x9d which appeared the year he moved to Cornish. We do not know whether Mr. Salinger retreated to husband his creativity or simply defend his privacy.'b'It remains to be seen whether death will now publish Mr. Salinger \xe2\x80\x94 whether there is an archive of his later life\xe2\x80\x99s work waiting to be revealed. There was a purity in Mr. Salinger\xe2\x80\x99s separation from the world, whatever its motives, whatever his character. His half-century of solitude and silence was a creative act in itself, requiring extraordinary force of will.'b'This is the core truth that readers \xe2\x80\x94 and writers, too \xe2\x80\x94 often struggle with. Beneath the riches of the creative life, and hidden well away from the claims we place upon the writers we care for, there is still the one life, the ordinary life, to be lived. Mr. Salinger chose to live his in a way that only he and his immediate family could observe. He\xe2\x80\x99s a-comin\xe2\x80\x99. The country would be better off if it were you.'b'Paris'b'SIXTY-FIVE years ago this week, the Soviets liberated Auschwitz, while the Americans were approaching Dachau. For a survivor of these two infernos to still be alive and well, with a new family that has resurrected for me the one I had lost, seems almost unreal. When I entered Adolf Eichmann and Josef Mengele\xe2\x80\x99s gruesome universe at the age of 13, I measured my life expectancy in days, weeks at the most.'b'In the early winter of 1944, World War II was coming to an end. But we in the camps knew nothing. We wondered: What is happening in the world outside? Where is God? Where is the pope? Does anyone out there know what is happening here to us? Does anyone even care?'b'Russia was devastated. Britain had its back against the wall. And America? It was so far away, so divided. How could it be expected to save civilization from the seemingly invincible forces of darkness?'b'It took a long time for the news of the American-led invasion of Normandy to slip into Auschwitz. There were also rumors that the Red Army was advancing quickly on the eastern front. With the ground shrinking under their feet, the Nazis were becoming palpably nervous. The gas chambers spewed fire and smoke as never before.'b'One gray, frosty morning, our guards ordered those of us still capable of slave labor to line up and marched us out of the camp. We were to be shunted westward, from Poland into Germany. I was beside myself with excitement \xe2\x80\x94 and dread. Salvation somehow seemed closer \xe2\x80\x94 yet we also knew that we could be killed at any moment. The goal was to hang on a little longer. I was almost 16 now, and I wanted to live.'b'We marched from camp to camp, day and night, until we and our torturers began to hear distant explosions that sounded like artillery fire. One afternoon we were strafed by a squadron of Allied fighter planes that mistook our column for Wehrmacht troops. As the Germans hit the dirt, their machine guns blazing in all directions, someone near me yelled, \xe2\x80\x9cRun for it!\xe2\x80\x9d I kicked off my wooden clogs and sprinted into the forest. There I hid, hungry and cold, for weeks, until I was discovered by a group of American soldiers. The boys who brought me life were not much older than I. They fed me, clothed me, made me a mascot of their regiment and gave me my first real taste of freedom.'b'Today, the last living survivors of the Holocaust are disappearing one by one. Soon, history will speak about Auschwitz with the impersonal voice of researchers and novelists at best, and at worst in the malevolent register of revisionists and falsifiers who call the Nazi Final Solution a myth. This process has already begun.'b'And it is why those of us who survived have a duty to transmit to humankind the memory of what we endured in body and soul, to tell our children that the fanaticism and violence that nearly destroyed our universe have the power to enflame theirs, too. The fury of the Haitian earthquake, which has taken more than 200,000 lives, teaches us how cruel nature can be to man. The Holocaust, which destroyed a people, teaches us that nature, even in its cruelest moments, is benign in comparison with man when he loses his moral compass and his reason.'b'After so much death, a groundswell of compassion and solidarity for victims \xe2\x80\x94 all victims, whether from natural disasters, racial hatred, religious intolerance or terrorism \xe2\x80\x94 occasionally manifests itself, as it has in recent days.'b'These actions stand in contrast to those moments when we have failed to act; they remind us, on this dark anniversary, of how often we remain divided and confused, how in the face of horror we hesitate, vacillate, like sleepwalkers at the edge of the abyss. Of course, they remind us, too, that we have managed to stave off the irrevocable; that our chances for living in harmony are, thankfully, still intact.'b'Iran has again proved to be a master at playing for time. It is time for President Obama and other leaders to ratchet up the pressure with tougher sanctions.'b'Mr. Obama, who offered a new relationship with Iran, gave its government until the end of 2009 to come to the table. In his State of the Union address this week, he warned Iran\xe2\x80\x99s leaders that they face \xe2\x80\x9cgrowing consequences\xe2\x80\x9d if they continue to ignore their obligations.'b'Four years after the United Nations Security Council first demanded that Iran stop enriching uranium (usable for nuclear fuel or a bomb), Tehran has thousands of centrifuges spinning. Washington plans to soon circulate a new sanctions resolution \xe2\x80\x94 the fourth in four years.'b'Britain, France and Germany share Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s concerns. Russia and China \xe2\x80\x94 which have veto power on the Security Council and strong economic ties with Iran \xe2\x80\x94 have previously insisted on watering down penalties. That has made the Council look feckless and made it far too easy for Iran to press ahead. On Friday, we were glad to see Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton 'b'publicly warn China'b', which seems especially intractable, that it faces diplomatic isolation if it fails to back new sanctions.'b'Last fall, after Iran was caught hiding another illicit enrichment plant, the major powers offered Tehran a reasonable interim deal: open all of its nuclear facilities to international inspectors and send most of its stock of low-enriched uranium abroad to be turned into fuel for a research reactor. That wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have solved the problem, but it would have bought more time for negotiations. A midlevel Iranian diplomat seemed to agree, but then higher-ups said no. Nothing has changed since.'b'This is a delicate time in Iran. Last June\xe2\x80\x99s fraudulent presidential election sparked fierce political protests and a brutal government crackdown \xe2\x80\x94 including political executions. New United Nations sanctions must be deftly targeted to inflict maximum damage on the levers of repression \xe2\x80\x94 especially the Iranian Revolutionary Guard Corps, which also runs the nuclear program \xe2\x80\x94 without imposing additional suffering on the Iranians. And the door must remain open to negotiations.'b'If the Security Council does not act quickly, then the United States and Europe must apply more pressure on their own. Meanwhile, the centrifuges keep spinning.'b'A bitter dispute between one of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s largest health insurers and a consortium of New York City hospitals illustrates the difficulties of controlling the ever-rising costs of medical care and insurance premiums. The hospitals say they were appalled to find that UnitedHealthcare wanted a reduction of 7 to 10 percent in reimbursement levels at a time when its largest hospitals are barely breaking even.'b'We don\xe2\x80\x99t pretend to know what the proper reimbursement rates should be. We simply note that many experts believe hospital costs generally are too high and that insurers should bargain hard to bring costs down rather than just raise premiums.'b'A second issue is UnitedHealthcare\xe2\x80\x99s demand that the hospitals notify it within 24 hours when a beneficiary is admitted \xe2\x80\x94 or suffer a 50 percent cut in reimbursements for that patient. The insurer says the faster it has that information the faster its case managers can look for ways to shorten a hospital stay \xe2\x80\x94 reducing costs and hospital-borne infections \xe2\x80\x94 and help organize post-hospital care to prevent relapses.'b'Hospitals are notoriously poor at coordinating post-discharge care, and insurers, who have the fullest records of what doctors a patient has been seeing, are in a good position to help do it. The hospitals suspect that UnitedHealthcare is looking for an excuse to cut reimbursements. The company denies that.'b'How hard could it be for admissions offices to alert the insurer \xe2\x80\x94 and the patient\xe2\x80\x99s primary care doctor \xe2\x80\x94 that a patient has arrived? That said, it might be fairer to impose a lesser penalty for, say, the first 10 missed deadlines and bigger penalties after that.'b'The fight should remind insurers and health care providers that they have a shared interest in making sure that medical treatment is better coordinated so that patients get well faster and don\xe2\x80\x99t relapse. That is a good way to rein in costs and premiums.'b'One of President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s worthier first-year achievements was to redirect federal sex-education financing from an abstinence-only approach to  broader, more-effective programs that provide information to young people about contraceptives, pregnancy and sexually transmitted diseases.'b'A 'b'new study'b' from the Guttmacher Institute examining the latest federal data on teenage sex, births and abortion \xe2\x80\x94 along with the group\xe2\x80\x99s own abortion statistics \xe2\x80\x94 suggests the wisdom of that shift.'b'The study found that the pregnancy rate among girls ages 15 to 19 years old increased by 3 percent in 2006 from the year before \xe2\x80\x94 a troubling departure after more than a decade of declining teenage pregnancy.'b'The teenage abortion rate also rose during the same period for the first time in more than a decade, increasing by 1 percent.'b'It remains to be seen whether these increases represent a longer-term trend. No doubt a number of factors contributed to the upticks, including, for example, declining contraceptive use by teenagers. But the institute also sees a link between the rise in the teenage pregnancy and abortion rates and the Bush administration\xe2\x80\x99s reliance on abstinence-only sex education programs that bar teaching about contraception. This is not an unreasonable inference.'b'The study is timely. As part of the broader health care reform effort, abstinence-only advocates are trying hard to restore financing for the narrow, ineffective and fundamentally dishonest approach.'b'As I read over last week\xe2\x80\x99s aggressively wrong 5-to-4 Supreme Court decision greatly escalating the power of corporate and union money in elections, my thoughts turned to  former Justice Sandra Day O\xe2\x80\x99Connor.'b'That is not just because the ruling is another reminder of the court\xe2\x80\x99s rightward shift since Justice O\xe2\x80\x99Connor was replaced by the starkly conservative Justice Samuel Alito. Since retiring, Justice O\xe2\x80\x99Connor has been warning about the threat to judicial independence from big-money state judicial campaigns and attack ads paid for by special interests hoping to influence future court decisions. The Citizens United ruling promises to make that problem worse, possibly much worse.'b'Thirty-nine states hold judicial elections. Between 2000 and 2009, State Supreme Court candidates raised $205.8 million, according to the Justice at Stake Campaign, a watchdog group that monitors money in court races. That was more than double the $84.9 million raised the previous decade. One immediate result of the Citizens United ruling, as Justice John Paul Stevens noted in dissent, is that these states \xe2\x80\x9cmay no longer have the ability to place modest limits on corporate electioneering even if they believe such limits to be critical to maintaining the integrity of their judicial systems.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Another result is that all states are now effectively barred from adopting curbs on corporate and union spending on political campaigns, including judicial races. Business and other outside interest groups able to spend the cash could further dominate the airwaves and the debate in campaigns. Judicial candidates concerned about retaining control of their message will need to devote even more time to fund-raising.'b'Thoughtful candidates known to look at the law on a case-by-case basis will be at a distinct disadvantage, forecasts Professor James Sample, a judicial elections expert at Hofstra Law School. The accelerated money war, he warns, will inevitably polarize the bench \xe2\x80\x9cbecause more moderate candidates are unlikely to be considered a bankable vote by any special interest group investing heavily in judicial campaigns.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'To protect the integrity of their court systems, states need to enact basic reforms: switching from judicial elections, for instance, to the selection of judges on merit, or adopting strict rules that bar judges from ruling in cases involving major financial supporters. \xe2\x80\x9cNo states can possibly benefit from having that much money injected into a political judicial campaign,\xe2\x80\x9d Justice O\xe2\x80\x99Connor said on Tuesday. Achieving these reforms won\xe2\x80\x99t be easy, but now they are even more essential.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'The Taliban Would Applaud'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (editorial, Jan. 27), criticizing a French proposal to ban all-concealing veils in many public places:'b'You write, \xe2\x80\x9cPeople must be free to make these decisions for themselves, not have them imposed by governments or enforced by the police.\xe2\x80\x9d But does this still hold when these decisions are imposed by culture or society?'b'Some Chinese women used to have their feet bound, and many probably thought that they were doing it voluntarily.'b'Some Indian women set themselves afire, because once their husbands had died, what was the point of living?'b'Some African girls undergo genital cutting, again a cultural and societal phenomenon, and some welcome the act as a sign of arrival of womanhood and acceptance in society.'b'Should we accept these acts, all of which are designed to demean women?'b'In Western society, covering a face is deemed to be sinister. (There\xe2\x80\x99s a restaurant chain called \xe2\x80\x9cHooters,\xe2\x80\x9d for crying out loud.)'b'I always wondered why Howard Zinn was considered a radical. (He called himself a radical.) He was an unbelievably decent man who felt obliged to challenge injustice and unfairness wherever he found it. What was so radical about believing that workers should get a fair shake on the job, that corporations have too much power over our lives and much too much influence with the government, that wars are so murderously destructive that alternatives to warfare should be found, that blacks and other racial and ethnic minorities should have the same rights as whites, that the interests of powerful political leaders and corporate elites are not the same as those of ordinary people who are struggling from week to week to make ends meet?'b'Mr. Zinn was often taken to task for peeling back the rosy veneer of much of American history to reveal sordid realities that had remained hidden for too long. When writing about Andrew Jackson in his most famous book, \xe2\x80\x9cA People\xe2\x80\x99s History of the United States,\xe2\x80\x9d published in 1980, Mr. Zinn said:'b'\xe2\x80\x9cIf you look through high school textbooks and elementary school textbooks in American history, you will find Jackson the frontiersman, soldier, democrat, man of the people  \xe2\x80\x94  not Jackson the slaveholder, land speculator, executioner of dissident soldiers, exterminator of Indians.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Radical? Hardly.'b'Mr. Zinn would protest peacefully for important issues he believed in  \xe2\x80\x94  against racial segregation, for example, or against the war in Vietnam  \xe2\x80\x94  and at times he was beaten and arrested for doing so. He was a man of exceptionally strong character who worked hard as a boy growing up in Brooklyn during the Depression. He was a bomber pilot in World War II, and his experience of the unmitigated horror of warfare served as the foundation for his lifelong quest for peaceful solutions to conflict.'b'He had a wonderful family, and he cherished it. He and his wife, Roslyn, known to all as Roz, were married in 1944 and were inseparable for more than six decades until her death in 2008. She was an activist, too, and Howard\xe2\x80\x99s editor. \xe2\x80\x9cI never showed my work to anyone except her,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.'b'They had two children and five grandchildren.'b'Mr. Zinn was in Santa Monica this week, resting up after a grueling year of work and travel, when he suffered a heart attack and died on Wednesday. He was a treasure and an inspiration. People don\xe2\x80\x99t care as much about process as they do about results.'b'According to 'b'a survey released this week'b' by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press, only 1 person in 4  knew that 60 votes are needed in the Senate to break a filibuster and only 1 in 3 knew that no Senate Republicans voted for the health care bill.'b'And, according to an NBC News/Wall Street Journal 'b'survey released this week'b', while slightly more Americans blamed Republicans than Democrats for the political impasse in Washington, the percentage of people with negative feelings about the Republicans was the same as it was for the Democrats.'b'The message that voters take away is not nuanced: Democrats in control.
