Sad but true.'b'We subsist on Twitter twaddle \xe2\x80\x94 a never-ending stream of ideas and idiocy, where emotions are rendered in anagrams and thoughts are amputated at 140 characters.'b'The most trusted \xe2\x80\x9cnewsman\xe2\x80\x9d 'b'may well be a comedian'b' (Jon Stewart), and stars of the \xe2\x80\x9c'b'most trusted news network'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Fox) may well be a comedian\xe2\x80\x99s dream.'b'The president must communicate within the environment he inhabits, not the one he envisions. The next time he gives a speech, someone should tap him on the ankle and say, \xe2\x80\x9cMr. President, we\xe2\x80\x99re down here.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Birmingham, England'b'THE life of J. D. Salinger, which has just ended, is one of the strangest and saddest stories in recent literary history. Nevertheless, it would be a mistake to let the disappointment of the second half of Mr. Salinger\xe2\x80\x99s career \xe2\x80\x94 consisting of a long short story called \xe2\x80\x9cHapworth 16, 1924\xe2\x80\x9d that reads as though he allowed the pain of hostile criticism to blunt the edge of self-criticism that every good writer must possess, followed by 45 years of living like a hermit in the New Hampshire woods \xe2\x80\x94 to overshadow the achievements of the first half.'b'The corpus of his good work is very small, but it is classic. His was arguably the first truly original voice in American  prose fiction after the generation of Hemingway, Fitzgerald and Faulkner. Of course nothing is absolutely original in literature, and Mr. Salinger had his precursors, of whom Hemingway was one, and Mark Twain \xe2\x80\x94 from whose Huck Finn Hemingway said that all modern American literature came \xe2\x80\x94 another. From them he learned what you could do with simple, colloquial language and a na\xc3\xafve youthful narrator. But in \xe2\x80\x9cThe Catcher in the Rye\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Salinger applied their lessons in a new way to create a new kind of hero, Holden Caulfield, whose narrative voice struck a chord with millions of readers.'b'The narrative is in a style the Russians call skaz, a nice word with echoes of jazz and scat in it, which uses the repetitions and redundancies of ordinary speech to produce an effect of sincerity and authenticity \xe2\x80\x94 and humor: \xe2\x80\x9cThe thing is, most of the time when you\xe2\x80\x99re coming pretty close to doing it with a girl ... she keeps telling you to stop. The trouble with me is, I stop. Most guys don\xe2\x80\x99t. I can\xe2\x80\x99t help it. You never know whether they really 'b'want 'b'you to stop, or whether they\xe2\x80\x99re just scared as hell, or whether they\xe2\x80\x99re just telling you to stop so that if you 'b'do'b' go through with it, the blame\xe2\x80\x99ll be on 'b'you'b', not them. Anyway, I keep stopping. The trouble is, I get to feeling sorry for them. I mean most girls are so dumb and all. After you neck them for a while you can really 'b'watch'b' them losing their brains. You take a girl when she really gets passionate, she just hasn\xe2\x80\x99t any brains. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know. They tell me to stop, so I stop.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It looks easy, but it isn\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'Nearly everybody loves \xe2\x80\x9cThe Catcher in the Rye,\xe2\x80\x9d and most readers enjoy Mr. Salinger\xe2\x80\x99s first collection of short stories, \xe2\x80\x9cNine Stories.\xe2\x80\x9d But the work that followed, the four long short stories paired together in two successive books as \xe2\x80\x9cFranny and Zooey\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cRaise High the Roof Beam, Carpenters and Seymour: An Introduction,\xe2\x80\x9d were less reader-friendly and provoked more critical comment, leading eventually to the retreat of the wounded author into solitude.'b'This was as much the consequence of critical failure as of authorial arrogance. These books challenged conventional notions of fiction and conventional ways of reading as radically as the kind of novels that would later be called post-modernist, and a lot of critics didn\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x9cget it.\xe2\x80\x9d The saga of the Glass family is stylistically the antithesis of \xe2\x80\x9cCatcher\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 highly literary, full of rhetorical tropes, narrative devices and asides to the reader \xe2\x80\x94 but there is also continuity between them. The literariness of the Glass stories is always domesticated by a colloquial informality. Most are narrated by Buddy, the writer in the family, who says at the outset of \xe2\x80\x9cZooey\xe2\x80\x9d that \xe2\x80\x9cwhat I\xe2\x80\x99m about to offer isn\xe2\x80\x99t really a short story at all but a sort of prose home movie.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The nearest equivalent to this saga in earlier literature is perhaps the 18th-century antinovel \xe2\x80\x9cThe Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman,\xe2\x80\x9d by Laurence Sterne. There is the same minutely close observation of the social dynamics of family life, the same apparent disregard for conventional narrative structure, the same teasing hints that the fictional narrator is a persona for the real author, the same delicate balance of sentiment and irony, and the same humorous running commentary on the activities of writing and reading.'b'How Shandean, for instance, is Buddy\xe2\x80\x99s presentation to the reader in \xe2\x80\x9cSeymour\xe2\x80\x9d of \xe2\x80\x9cthis unpretentious bouquet of very early-blooming parentheses: (((( )))). I suppose, most unflorally, I truly mean them to be taken, first off, as bow-legged \xe2\x80\x94 buckle-legged \xe2\x80\x94 omens of my state of mind and body at this writing.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Seymour Glass first appeared in one of the \xe2\x80\x9cNine Stories,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cA Perfect Day for Bananafish,\xe2\x80\x9d as a disturbed veteran of World War II (as Mr. Salinger himself was), who on vacation with his rather shallow wife, after a charmingly droll conversation with a little girl on the beach, shockingly shoots himself in the last paragraph. The late stories are all in some way about the attempts of Seymour\xe2\x80\x99s surviving siblings to come to terms with this action. This often takes a religious direction, and presents the Glass family as a kind of spiritual elite, struggling against a tide of materialism and philistinism with the aid of Christian existentialism, Eastern mysticism and a select pantheon of great writers.'b'This cultural and spiritual elitism got up the noses of many critics, but I think they overlooked the fact that Mr. Salinger was playing a kind of Shandean game with his readers. The more truth-telling and pseudo-historical the stories became in form (tending toward an apparently random, anecdotal structure, making elaborate play with letters and other documents as \xe2\x80\x9cevidence\xe2\x80\x9d), the less credible became the content (miraculous feats of learning, stigmata, prophetic glimpses, memories of previous incarnations, and so forth). But what were we asked to believe in: the reality of these things, or the possibility of them? Since it is fiction, surely the latter; to suppose it is the former is to lose half the pleasure of reading the books.'b'PRESIDENT OBAMA 10 days ago set out one important element in the needed structural reform of the financial system. No one can reasonably contest the need for such reform, in the United States and in other countries as well. We have after all a system that broke down in the most serious crisis in 75 years. The cost has been enormous in terms of unemployment and lost production. The repercussions have been international.'b'Aggressive action by governments and central banks \xe2\x80\x94 really unprecedented in both magnitude and scope \xe2\x80\x94 has been necessary to revive and maintain market functions. Some of that support has continued to this day. Here in the United States as elsewhere, some of the largest and proudest financial institutions \xe2\x80\x94 including both investment and commercial banks \xe2\x80\x94 have been rescued or merged with the help of massive official funds. Those actions were taken out of well-justified concern that their outright failure would irreparably impair market functioning and further damage the real economy already in recession.'b'Now the economy is recovering, if at a still modest pace. Funds are flowing more readily in financial markets, but still far from normally. Discussion is underway here and abroad about specific reforms, many of which have been set out by the United States administration: appropriate capital and liquidity requirements for banks; better official supervision on the one hand and on the other improved risk management and board oversight for private institutions; a review of accounting approaches toward financial institutions; and others.'b'As President Obama has emphasized, some central structural issues have not yet been satisfactorily addressed.'b'A large concern is the residue of moral hazard from the extensive and successful efforts of central banks and governments to rescue large failing and potentially failing financial institutions. The long-established \xe2\x80\x9csafety net\xe2\x80\x9d undergirding the stability of commercial banks \xe2\x80\x94 deposit insurance and lender of last resort facilities \xe2\x80\x94 has been both reinforced and extended in a series of ad hoc decisions to support investment banks, mortgage providers and the world\xe2\x80\x99s largest insurance company. In the process, managements, creditors and to some extent stockholders of these non-banks have been protected.'b'The phrase \xe2\x80\x9ctoo big to fail\xe2\x80\x9d has entered into our everyday vocabulary. It carries the implication that really large, complex and highly interconnected financial institutions can count on public support at critical times. The sense of public outrage over seemingly unfair treatment is palpable. Beyond the emotion, the result is to provide those institutions with a competitive advantage in their financing, in their size and in their ability to take and absorb risks.'b'As things stand, the consequence will be to enhance incentives to risk-taking and leverage, with the implication of an even more fragile financial system. We need to find more effective fail-safe arrangements.'b'In approaching that challenge, we need to recognize that the basic operations of commercial banks are integral to a well-functioning private financial system. It is those institutions, after all, that manage and protect the basic payments systems upon which we all depend. More broadly, they provide the essential intermediating function of matching the need for safe and readily available depositories for liquid funds with the need for reliable sources of credit for businesses, individuals and governments.'b'Combining those essential functions unavoidably entails risk, sometimes substantial risk. That is why Adam Smith more than 200 years ago advocated keeping banks small. Then an individual failure would not be so destructive for the economy. That approach does not really seem feasible in today\xe2\x80\x99s world, not given the size of businesses, the substantial investment required in technology and the national and international reach required.'b'Instead, governments have long provided commercial banks with the public \xe2\x80\x9csafety net.\xe2\x80\x9d The implied moral hazard has been balanced by close regulation and supervision. Improved capital requirements and leverage restrictions are now also under consideration in international forums as a key element of reform.'b'The further proposal set out by the president recently to limit the proprietary activities of banks approaches the problem from a complementary direction. The point of departure is that adding further layers of risk to the inherent risks of essential commercial bank functions doesn\xe2\x80\x99t make sense, not when those risks arise from more speculative activities far better suited for other areas of the financial markets.'b'The specific points at issue are ownership or sponsorship of hedge funds and private equity funds, and proprietary trading \xe2\x80\x94 that is, placing bank capital at risk in the search of speculative profit rather than in response to customer needs. Those activities are actively engaged in by only a handful of American mega-commercial banks, perhaps four or five. Only 25 or 30 may be significant internationally.'b'Apart from the risks inherent in these activities, they also present virtually insolvable conflicts of interest with customer relationships, conflicts that simply cannot be escaped by an elaboration of so-called Chinese walls between different divisions of an institution. The further point is that the three activities at issue \xe2\x80\x94 which in themselves are legitimate and useful parts of our capital markets \xe2\x80\x94 are in no way dependent on commercial banks\xe2\x80\x99 ownership. These days there are literally thousands of independent hedge funds and equity funds of widely varying size perfectly capable of maintaining innovative competitive markets. Individually, such independent capital market institutions, typically financed privately, are heavily dependent like other businesses upon commercial bank services, including in their case prime brokerage. Commercial bank ownership only tilts a \xe2\x80\x9clevel playing field\xe2\x80\x9d without clear value added.'b'Very few of those capital market institutions, both because of their typically more limited size and more stable sources of finance, could present a credible claim to be \xe2\x80\x9ctoo big\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9ctoo interconnected\xe2\x80\x9d to fail. In fact, sizable numbers of such institutions fail or voluntarily cease business in troubled times with no adverse consequences for the viability of markets.'b'What we do need is protection against the outliers. There are a limited number of investment banks (or perhaps insurance companies or other firms) the failure of which would be so disturbing as to raise concern about a broader market disruption. In such cases, authority by a relevant supervisory agency to limit their capital and leverage would be important, as the president has proposed.'b'To meet the possibility that failure of such institutions may nonetheless threaten the system, the reform proposals of the Obama administration and other governments point to the need for a new \xe2\x80\x9cresolution authority.\xe2\x80\x9d Specifically, the appropriately designated agency should be authorized to intervene in the event that a systemically critical capital market institution is on the brink of failure. The agency would assume control for the sole purpose of arranging an orderly liquidation or merger. Limited funds would be made available to maintain continuity of operations while preparing for the demise of the organization.'b'To help facilitate that process, the concept of a \xe2\x80\x9cliving will\xe2\x80\x9d has been set forth by a number of governments. Stockholders and management would not be protected. Creditors would be at risk, and would suffer to the extent that the ultimate liquidation value of the firm would fall short of its debts.'b'To put it simply, in no sense would these capital market institutions be deemed \xe2\x80\x9ctoo big to fail.\xe2\x80\x9d What they would be free to do is to innovate, to trade, to speculate, to manage private pools of capital \xe2\x80\x94 and as ordinary businesses in a capitalist economy, to fail.'b'I do not deal here with other key issues of structural reform. Surely, effective arrangements for clearing and settlement and other restrictions in the now enormous market for derivatives should be agreed to as part of the present reform program. So should the need for a designated agency \xe2\x80\x94 preferably the Federal Reserve \xe2\x80\x94 charged with reviewing and appraising market developments, identifying sources of weakness and recommending action to deal with the emerging problems. Those and other matters are part of the administration\xe2\x80\x99s program and now under international consideration.'b'In this country, I believe regulation of large insurance companies operating over many states needs to be reviewed. We also face a large challenge in rebuilding an efficient, competitive private mortgage market, an area in which commercial bank participation is needed. Those are matters for another day.'b'What is essential now is that we work with other nations hosting large financial markets to reach a broad consensus on an outline for the needed structural reforms, certainly including those that the president has recently set out. My clear sense is that relevant international and foreign authorities are prepared to engage in that effort. In the process, significant points of operational detail will need to be resolved, including clarifying the range of trading activity appropriate for commercial banks in support of customer relationships.'b'I am well aware that there are interested parties that long to return to \xe2\x80\x9cbusiness as usual,\xe2\x80\x9d even while retaining the comfort of remaining within the confines of the official safety net. They will argue that they themselves and intelligent regulators and supervisors, armed with recent experience, can maintain the needed surveillance, foresee the dangers and manage the risks.'b'In contrast, I tell you that is no substitute for structural change, the point the president himself has set out so strongly.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve been there \xe2\x80\x94 as regulator, as central banker, as commercial bank official and director \xe2\x80\x94 for almost 60 years. I have observed how memories dim. Individuals change. Institutional and political pressures to \xe2\x80\x9clay off\xe2\x80\x9d tough regulation will remain \xe2\x80\x94 most notably in the fair weather that inevitably precedes the storm.'b'The implication is clear. We need to face up to needed structural changes, and place them into law. To do less will simply mean ultimate failure \xe2\x80\x94 failure to accept responsibility for learning from the lessons of the past and anticipating the needs of the future.'b'WASHINGTON'b'It began as a bit of partisan gamesmanship and ended, surprisingly, as illuminating political theater.'b'White House advisers thought that if they asked that cameras and reporters be allowed in for the usually closed Q. and A. with the president at the annual retreat of House Republicans, the Republicans might say no and look obstructionist.'b'But the Republicans realized what the White House was up to, got irritated and opened up the exchange in Baltimore to show they weren\xe2\x80\x99t scared of the smart, facile and newly warmblooded Barack Obama.'b'And during the next hour and a half, our government did not look quite so lame.'b'Obama is always at his best when his back is against the wall, and he is perversely content when he has the challenge of the lion\xe2\x80\x99s den.'b'He may lapse back into his Camus coma at any moment. It was a lot more elucidating than Joe Wilson shouting, \xe2\x80\x9cYou lie!\xe2\x80\x9d'b'KALEHE, Congo'b'Sometimes I wish eastern Congo could suffer an earthquake or a tsunami, so that it might finally get the attention it needs. The barbaric civil war being waged here is the most lethal conflict since World War II and has claimed at least 30 times as many lives as the Haiti earthquake.'b'Yet no humanitarian crisis generates so little attention per million corpses, or such a pathetic international response.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s why I\xe2\x80\x99m here in the lovely, lush and threatening hills west of Lake Kivu, where militias rape, mutilate and kill civilians with a savagery that is almost incomprehensible. I\xe2\x80\x99m talking to a 9-year-old girl, Chance Tombola, an orphan whose eyes are luminous with fear.'b'For Chance, the war arrived one evening last May when armed soldiers from an extremist Hutu militia  \xe2\x80\x94 remnants of those who committed the Rwandan genocide  \xe2\x80\x94 burst into her home. They killed her parents in front of her. Chance ran away, but the soldiers seized her two sisters, ages 6 and 12, and carried them away into the forest, presumably to be turned into \xe2\x80\x9cwives\xe2\x80\x9d of soldiers. No one has seen Chance\xe2\x80\x99s sisters since.'b'Chance moved in with her aunt and uncle and their two teenage daughters. Two months later, the same militia invaded the aunt\xe2\x80\x99s house and held everyone at gunpoint. Chance says she recognized some of the soldiers as the same ones who had killed her parents.'b'This time, no one could escape. The soldiers first shot her uncle, and then, as the terrified family members sobbed, they pulled out a large knife.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey sliced his belly so that the intestines fell out,\xe2\x80\x9d said his widow, Jeanne Birengenyi, 34, Chance\xe2\x80\x99s aunt. \xe2\x80\x9cThen they cut his heart out and showed it to me.\xe2\x80\x9d The soldiers continued to mutilate the body, while others began to rape Jeanne.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOne takes a leg, one takes the other leg,\xe2\x80\x9d Jeanne said dully. \xe2\x80\x9cOthers grab the arms while one just starts raping. They don\xe2\x80\x99t care if children are watching.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Chance added softly: \xe2\x80\x9cThere were six who raped her. One raped me, too.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The soldiers left Jeanne and Chance, tightly tied up, and marched off into the forest with Jeanne\xe2\x80\x99s two daughters as prisoners. One daughter is 14, the other 16, and they have not been heard from since.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThey kill, they rape, burn houses and take people\xe2\x80\x99s belongings,\xe2\x80\x9d Jeanne said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen they come with their guns, it\xe2\x80\x99s as if they have a project to eliminate the local population.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A 'b'peer-reviewed study'b' found that 5.4 million people had already died in this war as of April 2007, and hundreds of thousands more have died as the situation has deteriorated since then. A catastrophically planned military offensive last year, backed by the governments of Congo and Rwanda as well as the United Nations force here, made some headway against Hutu militias but also led to increased predation on civilians from all sides.'b''b'Human Rights Watch estimates'b' that for every Hutu fighter sent back to Rwanda last year, at least seven women were raped and 900 people forced to flee for their lives. \xe2\x80\x9cFrom a human rights perspective, the operation has been catastrophic,\xe2\x80\x9d concluded Philip Alston, a senior United Nations investigator.'b'This is a pointless war  \xe2\x80\x94 now a dozen years old \xe2\x80\x94 driven by warlords, greed for minerals, ethnic tensions and complete impunity. While there is plenty of fault to go around, Rwanda has long played 'b'a particularly troubling role'b' in many ways, including support for one of the militias. Rwanda\xe2\x80\x99s government is dazzlingly successful at home, but next door in Congo, it appears complicit in war crimes.'b'Jeanne and Chance contracted sexually transmitted diseases. Like other survivors in areas that are accessible, they receive help from the International Rescue Committee, but Chance still suffers pain when she urinates.'b'Counselors say that most raped women are rejected by their husbands, and raped girls like Chance have difficulty marrying. In an area west of Lake Kivu where attacks are continuing, I met Saleh Bulondo, a newly homeless young man who was educated and spoke a little English. I asked him if he would still marry his girlfriend if she were raped.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cNever,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cI will abandon her.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'A girl here normally fetches a bride price (a reverse dowry, paid by the husband\xe2\x80\x99s family) when she marries. A village chief told me that a typical price would be 20 goats \xe2\x80\x94 but if the girl has been raped, two goats. At most.'b'Thus it takes astonishing courage for Jeanne and Chance to tell their stories (including in a video posted with the on-line version of this column). It\xe2\x80\x99s time to show the same compassion toward Congo that we have toward Haiti.'b'Davos, Switzerland'b'As a political barometer, the Davos World Economic Forum usually offers up some revealing indicators of the global mood, and this year is no exception. It is the only global sport more popular than soccer. But in the past, it was always done knowing that America was this global bedrock that could always be counted upon to lead. But this year is different. This year, Asians and Europeans, in particular, pull you aside and ask you some version of: \xe2\x80\x9cTell me, what\xe2\x80\x99s going on in your country?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'We\xe2\x80\x99re making people nervous.'b'Banks, multinationals and hedge funds often hire foreign policy experts to do \xe2\x80\x9cpolitical risk analysis\xe2\x80\x9d before they invest in places like, say, Kazakhstan or Argentina. They may soon have to add the United States to their watch lists.'b'You can understand why foreigners are uneasy. They look at America and see a president elected by a solid majority, coming into office riding a wave of optimism, controlling both the House and the Senate. Yet, a year later, he can\xe2\x80\x99t win passage of his top legislative priority: health care.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cOur two-party political system is broken just when everything needs major repair, not minor repair,\xe2\x80\x9d said K.R. Sridhar, the founder of Bloom Energy, a fuel cell company in Silicon Valley, who is attending the forum. \xe2\x80\x9cI am talking about health care, infrastructure, education, energy. We are the ones who need a Marshall Plan now.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Indeed, speaking of phrases I\xe2\x80\x99ve never heard here before, another goes like this: \xe2\x80\x9cIs the \xe2\x80\x98Beijing Consensus\xe2\x80\x99 replacing the \xe2\x80\x98Washington Consensus?\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d Washington Consensus is a term coined after the cold war for the free-market, pro-trade and globalization policies promoted by America. As Katrin Bennhold reported in The International Herald Tribune this week, developing countries everywhere are looking \xe2\x80\x9cfor a recipe for faster growth and greater stability than that offered by the now tattered \xe2\x80\x98Washington Consensus\xe2\x80\x99 of open markets, floating currencies and free elections.\xe2\x80\x9d And as they do, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is growing talk about a \xe2\x80\x98Beijing Consensus.\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9d'b'The Beijing Consensus, says Bennhold, is a \xe2\x80\x9cConfucian-Communist-Capitalist\xe2\x80\x9d hybrid under the umbrella of a one-party state, with a lot of government guidance, strictly controlled capital markets and an authoritarian decision-making process that is capable of making tough choices and long-term investments, without having to heed daily public polls.'b'Personally, I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t give up on the Washington Consensus so fast. The reason it is ailing is not because of its principles promoting economic openness and trade, many of which China is practicing better than we are lately. It is failing more because of, well, Washington.'b'It was hard to read President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s eloquent State of the Union address and not feel torn between his vision for the coming years and the awareness that the forces of inertia and special interests blocking him \xe2\x80\x94 not to mention the whole Republican Party  \xe2\x80\x94 make the chances of his implementing that vision highly unlikely. That is the definition of \xe2\x80\x9cstuck.\xe2\x80\x9d And right now we are stuck.'b'The sad and frustrating thing is, we are so close to being unstuck. If there were just six or eight Republican senators \xe2\x80\x94 a few more Judd Greggs and Lindsey Grahams \xe2\x80\x94 ready to meet Obama somewhere in the middle on deficit reduction, energy, health care and banking reform, I believe that in the wake of the Massachusetts wake-up call the president would indeed meet them in that middle ground to forge not just incremental compromises, but substantial ones on these key issues. But so far, the Republicans are having a good year politically by just being the Party of No.'b'It is a shame because here we are as a country scrounging around for a few billion more dollars of stimulus to help our unemployed and small businesses  \xe2\x80\x94  when the biggest stimulus of all is hiding in plain sight. And that is ending our political paralysis and the pall of uncertainty it is casting over everything from the cost of my health care to the cost of my energy to the way our biggest banks can do business.'b'If the two parties could get together and remove the clouds of uncertainty over those issues, remove the growing sense that our country is politically paralyzed, you would not need another dime of stimulus money. Investment and lending would take off on their own. If, however, the two parties continue with their duel-to-the-death paralysis, no amount of stimulus will give us the sustained growth and employment we need.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cGame Change,\xe2\x80\x9d the gossipy 'b'reconstruction'b' of the 2008 presidential election that opens today atop The New York Times 'b'nonfiction best-seller list'b', is filled with racy anecdotes about dysfunctional marriages and political back-stabbing. What it does not have are identifiable sources.'b'The book is mostly written in an omniscient, novelistic voice, purporting at times to be inside the heads of players and recreating scenes and dialogue that the authors could not have witnessed. There is none of that clunky \xe2\x80\x9cEdwards recalled in an interview,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9caccording to three independent sources\xe2\x80\x9d stuff \xe2\x80\x94 the sort of language that slows down the narrative but that most news organizations insist on for credibility.'b'So, even as it caused a stir \xe2\x80\x94 Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader, 'b'having to apologize'b' for remarks about Barack Obama\xe2\x80\x99s accent and skin tone \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cGame Change\xe2\x80\x9d posed an intriguing dilemma for The Times: How do you deal with a talker of a book reported in a way that the paper\xe2\x80\x99s own standards do not permit?'b'If you repeat some of the more salacious parts, like the supposed details of a fight between John and Elizabeth Edwards in an airport parking lot, are you just letting through the backdoor what you would never allow through the front? If you don\xe2\x80\x99t, are you just burying your head in the sand while readers get the juicy stuff elsewhere?'b'The authors, 'b'John Heilemann'b' and 'b'Mark Halperin'b', two veteran political journalists, have pushed the envelope on the insider story, a genre developed most notably by 'b'Bob Woodward'b'. But while \xe2\x80\x9c'b'State of Denial'b',\xe2\x80\x9d the third volume of Woodward\xe2\x80\x99s examination of the Bush administration\xe2\x80\x99s war efforts,  contained 29 pages of source notes, Heilemann and Halperin merely say in their book that they conducted more than 300 interviews with more than 200 people and tried to talk with everyone they named. Some declined, but they don\xe2\x80\x99t say who.'b'And they do not say who said what: all the interviews were conducted on deep background, meaning candidates and junior staffers alike were granted cover without being identified in any way.'b'The bottom-line message: trust us. In the particularly vicious context of presidential campaign politics, where chaos reigns and nearly everyone seems to have a score to settle, this is asking a lot.'b'The Times has treated \xe2\x80\x9cGame Change\xe2\x80\x9d as news, but carefully: 'b'a review'b' in the daily paper that raised the sourcing issues; 'b'a Sunday review'b'; coverage of Reid\xe2\x80\x99s apology and 'b'Republican attempts'b' to capitalize on it; 'b'an essay'b' on the death of loyalty among political staffers; 'b'and another'b' on the damage to the image of Elizabeth Edwards, portrayed in the book as \xe2\x80\x9can abusive, intrusive, paranoid, condescending crazywoman.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'None of the articles repeated the most titillating material. 'b'Jill Abramson'b', the managing editor for news, said a review had to give a sense of what a book was about. But she said it was the job of editors to decide if something was newsworthy enough to warrant a separate article and, if so, \xe2\x80\x9cto go back and do our own reporting.\xe2\x80\x9d The Times chose not to, focusing articles about Reid\xe2\x80\x99s apology, for example, on the quotes he was acknowledging and the political fallout.'b''b'Judith Warner'b', who wrote the Style section column about Elizabeth Edwards, said she did not try to verify what the book said because she was examining the issue of image. It\xe2\x80\x99s too bad she did not try, because on the same day her column appeared, former aides to Edwards 'b'told Politico'b', on the record, that the book\xe2\x80\x99s portrayal was accurate but incomplete, failing to capture her warmer side.'b'Reid\xe2\x80\x99s apology gave \xe2\x80\x9cGame Change\xe2\x80\x9d an aura of credibility from the start, and silence from other major figures helped. But, Abramson said, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think the lack of denials tells you all that much.\xe2\x80\x9d Some of the players, she said, may figure that denying something only serves to give it longer legs.'b'I was curious about one incident involving 'b'Maureen Dowd'b', the star Times Op-Ed columnist, who in early 2007 quoted 'b'David Geffen'b', the Hollywood mogul, disowning Bill and Hillary Clinton. Geffen, who raised millions for Bill Clinton and then became disenchanted, said of both Clintons, \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody in politics lies, but they do it with such ease, it\xe2\x80\x99s troubling.\xe2\x80\x9d The column had an enormous impact at the time.'b'According to \xe2\x80\x9cGame Change,\xe2\x80\x9d Dowd persuaded Geffen to give her an interview by telling him that, when it was over, if he did not want her to use it, she would not. She read 'b'the finished column'b' to Geffen, the book said, warned him it would be explosive and asked if he wanted to take back anything.  If true, Dowd would, in effect, have surrendered editorial control to her source, an unacceptable situation.'b'The book also implied that Dowd attended a private $2,300-per-person Obama fund-raiser the following night.  Afterward, it said,  she was among a small group of 35 who \xe2\x80\x9crepaired to Geffen\xe2\x80\x99s mansion\xe2\x80\x9d  for a dinner for the Obamas.'b'Dowd said it didn\xe2\x80\x99t happen that way. \xe2\x80\x9cI never gave David Geffen veto power over the column,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. She said she did not read the column to him, warn him that it would be explosive or ask if he wanted to take back his words, and she did not attend the Hollywood fund-raising event at the Beverly Hilton Hotel. She was a guest at the dinner later, she said, although the candidate\xe2\x80\x99s camp sought to have her barred.'b'Dowd said that, as is often her practice, she told Geffen which quotes she was using and checked them for accuracy and context. He had been unsure whether he wanted to say some of the things he told her but agreed to all of it, she said.'b'Geffen, who did not want to get embroiled in a controversy among journalists, would only say: \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think anyone imagines Maureen would allow anyone to edit her column. I certainly didn\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Dowd said the authors did not interview her for the book but that Halperin called at some point to \xe2\x80\x9ccheck a few \xe2\x80\x94 but not all \xe2\x80\x94 of the details.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'So, what is a person to believe: someone speaking on the record, or the word of \xe2\x80\x94 whom? And what does it say about other parts of \xe2\x80\x9cGame Change?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Halperin and Heilemann would not answer specific questions about the discrepancies in the accounts. \xe2\x80\x9cWe stand by everything that\xe2\x80\x99s in the book,\xe2\x80\x9d Halperin said. That response, he said,  was \xe2\x80\x9c a serious, considered answer\xe2\x80\x9d made necessary by promises to sources. While refusing to confirm that anyone had called Dowd, Heilemann said all the fact-checking was done while the book was still being written and while changes could be made.'b'Jacob Heilbrunn, who wrote the review for the Sunday Times, said he did not even mention the sourcing issue because this type of tell-all book has become so established. \xe2\x80\x9cI think they would have been crippled if they hadn\xe2\x80\x99t taken the approach they did,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou have a culture here in Washington, they won\xe2\x80\x99t tell you if they had a cup of coffee or not unless they go on background.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'That is true, and journalists for The Times operate in the same culture, sometimes giving in to it more than I think they should. But with \xe2\x80\x9cGame Change,\xe2\x80\x9d the paper was right to avoid relying on someone else\xe2\x80\x99s anonymous sources. Dowd could tell you.'b'As the candidate of hope and change, President Obama has doubtless spent some private time around his first anniversary in office wondering whether he shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have been more specific about the kind of change he\xe2\x80\x99d hoped for. If a single year has so transformed his political fortunes, imagine what cannot be imagined in the next three ahead.'b'If it\xe2\x80\x99s any comfort, the phenomenon isn\xe2\x80\x99t new to the American presidency. To quote the favorite political philosopher of the president I served, it\xe2\x80\x99s d\xc3\xa9j\xc3\xa0 vu all over again. Travel back to January 1990, as President George Bush \xe2\x80\x94 no \xe2\x80\x9cH. W.\xe2\x80\x9d needed back then \xe2\x80\x94 prepared for his first State of the Union address. The invasion of Panama, which returned democracy to that nation by way of the barrel speakers of a boom-box, had officially ended after 23 days. The Revolutions of 1989 across Europe \xe2\x80\x94 in the speech, the president told of a Czech Everyman reciting in accented English the words of the Declaration of Independence \xe2\x80\x94 served to underscore the president\xe2\x80\x99s claim that the State of our Union was strong.'b'And why not: The \xe2\x80\x9cIn-Box President,\xe2\x80\x9d as that month\xe2\x80\x99s Atlantic Monthly called him, was sailing along with a 63 percent approval rating \xe2\x80\x94 a number few in the White House uttered aloud, and never in the presence of the president. As we rehearsed the speech in the White House Family Theater, our focus was on how to \xe2\x80\x9cbolt in the rabbit\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 as in what the magician produces from his hat \xe2\x80\x94 which was the droll code name coined by the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft,   for the critical, close-hold section of the speech that dealt with reducing our conventional forces in Europe.'b'The other major issue was whether to add a reference near the close of the speech to the president\xe2\x80\x99s newest grandchild. In a podium break, the famously reticent president, almost allergic to the use of the pronoun \xe2\x80\x9cI,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked, \xe2\x80\x9cmaybe it\xe2\x80\x99s O.K. \xe2\x80\x94 it\xe2\x80\x99s just a grandfather talking.\xe2\x80\x9d The phrase clicked, and it was added to the teleprompter text. Both the grandson and the arms control treaty would receive more attention from the president than any of the domestic policy initiatives contained in his speech.'b'What we didn\xe2\x80\x99t see then from the high ground of Year One were any of the signal events of Year Two. The ill-fated deficit summit meeting at Andrews Air Force Base \xe2\x80\x94 a closed-door exercise that yielded the too-clever-by-180-I.Q.-points \xe2\x80\x9ctax revenue enhancements\xe2\x80\x9d as a substitute for the president\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cread my lips\xe2\x80\x9d no-new-taxes pledge \xe2\x80\x94 was three months away. In six months, Saddam Hussein would roll tanks into Kuwait. In eight months, we would hit what economists would later pinpoint as the beginning of a recession, at roughly the time the White House national security team was focused on reuniting East and West Germany. Working in the White House was a daily lesson in politics and policy, and the critical difference between the two.'b'Seen through the lens of 20 years\xe2\x80\x99 time, what\xe2\x80\x99s telling now is the  capriciousness of what we took to be the issues that would define a presidency. For more than half a century, no man or woman living has had as much power to shape the world as an American president. And yet the world retains an even greater power to challenge, confound and surprise.  \xe2\x80\x94 'b'DANIEL McGROARTY, speechwriter and special assistant to President George H. W. Bush 'b''b'We sympathized with the concerns about security and inconvenience raised by the Justice Department\xe2\x80\x99s plan to try Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the self-described 9/11 mastermind, at a federal courthouse in downtown Manhattan,  a short walk from ground zero.'b'But caving in to political pressure and agreeing to move the trial, as The Times reported the Obama administration has decided to do, was the wrong move. New York was the right place for this trial. This is where the attack occurred, and New Yorkers should have been proud to see justice done here. The United States District Court in Manhattan has a long, successful record of trying terrorists, including the ones responsible for the 1993 World Trade Center bombing.'b'President Obama was right to move Mr. Mohammed and four other high-profile terrorism suspects out of the jurisdiction of military tribunals. President George W. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s decision to hold prisoners outside the law and then attempt to try them in rigged military courts was legally wrong, and hugely damaging to American values and this country\xe2\x80\x99s global image.'b'Mayor Michael Bloomberg first supported the president\xe2\x80\x99s decision to hold the trial in New York, but reversed field after looking at the costs of what could be a very long process. Local business leaders protested, as did politicians with a variety of motives \xe2\x80\x94 none really sound and some profoundly cynical.'b'Mr. Obama should have worked with the mayor to develop a security plan, one that limited local disruption. The federal government should have paid any additional cost. It will have to do that wherever the trial is held.'b'The trial must remain within the federal court system. Mr. Obama should not put it in a makeshift court on a military base and definitely should not give in to demands from the right to return Mr. Mohammed (and the four other prisoners) to the tribunals.'b'Trying mass murderers in a criminal court is not \xe2\x80\x9csoft on terrorism.\xe2\x80\x9d The federal courts have tried, convicted and imprisoned many terrorists. The tribunals have not held a single trial, and may never have one that Americans can be proud of.'b'For some Republicans, this is really about keeping Guant\xc3\xa1namo open. Others just want to block whatever Mr. Obama wants. Representative Peter King, Republican of New York, has a particularly insidious bill that would obstruct justice by stopping the government from spending money on federal court trials for terrorists.'b'Dianne Feinstein, the California Democrat who heads the Senate Intelligence Committee, warned that holding the trial in New York \xe2\x80\x9cwould only heighten media and public attention.\xe2\x80\x9d That one baffled us. This trial would draw attention if it were held atop Pikes Peak. And isn\xe2\x80\x99t the idea of a public trial a bedrock principle of American justice?'b'Holding the trial in New York would be inconvenient. Democracy makes demands on its citizens. It is inconvenient to serve on a jury, too. This was just not-in-my-backyard-ism. Nearly 10 years after 9/11, it is sad if this country cannot freely conduct its business in Lower Manhattan.'b'IN April 1969, three months after his inauguration, President Richard Nixon hosted a party at the White House to celebrate Duke Ellington\xe2\x80\x99s 70th birthday and award the Duke the Medal of Freedom. Great American jazz figures were there. Musicians played Ellington songs arranged by Gerry Mulligan. Joe Williams and Mary Mayo sang. Ellington danced with Rose Mary Woods. After dinner, the president had a nightcap with the pianist Earl Hines.'b'It was in many other ways a very good year for President Nixon. He called to congratulate the Apollo 11 astronauts on their moon landing. He initiated a huge expansion of the National Endowment for the Arts and began the processes that led to the desegregation of public schools in the South and a historic reform of the government\xe2\x80\x99s policy toward American Indians. He announced the \xe2\x80\x9cNixon doctrine,\xe2\x80\x9d providing aid \xe2\x80\x94 but not military forces \xe2\x80\x94 to our anticommunist Asian allies. He signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.'b'In 1969 Nixon also committed the United States to continuing its defense of South Vietnam. The Vietnam War had already made a political casualty of President Lyndon Johnson and fatally crippled Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s vice president, Hubert Humphrey, as a presidential candidate. Yet to Nixon and his national security adviser, Henry Kissinger, leaving Vietnam meant losing the chance to apply pressure to the Soviet Union through China. In November 1969, toward the end of his first year in office, Nixon 'b'announced'b' a policy of \xe2\x80\x9cVietnamization\xe2\x80\x9d and the gradual withdrawal of American troops. At the end of the year, he told me he thought that we had \xe2\x80\x9cweathered the worst\xe2\x80\x9d of the Vietnam conflict and that if we could \xe2\x80\x9cjust hold on,\xe2\x80\x9d time would now work on our side.'b'But it was too late. A strike by Harvard students had erupted in the spring; the Vietnam Moratorium march had descended on Washington in October. The war had already begun to engulf Nixon\xe2\x80\x99s presidency just as it had destroyed Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s. What began in 1969 continued inexorably until Nixon was forced to resign in 1974. Years later, Nixon reflected that \xe2\x80\x9cif I underestimated the willingness of the North Vietnamese to hang on and resist a negotiated settlement ... they also underestimated my willingness to hold on despite the domestic and international pressures that would be ranged against me.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It may be that a president with fewer personal demons, without such a large capacity for resentment, could have survived the storm. As I look back over an increasing span of years, I am not sure I think so. 'b'\xe2\x80\x94 LEONARD GARMENT, White House counsel for President Richard Nixon'b''b'IN his first State of the Union speech, on Jan. 15, 1975, President Gerald R. Ford told Congress and the American people in his plain-spoken manner: \xe2\x80\x9cI must say to you that the State of the Union is not good.\xe2\x80\x9d And then he listed the particulars: The economy was suffering from stagflation \xe2\x80\x94 simultaneous high inflation and economic recession. Unemployment was rising toward 8 percent. There was an energy shortage and high oil prices because of an embargo on petroleum shipments by Arab nations. The federal budget deficit was approaching $50 billion and the national debt $500 billion \xe2\x80\x94 big money in those days. As we prepared the speech \xe2\x80\x94 the first draft wasn\xe2\x80\x99t even completed until around 3:30 a.m. on the day of the address \xe2\x80\x94 Ford asked Roy Ash, director of the Office of Management and Budget, if he had any good economic news to include. Ash replied, \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99ll take about four seconds.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Nonetheless, Ford offered a number of specific proposals in his speech, some of which may sound familiar to those who listened to President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s address on Wednesday: capping the federal budget at $300 billion; cutting taxes by giving individuals a rebate of up to $1,000 and by giving industries a $4 billion reward for creating new jobs; imposing new taxes on petroleum products to discourage use and offering new incentives to encourage more domestic production as well as development of nuclear and solar energy.'b'Ford ended his State of the Union speech by declaring, \xe2\x80\x9cIn partnership with the American people, we will achieve these objectives.\xe2\x80\x9d However, Ford\xe2\x80\x99s ability to achieve the goals \xe2\x80\x94 as well as his relationship with Congress, the press corps and the American people \xe2\x80\x94 had been seriously undermined by the pardon of his disgraced predecessor, Richard Nixon, four months earlier. When Nixon resigned, Ford seemed to be a breath of fresh air after the miasma of Watergate \xe2\x80\x94 he was a regular guy who could laugh at his own foibles, down-to-earth, self-confident, liked by both Democrats and Republicans in Congress.'b'All that hope and good will were blown away by the pardon, and by subsequent rumors (never substantiated) of some kind of deal between Ford and Nixon. It was in that atmosphere of anger and disillusionment that Ford delivered his first State of the Union speech. Only decades later was Ford\xe2\x80\x99s presidency \xe2\x80\x94 and the pardon \xe2\x80\x94 reappraised and his reputation restored. 'b' \xe2\x80\x94 RONALD NESSEN, press secretary for President Gerald Ford'b''b'THINGS were tough as Jimmy Carter prepared for his 1978 State of the Union address, one year into his term. But they seemed, strangely, hopeful. The president\xe2\x80\x99s big domestic initiative that year was a national energy policy. The gas-station lines and first-ever spike in fuel prices in the mid-1970s made this a genuine emergency. He hadn\xe2\x80\x99t yet gotten the whole plan through, but the previous summer he had signed legislation creating the Department of Energy and begun imposing standards that, even after he was gone, kept improving the fuel efficiency of American cars, buildings and factories.'b'His big foreign policy initiative was the Panama Canal treaty, to restore Panama\xe2\x80\x99s sovereignty over the Canal Zone with safeguards for the canal\xe2\x80\x99s operation. Although the opponents were fierce, employing what we would now call \xe2\x80\x9ctea party\xe2\x80\x9d tactics, they were a minority. Mr. Carter had John Wayne and other tough guys to speak on the treaty\xe2\x80\x99s behalf \xe2\x80\x94 not to mention  61 Democratic votes in the Senate and a more than 2-to-1 Democratic majority under  Tip O\xe2\x80\x99Neill in the House.'b'Just before the speech, the president had traveled across four continents in a marathon world tour. Yes, there were glitches, like a toast in Tehran praising the soon-to-be-deposed shah of Iran as \xe2\x80\x9can island of stability\xe2\x80\x9d in a troubled area of the world. (I remember \xe2\x80\x94 I wrote it!) But I also know firsthand that President Carter was warmly and admiringly received from India to Brazil for his emphasis on a new foreign policy built on traditional American respect for human rights.'b'Inflation was going down. Job creation was going up. So as time came to put the speech together, everyone involved dared think about what else the administration could do, after such a good start. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is all across our land a growing sense of peace and a sense of common purpose,\xe2\x80\x9d  Mr. Carter said in his address \xe2\x80\x94 a sentence I cannot remember writing and in retrospect can hardly believe was uttered at all. \xe2\x80\x9cFor the first time in a generation we are not haunted by a major international crisis\xe2\x80\x9d and therefore have \xe2\x80\x9ca rare and precious opportunity to address persistent problems\xe2\x80\x9d that otherwise would just get worse. And so he laid out his bright plans, which included making government activities more transparent and reducing the role of lobbyists.'b'One year tells us something about a presidency and its capacities. But a lot can change after that. 'b'\xe2\x80\x94'b' 'b'JAMES FALLOWS, chief speechwriter for President Jimmy Carter'b''b'Political platforms are usually written for election campaign purposes, then quickly scrapped after a presidential election. But the 1980 Republican platform bore a simple five-word title: \xe2\x80\x9cFamily, Neighborhood, Work, Peace, Freedom,\xe2\x80\x9d and was planned and written with the purpose of creating an agenda for a Reagan administration on Day One, Jan. 20, 1981. My signal memory of Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s first year in office is that we were actually able to stick to the plan that he insisted we put in place.'b'Coupled with the basic policy framework, Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s was one of the most carefully planned presidential transitions in modern political history, replete with teams of \xe2\x80\x9cReaganauts\xe2\x80\x9d dispatched to each department and agency in the days following the election. Staffing lists were compiled, and presidential and subcabinet appointments were made swiftly, background and vetting checks completed and requisite Senate hearings scheduled.'b'The plan from the outset was to put in place the Reagan economic program as the major priority and foundation for every major initiative, domestic and foreign. Tax cuts were high on the president\xe2\x80\x99s agenda, and work began, quietly and in the background for the most part, on a huge \xe2\x80\x9cget well\xe2\x80\x9d program for the nation\xe2\x80\x99s defenses.'b'While Reagan received an immediate boost with the Inauguration Day release of the American hostages in Iran, it\xe2\x80\x99s doubtful that the incident altered his approach. In his first press conference he declared that the Soviets \xe2\x80\x9creserve the right to lie and cheat\xe2\x80\x9d to achieve their goals, setting some teeth on edge. He knew precisely what he wanted to say and made a point not to reveal it to staff in two preparatory sessions.'b'There were, of course, unexpected moments that first year: Alexander Haig\xe2\x80\x99s bizarre behavior as secretary of state; David Stockman\xe2\x80\x99s effort, as budget director, to undercut the president\xe2\x80\x99s budget; and, of course, the assassination attempt outside the Washington Hilton in March. Remarkably, Reagan recovered from all these.'b'One other thing stands out: Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s ability to get along with Democrats, something he had shown he could do as governor of California. Although the House of Representatives was controlled by Democrats, the president managed to pass his tax reduction package. He also found a way, through one-on-one sessions with senatorial opponents of both parties, to gain Congressional approval of the sale of Awacs radar planes to Saudi Arabia. By 1991, the deployed aircraft were a decisive military asset in the Persian Gulf war.'b'As Reagan\xe2\x80\x99s debut year came to a close, I remember thinking how remarkable it was that he had managed to stay the course. Having watched subsequent presidencies lurch in response to political pressure, I find the president\xe2\x80\x99s first-year feat even more remarkable today. 'b' \xe2\x80\x94 RICHARD V. ALLEN, senior fellow at the Hoover Institution and national security advisor to President Ronald Reagan'b''b'Barack Obama, reeling from the Democratic defeat in the Massachusetts Senate race, isn\xe2\x80\x99t the first president to get an unwelcome anniversary gift a year after taking office. On Jan. 20, 1994, Attorney General Janet Reno announced that, at President Bill Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s request, she had appointed Robert Fiske as special counsel to investigate the Whitewater case. What we didn\xe2\x80\x99t know then was that seven months later, Mr. Fiske would be replaced by Ken Starr, whose investigation would ultimately lead to the president\xe2\x80\x99s impeachment. But what those of us on the Clinton staff were learning fast after 12 tumultuous months on the job was how little control we had over our own unfolding drama. The cockiness of the campaign was giving way to a humility imposed by history.'b'Events large and small \xe2\x80\x94 and so often out of our hands \xe2\x80\x94 could unfurl without warning, or sometimes over time, to upend our day, alter our political fortunes and change the world. In that first year, they often did.'b'Mr. Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s first budget went to Congress in June. A plan to invest in jobs and growth, cut wasteful spending and raise taxes on the rich, it passed both houses with nary a vote to spare \xe2\x80\x94 or a single Republican. We celebrated at the time, but victory was short-lived. Eighteen months later, Democrats lost both the House and Senate. Still, the president\xe2\x80\x99s economic strategy proved successful,   fuelling the longest economic expansion in American history.'b'In September, Mr. Clinton presided over the signing of peace accords, and a historic handshake, between Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestinian Authority. Even hard-bitten Clinton advisers like Rahm Emanuel, now President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s chief of staff, were moved to tears, and reviews were almost universally positive. But two years later, a deranged opponent of the plan assassinated Rabin, and over time, progress stalled.'b'As the people in the Obama administration look back over the first year, and forward to the future, they should do all they can to move their agenda. But they would be wise to remember that forces more powerful than their best-laid plans will shape their fate. Today\xe2\x80\x99s failure may be tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s success, or vice versa. And history will have the last word. \xe2\x80\x94 'b'DEE DEE MYERS, press secretary for President Bill Clinton'b''b'THEY served pineapple upside-down cake for dessert that snowy evening at Camp David, the last weekend of President George W. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s first year in office. I remember thinking it seemed fitting. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a year,\xe2\x80\x9d President Bush said during dinner. \xe2\x80\x9cSometimes it seems like seven,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Condoleezza Rice, his national security advisor. But no one else said much. The emotions had been too raw, too intense. The sudden horror of Sept. 11 had changed the course of the presidency, making America\xe2\x80\x99s national security the president\xe2\x80\x99s relentless focus. \xe2\x80\x9cContinued vigilance\xe2\x80\x9d were the watchwords, as we fully expected additional attacks.'b'We had seen the president\xe2\x80\x99s  strong leadership as he rallied the country, Congress and each of us to confront the threat. \xe2\x80\x9cLet me tell you how to do your job today,\xe2\x80\x9d I remember him saying to me early one morning, directing me to plan an announcement. We had watched Mr. Bush make the most profound decision a commander in chief can make, committing American lives to battle in Afghanistan. We had witnessed the fall of the Taliban  and worked to calm the panic of anthrax attacks.'b'As President Obama is learning, the first year of a presidency is one in which the rhetoric of campaigning collides with the hard reality of governing. As President Bush took office, the economy was falling into recession; we passed tax cuts to try to stimulate jobs. We had celebrated moments of great achievement: overwhelming bipartisan approval for education reforms. We had wrestled with the  profound  moral ramifications of stem cell research. And we had   experienced the thrills of the presidency: the drama of the first meeting with President Vladimir Putin of Russia; the visit by Mexico\xe2\x80\x99s president, Vicente Fox, which involved a fireworks display so spectacular that Condi Rice joked we could be \xe2\x80\x9ctesting the missile defense system.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'President Obama often seems to suggest that his administration is facing challenges more difficult than others did. Yet the state of our Union has never been stronger.\xe2\x80\x9d'b''b'\xe2\x80\x94 KAREN HUGHES, counselor to President George W. Bush'b''b''b'With the State of the Union address, President Obama marked the symbolic end to his first year in office. From the outside, it seemed like a pretty rough roller-coaster ride. 'b''b''b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9c'b'A Lifesaving Tool Turned Deadly: Radiation Offers Powerful New Cures, and Ways to Do Harm'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cThe Radiation Boom\xe2\x80\x9d series, front page, Jan. 24):'b'The treatment errors described in your article about radiation therapy are tragic. But it is important to remember that they are also rare. Patients should not refuse radiation therapy out of safety concerns. It is a proven treatment that can ease pain, control the spread of cancer and, in many cases, cure the disease.'b'The goal of the radiation therapist is to deliver a targeted dose of radiation to the tumor while reducing damage to normal tissue that surrounds it. Thanks to the care provided by registered radiation therapists, millions of Americans are cancer survivors.'b'Unfortunately, 17 states do not require a license to deliver radiation therapy. That is why the American Society of Radiologic Technologists urges Congress to establish national standards for those who perform medical imaging or radiation therapy procedures. Patients deserve the best care possible, from the most qualified caregivers possible.'b'Diane Mayo'b'\n   Albuquerque, Jan. 24, 2010'b''b''b'The writer is president of the American Society of Radiologic Technologists.'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'As a 12-year breast cancer survivor who underwent radiation therapy after surgery and chemotherapy, I began physically shaking as I finished this article about two patients who received radiation overdoses. The equipment would be thoroughly vetted and reported on in peer review articles before being accepted and used by the smaller community hospitals.'b'Now the reverse is true. Small community hospitals often far outpace academic medical centers. One example is the proliferation of proton centers run by for-profit companies. Often the staff has limited knowledge and experience with this extraordinarily complex equipment. And new technologies are often assumed by the public to be better, even though there is often little firm clinical data to support that.'b'As we struggle as a country to come to grips with health care costs, this is one area where there is great opportunity for savings. Clinical reviews can prevent the proliferation of needlessly expensive technology. What the public must come to grips with is that \xe2\x80\x9cnew\xe2\x80\x9d is not automatically \xe2\x80\x9cbetter.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Joseph P. Imperato'b'\n   Lake Forest, Ill., Jan. 24, 2010'b''b''b'The writer is medical director of the Center for Advanced Radiation Medicine at Lake Forest Hospital.'b''b'\xc2\x95'b'To the Editor:'b'Patients who need diagnostic imaging, like X-rays and CT or M.R.I. scans, should play an active role in making sure that they receive optimal care. Landis'b'\n   Seattle, Jan. 24, 2010'b''b''b'The writer is a radiation oncologist.'b''b'It may seem counterintuitive, but with the government reporting stronger-than-expected economic growth at the end of last year, now is the time to think about renewed recession \xe2\x80\x94 and to act to avoid it.'b'The economy grew at an annual rate of 5.7 percent in the fourth quarter of 2009. But well over half of that growth came from large adjustments to business inventories that are unlikely to be repeated on a similar scale in the months to come. As such, they are evidence that the sick economy is recovering, not that it is healthy.'b'Another chunk of growth was due to government stimulus spending, which will wane in 2010. Much of the recent upsurge in business purchases of equipment and software was likely due to a rush to take advantage of an investment tax break before it expired in December.'b'So, what does it take to translate an incipient recovery into a sustained expansion? In a word: jobs. Employment leads to income and to spending. As sales deplete inventories, businesses restock, which creates more jobs and so on in an upward spiral.'b'Unfortunately, with the economy already some 10 million jobs short, there is no job growth on the horizon robust enough to set that upward spiral in motion. And because the economy is already in such a deep hole, a second leg down would mean ever worsening hardship.'b'The House has already passed a bill that is a good starting point for creating jobs. Without such aid, states will have to make even deeper budget cuts \xe2\x80\x94 laying off large numbers of their own work forces and forcing their private sector contractors to do the same.'b'A final bill should also include provisions from the House and the Senate to create infrastructure jobs and public service jobs. And it should adopt the Senate\xe2\x80\x99s plan to create jobs that foster energy efficiency.'b'Mr. Obama said he wanted a jobs bill on his desk \xe2\x80\x9cwithout delay.\xe2\x80\x9d Getting a good bill passed will be a crucial test of his ability to lead lawmakers, including members of his own party, where America needs them to go.'b'There were predictable howls after the Securities and Exchange Commission told publicly held companies they should warn investors of any potential effects from climate change on their bottom lines. A climate change law could also help companies that produce renewable fuels or environmentally friendly technologies, like wind turbines. That, too, should trigger disclosure.'b'The commission, which took pains to say that it was not expressing an opinion on whether the world\xe2\x80\x99s climate was changing, has long required companies to reveal financial or legal impacts from other environmental challenges \xe2\x80\x94 potential liabilities under the Superfund law or the Clean Water Act, for instance. It has also been petitioned by investor groups and environmentalists to add climate change to the list of those challenges.'b'At the same time, ordinary stockholders and state insurance regulators have begun expressing increasing alarm about the potential cost of unchecked climate change for American businesses. That would be L.B.J. in the pre-Kennedy era. Operating with the narrowest of majorities and under an opposition president, he was able to transform a sleepy, seniority-hobbled, regionally polarized debating society into an often-progressive legislative factory. As Robert Caro tells the story in his book \xe2\x80\x9cMaster of the Senate,\xe2\x80\x9d this Senate leader had determination, \xe2\x80\x9ca gift for grand strategy,\xe2\x80\x9d and a sixth sense for grabbing opportunities for action before they vanished for good. Crunching Congressional Budget Office numbers, 'b'David Leonhardt of The Times calculated'b' that of the projected $2 trillion swing into the red between the Clinton surplus and 2012, some 33 percent could be attributed to Bush legislation and another 20 percent to Bush-initiated spending (Iraq, TARP) continued by Obama. Only 7 percent of the deficit could be credited to the Obama stimulus bill and 3 percent to his other initiatives. (The business cycle accounts for the other 37 percent.)'b'Perhaps McCain was sneering at Obama because of the Beltway\xe2\x80\x99s newest unquestioned clich\xc3\xa9: one year after a new president takes office he is required 'b'to stop blaming his predecessor'b' for the calamities left behind.
